description: The Becoming a Linux Server Administrator covers managing Linux servers in a business environment. Topics covered include installing Linux as a server, managing networking and troubleshooting the OS. Other episodes demonstrate how to configure a web server, a file server, and other common servers. The primary goal of the course is to help system administrators learn to deploy and support the Linux operating system as a server platform.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.846
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.846 --> 00:00:07.169
Hello, and thank you for joining us.

3
00:00:07.169 --> 00:00:09.557
In this video we're taking
to look at the upcoming,

4
00:00:09.557 --> 00:00:12.030
Becoming a Linux Server Administrator
series.

5
00:00:12.030 --> 00:00:15.600
And what is becoming
a Linux Server Administrator series?

6
00:00:15.600 --> 00:00:18.300
>> Sure, you know a lot of people out
there wan to learn the Linux operating

7
00:00:18.300 --> 00:00:21.460
systems, it's very popular and most people
get their start working on a desktop.

8
00:00:21.460 --> 00:00:25.400
You install Linux on your laptop, or
your PC, and that's how you learn it.

9
00:00:25.400 --> 00:00:29.950
But in real life land where Linux really
dominates is in the server market.

10
00:00:29.950 --> 00:00:33.180
And you'll find that running Linux
on a server is a lot different

11
00:00:33.180 --> 00:00:35.270
than running Linux on a work station.

12
00:00:35.270 --> 00:00:38.010
So in this series what we do is we try and

13
00:00:38.010 --> 00:00:39.940
get the users accustomed
to working on a server.

14
00:00:39.940 --> 00:00:40.990
We show them that environment,

15
00:00:40.990 --> 00:00:44.110
what it's like working with Linux in
a server environment and the different

16
00:00:44.110 --> 00:00:47.580
administrative tasks we have to perform
to keep that system up and running.

17
00:00:47.580 --> 00:00:51.620
It really helps to take your Linux skills
from hobbyist to professional, and

18
00:00:51.620 --> 00:00:55.230
get you out there in the real world using
trade skills to manage Linux servers.

19
00:00:55.230 --> 00:00:57.190
>> And who is the show targeted towards?

20
00:00:57.190 --> 00:00:59.840
>> Well, this could really apply
to a number of different people,

21
00:00:59.840 --> 00:01:03.530
if you work for a company that implements
Linux servers and you're responsible for

22
00:01:03.530 --> 00:01:06.130
supporting those servers this
series should be great for you.

23
00:01:06.130 --> 00:01:09.120
Cuz we're gonna help you ensure those
servers are installed properly.

24
00:01:09.120 --> 00:01:10.240
And show you how to maintain them.

25
00:01:10.240 --> 00:01:12.420
And run the different services
that are inside of there.

26
00:01:12.420 --> 00:01:14.630
If you're just curious about
how Linux servers work,

27
00:01:14.630 --> 00:01:16.780
this is a great series for you.

28
00:01:16.780 --> 00:01:18.920
But if you're looking to
run Linux on your desktop,

29
00:01:18.920 --> 00:01:22.310
well that's not really a thing
we're going to be covering here.

30
00:01:22.310 --> 00:01:25.450
In fact, we're going to do very very
little with the graphical user interface.

31
00:01:25.450 --> 00:01:27.650
So if you're just getting
started with Linux,

32
00:01:27.650 --> 00:01:29.760
this will be a pretty harsh spot to start.

33
00:01:29.760 --> 00:01:32.950
So, the typical viewer for the series
is gonna be somebody who already

34
00:01:32.950 --> 00:01:34.900
has experience working with
a Linux operating system,

35
00:01:34.900 --> 00:01:37.880
maybe not servers but
at least experience with the OS itself.

36
00:01:37.880 --> 00:01:39.490
And is ready to make that jump.

37
00:01:39.490 --> 00:01:43.175
If you're somebody who's just starting
out, wanting to get that first taste

38
00:01:43.175 --> 00:01:45.675
of working with Linux,
I encourage you to check out our Linux for

39
00:01:45.675 --> 00:01:49.355
Beginners series, or
our Becoming a Linux System Administrator.

40
00:01:49.355 --> 00:01:50.565
Different than server administrator.

41
00:01:50.565 --> 00:01:52.185
System focuses on the desktop.

42
00:01:52.185 --> 00:01:55.225
We use a lot of GUI utilities and other
things there, and you get that experience.

43
00:01:55.225 --> 00:01:59.247
But this one, this series is dedicated
to that person that's got to support

44
00:01:59.247 --> 00:02:01.207
servers and work in that environment.

45
00:02:01.207 --> 00:02:03.507
>> Is there certificated available for
this?

46
00:02:03.507 --> 00:02:05.287
>> No, you know this series is
a little bit different than what we

47
00:02:05.287 --> 00:02:06.207
create normally on [INAUDIBLE] TV.

48
00:02:06.207 --> 00:02:08.527
A lot of our content is
certification based but

49
00:02:08.527 --> 00:02:11.057
here, it's more real world skills based.

50
00:02:11.057 --> 00:02:14.337
I wanna show you guys what it takes to
be able to manage these systems and

51
00:02:14.337 --> 00:02:16.657
give you more of a hands
on practical example.

52
00:02:16.657 --> 00:02:20.210
So as this series goes through, you'll
see where we're doing just examples,

53
00:02:20.210 --> 00:02:22.210
labs we're actually working
with the equipment and

54
00:02:22.210 --> 00:02:25.260
getting it set up and
using it and implementing it.

55
00:02:25.260 --> 00:02:28.810
Without having to worry about what
question is on a particular exam.

56
00:02:28.810 --> 00:02:31.085
There are some great certifications
out there if you're looking for

57
00:02:31.085 --> 00:02:34.700
Linux certifications we have several
on our own site like CompTIA Linux+.

58
00:02:34.700 --> 00:02:37.240
You can check those out and get certified.

59
00:02:37.240 --> 00:02:39.670
But if you're just looking
to get the practical skills,

60
00:02:39.670 --> 00:02:41.300
that's what this series is all about.

61
00:02:41.300 --> 00:02:43.350
>> Now what topics
are covered in this show?

62
00:02:43.350 --> 00:02:44.780
>> Well you know, we cover a big range.

63
00:02:44.780 --> 00:02:45.870
We start with the really important stuff,

64
00:02:45.870 --> 00:02:49.980
which is how you install a Linux server
and how you get it initially set up.

65
00:02:49.980 --> 00:02:52.810
There's a lot of initial configuration
you have to go through to get that Linux

66
00:02:52.810 --> 00:02:55.220
server in place and deployed correctly.

67
00:02:55.220 --> 00:02:58.530
We talked a little bit about securing and
hardening a Linux server,

68
00:02:58.530 --> 00:03:01.550
which is another really important thing
because these servers are typically

69
00:03:01.550 --> 00:03:03.740
exposed to the Internet, and
that makes them a security risk.

70
00:03:03.740 --> 00:03:06.090
So we've gotta make sure that
they're configured properly.

71
00:03:06.090 --> 00:03:09.790
After that, we're gonna break
down into individual services.

72
00:03:09.790 --> 00:03:12.030
And we'll take a look at
how to set up a web server,

73
00:03:12.030 --> 00:03:13.900
we'll talk about how to
set up a database server,

74
00:03:13.900 --> 00:03:18.830
we'll talk about how to do Samba and
file sharing, NFS, another file system.

75
00:03:18.830 --> 00:03:22.590
And so different kind of roles that
your Linux server can perform.

76
00:03:22.590 --> 00:03:26.170
Now we're gonna take a look
at these from the basics.

77
00:03:26.170 --> 00:03:27.740
Take for example a database server.

78
00:03:27.740 --> 00:03:29.720
If I wanna set up MariaDB.

79
00:03:29.720 --> 00:03:33.948
Well, we could have 100 hours of
content on how just to setup MariaDB.

80
00:03:33.948 --> 00:03:36.180
So in this series it's
more of an introduction.

81
00:03:36.180 --> 00:03:38.750
How we get the database server deployed,
how we connect to it,

82
00:03:38.750 --> 00:03:42.150
how we make sure it's secured
properly to be able to put it in use.

83
00:03:42.150 --> 00:03:46.480
But you can carry that knowledge on and go
into the more advanced courses later on to

84
00:03:46.480 --> 00:03:47.890
learn more about these
individual products.

85
00:03:47.890 --> 00:03:51.250
But here we'll look at how to set up
all these difference server types and

86
00:03:51.250 --> 00:03:52.840
get them running in
the production environment.

87
00:03:52.840 --> 00:03:53.710
>> That sounds great.

88
00:03:53.710 --> 00:03:56.910
Becoming a Linux server administrator,
if this sounds interesting to you, and I'm

89
00:03:56.910 --> 00:04:02.100
sure it does, watch all the video content
in becoming a Linux server administrator.

90
00:04:02.100 --> 00:04:03.410
Thank you for watching.

91
00:04:03.410 --> 00:04:04.326
See you soon.

92
00:04:04.326 --> 00:04:08.912
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss Installing Linux as a Server, why install it, how to install it, starting the Server, monitoring the Server, obtaining installation media, obtaining the necessary hardware, performing the install, and what you need to know when working with Red Hat 7.3 / Ubuntu / & Centos in regards to the installation of Linux as a Server.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.330 --> 00:00:06.334
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.334 --> 00:00:07.964
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:07.964 --> 00:00:12.101
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:12.101 --> 00:00:14.620
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:14.620 --> 00:00:17.020
Helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:17.020 --> 00:00:19.358
I'm your host Zach Memos
as we continue on,

7
00:00:19.358 --> 00:00:23.737
where we actually begin a brand series,
Becoming A Linux Server Administrator.

8
00:00:23.737 --> 00:00:27.674
And bringing us all the information
we need is our IT pro, Don Pezet.

9
00:00:27.674 --> 00:00:29.034
Hey, Don, good to see you sir.

10
00:00:29.034 --> 00:00:31.639
>> Hey, Zach, I am excited to
be kicking off a new series and

11
00:00:31.639 --> 00:00:35.332
this is actually a pretty fun one for me
cuz I love working with Linux servers, and

12
00:00:35.332 --> 00:00:38.840
so that's what we're gonna be doing
right here in this very first episode.

13
00:00:38.840 --> 00:00:42.790
So we're gonna be talking about what's
involved in just installing a Linux

14
00:00:42.790 --> 00:00:43.380
server.

15
00:00:43.380 --> 00:00:46.503
What it takes to run the Linux operating
system as a server in your environment or

16
00:00:46.503 --> 00:00:47.073
in the cloud.

17
00:00:47.073 --> 00:00:49.050
It's really all the same to Linux.

18
00:00:49.050 --> 00:00:52.185
So we'll get a chance to see this right
here as we walk through the initial steps

19
00:00:52.185 --> 00:00:53.955
of becoming a Linux Server Administrator.

20
00:00:53.955 --> 00:00:58.800
>> So, the basic question is what are
the steps to install Linux as a server?

21
00:00:58.800 --> 00:01:02.590
>> All right, so, it's not all that much
different than other operating systems.

22
00:01:02.590 --> 00:01:04.530
The way we execute the steps
is very different but

23
00:01:04.530 --> 00:01:06.470
the steps themselves are pretty
straight forward, right?

24
00:01:06.470 --> 00:01:09.332
Step one, we gotta install
the operating system, right?

25
00:01:09.332 --> 00:01:11.350
So, what is that entail?

26
00:01:11.350 --> 00:01:12.387
How is that different than a normal OS?

27
00:01:12.387 --> 00:01:13.294
So we'll get a chance to see that.

28
00:01:13.294 --> 00:01:15.270
So, that's what step one is gonna be.

29
00:01:15.270 --> 00:01:16.790
But after that we're not just done right.

30
00:01:16.790 --> 00:01:17.797
We've gotta configure the server,

31
00:01:17.797 --> 00:01:19.680
where there's a lot of things
that will have to change.

32
00:01:19.680 --> 00:01:24.310
The default install is not necessarily
very useful to us, we need to modify it

33
00:01:24.310 --> 00:01:27.800
to our needs and get it set up
the way that we want to implement it.

34
00:01:27.800 --> 00:01:29.543
Step three we've got firing up the server,
right.

35
00:01:29.543 --> 00:01:32.395
You gotta start it up, make sure
everything's working properly because,

36
00:01:32.395 --> 00:01:35.202
just because the install's over doesn't
mean that everything is working

37
00:01:35.202 --> 00:01:36.690
the way we expect.

38
00:01:36.690 --> 00:01:39.140
The next step is to secure the server.

39
00:01:39.140 --> 00:01:41.600
The default install makes
a lot of assumptions.

40
00:01:41.600 --> 00:01:45.960
And those assumptions aren't
necessarily the best choices in life.

41
00:01:45.960 --> 00:01:49.050
So we'll need to come in and
do what's called hardening the server.

42
00:01:49.050 --> 00:01:51.070
Closing down any services we're not using,

43
00:01:51.070 --> 00:01:53.710
disabling any defaults that we don't need,
and making sure

44
00:01:53.710 --> 00:01:57.710
the system is secure as possible before
we throw it out there into the wild.

45
00:01:57.710 --> 00:02:01.690
And then the last step is, well,
technically, we're done setting it up.

46
00:02:01.690 --> 00:02:04.218
But we need to monitor it,
we need to maintain it,

47
00:02:04.218 --> 00:02:07.430
we need to make sure that server
stays up and running reliably.

48
00:02:07.430 --> 00:02:09.780
So what are the different things
that we need to set up to do that?

49
00:02:09.780 --> 00:02:11.770
That's all kind of in that fifth step.

50
00:02:11.770 --> 00:02:13.130
So it's a lot to do.

51
00:02:13.130 --> 00:02:17.836
It's a lot involved in it and
while I know that I could install a Linux

52
00:02:17.836 --> 00:02:21.487
server in I don't know five
minutes probably tops.

53
00:02:21.487 --> 00:02:24.680
Get one spun out and deployed out
there as a web server or something.

54
00:02:24.680 --> 00:02:26.816
There's a lot of decisions
that go into that.

55
00:02:26.816 --> 00:02:28.640
>> Mm-hm.
>> And if you're just starting out and

56
00:02:28.640 --> 00:02:31.100
just learning you need to know
what all those decisions are.

57
00:02:31.100 --> 00:02:31.985
So we're gonna take it slow.

58
00:02:31.985 --> 00:02:33.900
We're not gonna try and
deploy a server in five minutes.

59
00:02:33.900 --> 00:02:38.389
We'll walk through the process and see how
we can make decisions that change the way

60
00:02:38.389 --> 00:02:41.675
that servers functions, and
get it working the best for us.

61
00:02:41.675 --> 00:02:43.619
>> So, where do we start?

62
00:02:43.619 --> 00:02:45.788
>> All right, so step one,
just like any operating system,

63
00:02:45.788 --> 00:02:48.830
if you're gonna install you need to
get the installation media, right?

64
00:02:48.830 --> 00:02:51.350
If you watched our becoming
a Linux System Administrator show,

65
00:02:51.350 --> 00:02:53.440
we've all ready shown you how to do that.

66
00:02:53.440 --> 00:02:57.110
If you're just starting out here, the way
you get installation media is a little

67
00:02:57.110 --> 00:02:59.620
different depending on which
distribution you choose.

68
00:02:59.620 --> 00:03:03.680
Now out there in real life land,
when it comes down to Linux servers,

69
00:03:03.680 --> 00:03:07.670
there's really three primary
distributions that are used today.

70
00:03:07.670 --> 00:03:11.310
In the desktop world, everybody has
a different distro they prefer.

71
00:03:11.310 --> 00:03:13.387
I like Linux Mint or I like XYZ.

72
00:03:13.387 --> 00:03:15.100
There's all sorts of distros.

73
00:03:15.100 --> 00:03:16.840
But in the server world,

74
00:03:16.840 --> 00:03:20.270
this is where we're dealing with
mission critical applications.

75
00:03:20.270 --> 00:03:23.611
Applications that if they fail,
they don't just affect you, right?

76
00:03:23.611 --> 00:03:26.730
Like, if my laptop fails,
it inconveniences me and that's it.

77
00:03:26.730 --> 00:03:29.813
Zach doesn't care if my laptop fails.

78
00:03:29.813 --> 00:03:30.629
>> I do care though.

79
00:03:30.629 --> 00:03:31.998
>> Maybe we have an emotional bond, right?

80
00:03:31.998 --> 00:03:36.435
But as far your ability to work Is not
impacted, but if the web server were to go

81
00:03:36.435 --> 00:03:41.170
down, right, or our video server, you
guys are watching this video streaming.

82
00:03:41.170 --> 00:03:44.915
That video server failed, all of you
viewers out there would lose access.

83
00:03:44.915 --> 00:03:48.570
Now it's one system failing
affecting a ton of people.

84
00:03:48.570 --> 00:03:53.880
So, when businesses deploy Linux as
an operating system for a server.

85
00:03:53.880 --> 00:03:57.700
They wanna pick an operating system
that is reliable and solid, and

86
00:03:57.700 --> 00:04:01.760
that if something goes wrong,
they have somebody to call, right?

87
00:04:01.760 --> 00:04:04.460
Slackware Linux,
I love Slackware Linux, but

88
00:04:04.460 --> 00:04:07.260
if something goes wrong,
there's no one to call.

89
00:04:07.260 --> 00:04:10.953
You can post a message in one of the email
lists and usually get made fun of for

90
00:04:10.953 --> 00:04:14.189
a few days and that's it and
never actually get any help, right?

91
00:04:14.189 --> 00:04:15.938
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's the culture that's been built in

92
00:04:15.938 --> 00:04:17.090
the Linux community.

93
00:04:17.090 --> 00:04:20.000
But there's nobody there to call for help.

94
00:04:20.000 --> 00:04:21.900
A lot of the OS' are like that.

95
00:04:21.900 --> 00:04:25.210
And so in the server world you
see this gravitation towards OS'

96
00:04:25.210 --> 00:04:26.960
that actually have a support structure.

97
00:04:26.960 --> 00:04:31.701
And the two leading operating systems,
are Red Hat Enterprise Linux from

98
00:04:31.701 --> 00:04:37.273
the Red Hat Company and then you have
Ubuntu Linux which is from right?

99
00:04:37.273 --> 00:04:41.050
And Red Hat are two
commercial organizations.

100
00:04:41.050 --> 00:04:45.960
You get Linux from them and
you pay them for support.

101
00:04:45.960 --> 00:04:49.320
Net support says, if something goes
wrong you can call them on the phone and

102
00:04:49.320 --> 00:04:52.130
they will help you get through the issues.

103
00:04:52.130 --> 00:04:53.560
That's really important.

104
00:04:53.560 --> 00:04:57.240
They're also reviewing security patches
and updates and pushing them out and

105
00:04:57.240 --> 00:04:59.660
making sure that you get up to date right?

106
00:04:59.660 --> 00:05:02.051
Now, I mention a moment ago that
there's three distributions,

107
00:05:02.051 --> 00:05:03.191
I just mentioned two, right?

108
00:05:03.191 --> 00:05:07.670
Red Hat Enterprise Linux and
Ubuntu, the third one is CentOS.

109
00:05:07.670 --> 00:05:13.119
And CentOS is the community enterprise
operating system, C-E-N-T-O-S and

110
00:05:13.119 --> 00:05:17.260
CentOS Is technically Red Hat, right?

111
00:05:17.260 --> 00:05:19.312
Red Hat and Ubuntu have kind
of taken different models for

112
00:05:19.312 --> 00:05:20.217
how their system works.

113
00:05:20.217 --> 00:05:22.060
So let me show you here,
I'll pull up the web page.

114
00:05:22.060 --> 00:05:23.810
Let's start with Ubuntu.

115
00:05:23.810 --> 00:05:27.270
So if you go to Ubuntu's website,
Ubuntu.com, right?

116
00:05:27.270 --> 00:05:29.910
There is a commercial
entity named Canonical and

117
00:05:29.910 --> 00:05:32.610
they need to make money, they need
to make money to stay in business.

118
00:05:32.610 --> 00:05:35.490
And they make their money through support.

119
00:05:35.490 --> 00:05:39.753
If you go to their website and you look up
top, there's all these options here and

120
00:05:39.753 --> 00:05:40.894
you'll see server.

121
00:05:40.894 --> 00:05:44.950
And I can go to server and
I can learn about their server options.

122
00:05:44.950 --> 00:05:47.240
And I can download Ubuntu
server right here.

123
00:05:47.240 --> 00:05:49.320
If I had just gone straight to downloads,

124
00:05:49.320 --> 00:05:52.430
I've got the option of download server or
desktop.

125
00:05:52.430 --> 00:05:55.220
Under the hood It's the same Linux Kernel,

126
00:05:55.220 --> 00:05:59.610
it's the same core operating system,
it's just configured differently.

00:28:40.280 --> 00:28:44.800
just redo that root password, just because
I'm not positive if my caps lock was on or

573
00:28:44.800 --> 00:28:45.630
not when I did it.

574
00:28:47.580 --> 00:28:50.310
So let's try that, there we go.

575
00:28:50.310 --> 00:28:53.000
And now that's gonna churn through and
do the installation.

576
00:28:53.000 --> 00:28:59.091
Now technically that brings
us to the end of step one.

577
00:28:59.091 --> 00:29:02.070
I figured we'd get further in this
episode but that's the end of step one.

578
00:29:02.070 --> 00:29:06.560
It's doing the install,
when it's done it's going to reboot and

579
00:29:06.560 --> 00:29:08.580
everything's been working great so far.

580
00:29:08.580 --> 00:29:11.720
I haven't had any problems I've been
able to navigate through my windows and

581
00:29:11.720 --> 00:29:14.880
all that but
just because the installer ran great

582
00:29:14.880 --> 00:29:18.410
doesn't mean the actual
install went great.

583
00:29:18.410 --> 00:29:21.740
When you reboot you may have
hardware that didn't get detected,

584
00:29:21.740 --> 00:29:24.860
you may have other problems
that we just didn't see.

585
00:29:24.860 --> 00:29:29.940
So as part of any install, the next step
would be to verify the installation,

586
00:29:29.940 --> 00:29:32.000
to make sure all your
hardware was detected.

587
00:29:32.000 --> 00:29:34.740
And if you haven't watched our
Linux system administration series,

588
00:29:34.740 --> 00:29:35.920
I definitely encourage
you to jump back and

589
00:29:35.920 --> 00:29:38.500
check that out because I show
you the hardware process there.

590
00:29:38.500 --> 00:29:41.700
How to detect all of
your hardware on servers,

591
00:29:41.700 --> 00:29:45.760
all we normally care about our
network adapters and rate controllers.

592
00:29:45.760 --> 00:29:47.350
The rate controllers
will determine whether or

593
00:29:47.350 --> 00:29:48.920
not your hard drives were detected.

594
00:29:48.920 --> 00:29:50.590
The network adapters are whether
you can talk on the network.

595
00:29:50.590 --> 00:29:52.090
So we need to verify those are there,

596
00:29:52.090 --> 00:29:54.640
and I show you how to do that in
the systems administration series.

597
00:29:54.640 --> 00:29:57.940
But, definitely,
make sure you verify that install.

598
00:29:57.940 --> 00:30:00.970
After that, we are technically
done with the installation,

599
00:30:00.970 --> 00:30:02.910
and we're ready to customize
it to meet our needs.

600
00:30:04.440 --> 00:30:07.890
All right, well instead of sitting here
waiting, looks like it's about 50% done.

601
00:30:07.890 --> 00:30:11.590
It's actually done copying the files cuz
it's not really a whole lot of files, but

602
00:30:11.590 --> 00:30:12.870
now it's configuring add-ons and
other things.

603
00:30:12.870 --> 00:30:16.070
So we gotta give a little
time to finish that install.

604
00:30:16.070 --> 00:30:20.800
Why don't we stop here and
we'll do a part two in this series, and

605
00:30:20.800 --> 00:30:24.130
in part two, I wanna show you the initial
configuration of this machine,

606
00:30:24.130 --> 00:30:26.420
what we need to get it actually setup.

607
00:30:26.420 --> 00:30:27.690
To be able to start using it.

608
00:30:27.690 --> 00:30:31.020
And we'll tackle that as soon is
this install is done in part two.

609
00:30:31.020 --> 00:30:32.400
>> Awesome job, Don.

610
00:30:32.400 --> 00:30:36.570
Becoming a Linux server administrator,
installing Linux as a server.

611
00:30:36.570 --> 00:30:37.900
This has been part one.

612
00:30:37.900 --> 00:30:39.410
Any final words?

613
00:30:39.410 --> 00:30:42.580
>> Main thing here is pay
attention during the install.

614
00:30:42.580 --> 00:30:46.010
Don't just click Next 15 times,
because on a server there's changes.

615
00:30:46.010 --> 00:30:47.840
And we need to be involved
in every decision so

616
00:30:47.840 --> 00:30:49.900
we know we're making the right ones.

617
00:30:49.900 --> 00:30:52.210
And make sure you practice this stuff.

618
00:30:52.210 --> 00:30:54.610
Practice in a lab before you
roll it out in production.

619
00:30:54.610 --> 00:30:56.810
Because if this is exposed
to the Internet and

620
00:30:56.810 --> 00:31:00.090
you missed some security setting,
the hackers won't miss it.

621
00:31:00.090 --> 00:31:00.950
They'll find that.

622
00:31:00.950 --> 00:31:03.269
So we need to make sure that we're
taking the proper precautions.

623
00:31:04.340 --> 00:31:07.720
>> Well, installing Linux as a server,
part two, it'll be soon.

624
00:31:07.720 --> 00:31:10.920
And you wanna watch
everything in the Becoming

625
00:31:10.920 --> 00:31:12.780
a Linux Server Administrator series.

626
00:31:12.780 --> 00:31:14.090
You'll be glad you did.

627
00:31:14.090 --> 00:31:16.040
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

628
00:31:16.040 --> 00:31:18.520
Remember, a good IT pro
is always learning.

629
00:31:18.520 --> 00:31:19.430
I'm Zach Memos.

630
00:31:19.430 --> 00:31:20.360
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

631
00:31:20.360 --> 00:31:22.840
>> And we'll see you very soon.

632
00:31:22.840 --> 00:31:28.768
[MUSIC]

633
00:31:28.768 --> 00:31:31.683
Thank you for watching ITPro TV.

episodes.description: Don and Zach continue to cover Installing Linux As A Server, what kind of configuration is needed from the start, configuring the Server, Licensing, Networking, Drivers, Default Files, User Accounts, starting the Server, performing updates, and performing a reboot.
episodes.title: Installing Linux as a Server Part 2

episodes.description: Don and Zach cover what we need to do to secure the server, configuring passwords, configuring certificates, configure firewall, determine default zone, allow a standard service through firewall, adding custom services, allowing a non-standard service through firewall, configure TCP Wrappers, configure SELinux, view SELinux log, configure service related security, monitoring the Server, and performing updates.
episodes.title: Hardening a Linux Server
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:07.529
Welcome to ITProTV [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:07.529 --> 00:00:11.465
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.465 --> 00:00:14.640
>> Hello again and
thank you for watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:14.640 --> 00:00:19.030
Helping you learn wherever you go,
I'm your host Zach Memos as we continue on

5
00:00:19.030 --> 00:00:21.400
with becoming a Linux
server administrator.

6
00:00:21.400 --> 00:00:27.130
And this is hardening a Linux server and
it's gonna be interesting and wonderful.

7
00:00:27.130 --> 00:00:30.540
And Don Pezet is gonna bring us all the
information we need because he knows so

8
00:00:30.540 --> 00:00:31.870
much about it.

9
00:00:31.870 --> 00:00:33.200
Don't you?
>> [LAUGH] I try.

10
00:00:33.200 --> 00:00:36.300
Well, you know in this episode like Zach
said we are going to be tackling hardening

11
00:00:36.300 --> 00:00:37.370
a Linux server.

12
00:00:37.370 --> 00:00:39.270
When you do a default install and

13
00:00:39.270 --> 00:00:43.400
you install any of them Ubuntu,
Red Hat or whatever.

14
00:00:43.400 --> 00:00:46.080
The default operating system

15
00:00:46.080 --> 00:00:49.810
is configure in a way to make it the most
convenient for the most users, and

16
00:00:49.810 --> 00:00:53.750
that means that it's not necessarily
configured as securely as possible.

17
00:00:53.750 --> 00:00:54.940
So whenever we deploy a new system,

18
00:00:54.940 --> 00:00:59.600
one of our first actions needs
to be make it more secure.

19
00:00:59.600 --> 00:01:02.520
Turning off all things around using,
restricting some access to base.

20
00:01:02.520 --> 00:01:05.844
So that's what we're gonna be taking a
look at in our episode here is we kind of

21
00:01:05.844 --> 00:01:08.861
run through that process of getting
a server ready to be pushed out into

22
00:01:08.861 --> 00:01:09.490
production.

23
00:01:09.490 --> 00:01:12.240
>> Again Don thanks for
doing this and what do we need to do?

24
00:01:12.240 --> 00:01:14.970
Or how do we begin to secure the server?

25
00:01:14.970 --> 00:01:16.460
What do we have to start?

26
00:01:16.460 --> 00:01:20.980
>> Well step number one really is kind
of performing an inventory right.

27
00:01:20.980 --> 00:01:24.660
An inventory of what you intend to
do with that server because there's

28
00:01:24.660 --> 00:01:27.280
going to be certain things
you need to allow and

29
00:01:27.280 --> 00:01:29.650
certain things you don't
need to allow on a system.

30
00:01:29.650 --> 00:01:34.385
So if I wanna have a web server,
I'm gonna need a web service running and

31
00:01:34.385 --> 00:01:36.300
I'm gonna need to allow
people to get to it.

32
00:01:36.300 --> 00:01:40.390
So if I really wanna harden a server
the best way to do it is to turn off

33
00:01:40.390 --> 00:01:43.270
all the network adaptors,
just turn them all off right.

34
00:01:43.270 --> 00:01:45.910
Now nobody can get your
system from the network.

35
00:01:45.910 --> 00:01:49.810
But that's a problem if I wanna run a web
server, nobody can get to it right in here

36
00:01:49.810 --> 00:01:52.360
the most secured computer is
the one that powered off.

37
00:01:52.360 --> 00:01:54.530
But if it's power off it
is not really useful so

38
00:01:54.530 --> 00:01:58.380
I need to come up in the inventory
of what is I intend to do.

39
00:01:58.380 --> 00:02:04.450
And then I need to provide the minimal
level of access to provide that service.

40
00:02:04.450 --> 00:02:07.851
And the best way to get started with
that is through the configuration of

41
00:02:07.851 --> 00:02:09.035
a firewall.

42
00:02:09.035 --> 00:02:11.950
Then we can use a firewall
service on your system.

43
00:02:11.950 --> 00:02:14.610
You more than likely
have hardware firewalls.

44
00:02:14.610 --> 00:02:18.260
We use software firewalls also
because you want defense in depth.

45
00:02:18.260 --> 00:02:21.370
And in that software
firewall we can restrict and

46
00:02:21.370 --> 00:02:25.920
only allow the traffic that we
specifically want into our system.

47
00:02:25.920 --> 00:02:28.180
Now when you start coming
up with that inventory,

48
00:02:28.180 --> 00:02:32.890
you need to think of things like I want to
remotely administer that server with SSH.

49
00:02:32.890 --> 00:02:35.710
So it might be a web server,
which doesn't need SSH, but

50
00:02:35.710 --> 00:02:40.360
I might allow SSH anyway, so that I can
get in and remotely manage that system.

51
00:02:40.360 --> 00:02:42.540
If it's gonna be a web server
I do need to allow web ports,

52
00:02:42.540 --> 00:02:46.280
and so I'll need to figure out what ports
I need to open up for that service.

53
00:02:46.280 --> 00:02:50.700
And most distros come with a software
firewall enabled by default.

54
00:02:50.700 --> 00:02:53.930
In Ubuntu you have
the IP Tables Firewall utility.

55
00:02:53.930 --> 00:02:56.212
That software's been around a long,
long time.

56
00:02:56.212 --> 00:02:59.810
Red Hat has made the switch over to
FirewallD which is a newer firewall daemon

57
00:02:59.810 --> 00:03:00.310
that's out there.

58
00:03:00.310 --> 00:03:02.400
Ubuntu eventually will
switch over to FirewallD.

59
00:03:02.400 --> 00:03:05.190
So that's usually the one that
we wanna worry about today.

60
00:03:05.190 --> 00:03:08.750
But either one, whichever firewall
you're using, they all work the same.

61
00:03:08.750 --> 00:03:10.960
You go in and you specify rules, and

62
00:03:10.960 --> 00:03:14.860
the rules dictate who is allowed
to come in and who isn't?

63
00:03:14.860 --> 00:03:17.990
Right and if you're not on the list,
you get blocked and you get stopped and

64
00:03:17.990 --> 00:03:19.773
you can't access the system.

65
00:03:19.773 --> 00:03:24.420
Now, if you're distro included a firewall,
it's gonna have some default rules.

66
00:03:24.420 --> 00:03:27.310
And those default rules might be great,
they might be terrible.

67
00:03:27.310 --> 00:03:30.780
They might be saying, everyone's allowed
in so you're running a firewall service,

68
00:03:30.780 --> 00:03:32.010
but it's not doing anything.

69
00:03:32.010 --> 00:03:34.110
So we need to get in there and
start to manipulate that.

70
00:03:34.110 --> 00:03:36.090
So I'm gonna take this
Red Hat system that I've got.

71
00:03:36.090 --> 00:03:40.250
This is the one that we installed
in the first part of this series.

72
00:03:40.250 --> 00:03:42.920
So I've installed
Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.3.

73
00:03:42.920 --> 00:03:46.130
And I chose to do a minimal install.

74
00:03:46.130 --> 00:03:49.380
The only thing I've changed
on this system is actually,

75
00:03:49.380 --> 00:03:51.040
have I changed anything at this point?

76
00:03:51.040 --> 00:03:52.360
[LAUGH] I haven't really changed anything.

77
00:03:52.360 --> 00:03:54.290
>> No.
>> I registered it to my account and

78
00:03:54.290 --> 00:03:55.390
I did some updates.

79
00:03:55.390 --> 00:03:56.480
That's it, right?

80
00:03:56.480 --> 00:04:01.540
So if I wanna take a look at it here, I
can come in and say, firewall -cmd, right?

81
00:04:01.540 --> 00:04:05.330
That's the FirewallD utility for
manipulating the firewall.

82
00:04:05.330 --> 00:04:08.290
And I can do a --state to
look at its current state,

83
00:04:08.290 --> 00:04:09.800
to find out if it's running or not.

84
00:04:09.800 --> 00:04:14.460
And I'm actually gonna pseudo that so
that it'll run as the administrator.

85
00:04:14.460 --> 00:04:17.030
And I can see the firewall
is indeed running.

86
00:04:17.030 --> 00:04:18.160
I didn't tell it to do that.

87
00:04:18.160 --> 00:04:22.141
That was part of the default install,
it configured FirewallD and

88
00:04:22.141 --> 00:04:24.950
it turned it on so I am filtering traffic.

89
00:04:24.950 --> 00:04:30.090
If you do a firewall
that's cmd-- get- zones,

90
00:04:30.090 --> 00:04:33.220
what you'll see is where
it's created several zones.

91
00:04:33.220 --> 00:04:37.580
Work, drop, internal, external,
trusted home, DMZ, public block.

92
00:04:37.580 --> 00:04:40.830
Each of these are collections of rules and

93
00:04:40.830 --> 00:04:45.020
every network adapter gets
assigned to one of these zones.

94
00:04:45.020 --> 00:04:49.690
I might have a zone like work,
where, I trust my work network.

95
00:04:49.690 --> 00:04:52.110
And so I might allow everything
to pass through that one.

96
00:04:52.110 --> 00:04:55.930
But then I might have a zone like DMZ,
where I don't trust anything, and

97
00:04:55.930 --> 00:04:57.820
that one's really strict.

98
00:04:57.820 --> 00:05:00.715
And if I have multiple network
adapters In my system,

99
00:05:00.715 --> 00:05:03.997
some that work adaptors might be on
trusted networks some might not, right.

100
00:05:03.997 --> 00:05:06.925
I might have web server and
the web interface,

101
00:05:06.925 --> 00:05:08.445
the one that's facing the internet.

102
00:05:08.445 --> 00:05:09.525
I don't trust it at all.

103
00:05:09.525 --> 00:05:11.975
The internet is a dangerous place so
it's really restrictive.

104
00:05:11.975 --> 00:05:14.745
But there might be another interface
that faces the internal network so

105
00:05:14.745 --> 00:05:15.625
I do allow it.

106
00:05:15.625 --> 00:05:17.820
So these zones become really important.

107
00:05:17.820 --> 00:05:22.600
But most of us deploy servers with
just one network adapter, right?

108
00:05:22.600 --> 00:05:24.460
If it's a web server it faces
the internet, and that's it.

109
00:05:24.460 --> 00:05:28.790
And if I look at this server, I can see
that in fact I do just have one adapter.

110
00:05:28.790 --> 00:05:30.000
ENS33 right there.

111
00:05:30.000 --> 00:05:32.180
So that's the adapter that I've got, and

112
00:05:32.180 --> 00:05:35.280
it's going to be stuck
inside one of these zones.

113
00:05:35.280 --> 00:05:42.360
If I do a firewall cmd --get Default zone.

114
00:05:42.360 --> 00:05:46.320
What you'll find is that there's
a zone that's defined by default and

115
00:05:46.320 --> 00:05:47.730
that's where your adapters are.

116
00:05:47.730 --> 00:05:49.810
So all of my adapters are gonna
be in this default zone.

117
00:05:49.810 --> 00:05:51.590
My default zone is called Public.

118
00:05:51.590 --> 00:05:55.390
And unless I move them to another zone,
that's where they're all going to reside.

119
00:05:55.390 --> 00:05:57.340
And if I could move them if I need to.

120
00:05:57.340 --> 00:06:00.070
But mine is fine right there.

121
00:06:00.070 --> 00:06:05.400
And so inside of that zone it's got rules
that are restricting or allowing access.

122
00:06:05.400 --> 00:06:07.760
And so I just need to configure
that to meet my needs.

123
00:06:07.760 --> 00:06:11.160
So for example, if I'm running a standard
service that's pretty easy right?

124
00:06:11.160 --> 00:06:16.780
Web servers, database servers
because you can just come in and

125
00:06:16.780 --> 00:06:20.820
say firewall-cmd --get-services.

126
00:06:20.820 --> 00:06:23.070
And you'll see a list of
standard services they support.

127
00:06:23.070 --> 00:06:25.770
And so if I wanna allow our servers
through that's in this list,

128
00:06:25.770 --> 00:06:27.450
that makes life really easy.

129
00:06:27.450 --> 00:06:31.182
So if I am doing a web server for
example here's HTTP and HTTPS,

130
00:06:31.182 --> 00:06:35.820
I probably wanna allow those through
they're defined right here right?

131
00:06:35.820 --> 00:06:41.214
So I can come in and
I can say something like firewall-cmd.

132
00:06:41.214 --> 00:06:44.240
Hang on let me pseudo that, firewallcmd,

133
00:06:44.240 --> 00:06:48.276
I can say -- zone=public,
that's the default zone so

134
00:06:48.276 --> 00:06:53.790
I could leave this off if I had other
zones I would have to specify it here.

135
00:06:53.790 --> 00:07:02.070
So zone=public and
then I could say --add-service=http.

136
00:07:02.070 --> 00:07:05.800
And that's going to allow http
to pass through the firewall.

137
00:07:05.800 --> 00:07:07.549
And I could follow it up with https and

138
00:07:07.549 --> 00:07:10.433
that's going to allow it to
pass through the firewall also.

139
00:07:10.433 --> 00:07:14.308
I'm opening up these ports if I didn't
want them I could do the remove server so

140
00:07:14.308 --> 00:07:19.490
delete service--DEL-service, and delete
them out of there and close those ports.

141
00:07:19.490 --> 00:07:22.550
Now quick word of warning
with these commands.

142
00:07:22.550 --> 00:07:26.270
These commands are actually temporary,
I'm modifying in configuration in memory.

143
00:07:26.270 --> 00:07:28.370
If I reboot, I'm gonna lose all these.

144
00:07:28.370 --> 00:07:34.670
So I need to run them a second
time with --permanent added to it.

145
00:07:34.670 --> 00:07:36.530
And that's gonna add it to
the configuration file, so

146
00:07:36.530 --> 00:07:37.920
it'll be there when we start up.

147
00:07:37.920 --> 00:07:40.990
If I just ran it with permanent,
it actually doesn't modify it in memory.

148
00:07:40.990 --> 00:07:41.990
So I have to do both.

149
00:07:41.990 --> 00:07:44.350
I have to make sure I run
both sets of commands.

150
00:07:44.350 --> 00:07:46.420
So that we get in there and
we secure it, right?

151
00:07:46.420 --> 00:07:50.950
So there, I've done http and https and
kinda added those to the list.

152
00:07:50.950 --> 00:07:54.797
If you're working with simple
standard services like these,

153
00:07:54.797 --> 00:07:58.001
it's really easy to just add them in or
remove them.

154
00:07:58.001 --> 00:08:01.828
If you pull up the MAN file for
firewall-cmd, You can look around in there

155
00:08:01.828 --> 00:08:05.964
and you'll see a ton of options that make
it easy to verify that state, to reload

156
00:08:05.964 --> 00:08:10.250
the firewall if you need to test, whether
those configuration items were saved.

157
00:08:10.250 --> 00:08:12.410
You can pull all
the information right from here,

158
00:08:12.410 --> 00:08:17.940
it's really pretty straight forward how
to work with it, and see what's going on.

159
00:08:17.940 --> 00:08:21.850
So, they try to make it as easy as
possible with the iptables firewall,

160
00:08:21.850 --> 00:08:24.270
the older version, you had to go and
modify a config file,

161
00:08:24.270 --> 00:08:26.130

00:14:44.560 --> 00:14:46.510
Now that means it builds
an encrypted tunnel and

294
00:14:46.510 --> 00:14:47.910
then sends it over the network encrypted.

295
00:14:47.910 --> 00:14:51.650
If I just copy and paste this,
I might do it through a non-secure means.

296
00:14:51.650 --> 00:14:53.400
I might send it via email or
something, right.

297
00:14:53.400 --> 00:14:56.110
So the SSH copy ID utility
can help us to do that.

298
00:14:56.110 --> 00:14:57.010
But at the end of the day,

299
00:14:57.010 --> 00:15:01.810
I need to get this public key stored
in my home directory on the server.

300
00:15:01.810 --> 00:15:03.917
So I'll use ssh-copy-id, and

301
00:15:03.917 --> 00:15:08.742
you basically just specify the server
that you're gonna be connecting to.

302
00:15:08.742 --> 00:15:16.380
So I'm gonna use dpezet@172.16.0.100,
right, so I'm pointing to that server.

303
00:15:16.380 --> 00:15:20.330
And it's gonna reach out to the server and
it's gonna ask me for my password, right?

304
00:15:20.330 --> 00:15:22.470
It's building up an SSH tunnel.

305
00:15:22.470 --> 00:15:24.060
And once it builds the SSH tunnel,

306
00:15:24.060 --> 00:15:28.600
then it's gonna copy my key
over to the server, okay?

307
00:15:28.600 --> 00:15:32.145
And that's important because
when I looked at that key

308
00:15:32.145 --> 00:15:38.090
here, What you saw was this information.

309
00:15:38.090 --> 00:15:40.370
And then if I jump over to the server.

310
00:15:42.202 --> 00:15:43.153
Let's see.

311
00:15:46.102 --> 00:15:48.340
Let me try to get these
close to the same size.

312
00:15:48.340 --> 00:15:52.180
Oops, a little bit on the giant side.

313
00:15:52.180 --> 00:15:56.706
So I will log into that server,
and I'll show you what it did.

314
00:15:56.706 --> 00:16:00.615
So when I login to the server,
Here I am, and

315
00:16:00.615 --> 00:16:06.535
when I look in my home directory,
I can go into that .ssh folder and

316
00:16:06.535 --> 00:16:11.250
I see this authorized_keys file,
all right.

317
00:16:11.250 --> 00:16:15.815
And if I take a look at that
authorized_keys file, it's copied that

318
00:16:15.815 --> 00:16:20.945
public key that I had right over into
the system, and there it is, all right.

319
00:16:20.945 --> 00:16:25.319
So now the server knows that I have an
authorized key, and if I wanna connect in,

320
00:16:25.319 --> 00:16:27.180
I can provide it, right?

321
00:16:27.180 --> 00:16:29.700
And you might have also
noticed something else.

322
00:16:29.700 --> 00:16:33.210
When I logged in,
did you see me type a password?

323
00:16:33.210 --> 00:16:34.320
I didn't, right?

324
00:16:34.320 --> 00:16:35.960
Let me exit out and show you that again.

325
00:16:35.960 --> 00:16:40.400
If I connect to dpezet@172.16.0.100 and

326
00:16:40.400 --> 00:16:44.930
I go to connect, it just let me in,
no password at all, right?

327
00:16:44.930 --> 00:16:49.110
And the reason is I have the certificate
right there on my own machine.

328
00:16:49.110 --> 00:16:52.550
And when I connected to the server,
the server had the certificate as well.

329
00:16:52.550 --> 00:16:55.975
I presented the certificate,
they presented their hash, everything

330
00:16:55.975 --> 00:17:00.490
matched up, and so I'd knew that I was
who I said I was and it allowed me in.

331
00:17:00.490 --> 00:17:03.410
I'm now doing certificate
based authentication.

332
00:17:03.410 --> 00:17:06.900
Now there's a little more that you
can tweak with it if you really want.

333
00:17:06.900 --> 00:17:10.340
For example, right now,
I'm actually allowing password and

334
00:17:10.340 --> 00:17:12.720
certificate based authentication, right?

335
00:17:12.720 --> 00:17:17.680
So if I were to exit out of this and
let's say I delete these keys, right?

336
00:17:17.680 --> 00:17:20.250
Which, in real life,
if you delete the keys,

337
00:17:20.250 --> 00:17:24.140
then you're not going to be
able to get into those systems.

338
00:17:24.140 --> 00:17:26.190
And there's not a good way
to recover them, right?

339
00:17:26.190 --> 00:17:28.010
So you want to have
a backup of these things,

340
00:17:28.010 --> 00:17:29.140
otherwise you can lock yourself out.

341
00:17:29.140 --> 00:17:33.550
But in my case, if I get rid of those
keys, I should be able to SSH back in.

342
00:17:33.550 --> 00:17:35.620
And this time I don't
have a key to present.

343
00:17:35.620 --> 00:17:39.140
And so it just prompts for the password
and I can provide the password and

344
00:17:39.140 --> 00:17:40.220
still get in.

345
00:17:40.220 --> 00:17:43.010
If you've set up a certificate based
authentication you might wanna turn off

346
00:17:43.010 --> 00:17:44.400
password authentication.

347
00:17:44.400 --> 00:17:51.470
And you might have noticed that when
I was in the /etc/ssh/sshd_config

348
00:17:51.470 --> 00:17:56.050
file that buried in this file is
an entry right here where you can

349
00:17:56.050 --> 00:18:00.260
tell it whether you want to allow
password authentication or not.

350
00:18:00.260 --> 00:18:03.575
So right here, PasswordAuthentication,
yes, that's the default.

351
00:18:03.575 --> 00:18:06.370
If I've configured certificate
based authentication,

352
00:18:06.370 --> 00:18:08.450
I might want to come in here and
say no to this.

353
00:18:08.450 --> 00:18:12.240
And if I say no, right,
if I just change that to no,

354
00:18:12.240 --> 00:18:16.160
now the only way I can log in is with
certificate based authentication.

355
00:18:16.160 --> 00:18:19.700
So it's a much stronger level of
authentication, much more hard,

356
00:18:19.700 --> 00:18:22.090
it's impossible, no,
I shouldn't say impossible.

357
00:18:22.090 --> 00:18:23.870
It's very, very difficult to brute force.

358
00:18:23.870 --> 00:18:27.270
You would need quantum computing and
hundreds of years and all that stuff.

359
00:18:27.270 --> 00:18:29.270
So it's really challenging to do that.

360
00:18:29.270 --> 00:18:32.020
And so now we get that high level
security and we require it, so

361
00:18:32.020 --> 00:18:33.882
that's another option you wanna look into.

362
00:18:33.882 --> 00:18:37.300
>> Far out, well, it looks like we've
got SSH configured pretty tight.

363
00:18:37.300 --> 00:18:39.310
Is there anything else we need to look at?

364
00:18:39.310 --> 00:18:42.987
>> You know there is one more thing that
I'll do sometimes, it just kinda depends.

365
00:18:42.987 --> 00:18:48.000
There is a technology or a technique
called security through obscurity, right?

366
00:18:48.000 --> 00:18:51.130
Where sometimes you can secure
something just by hiding it.

367
00:18:51.130 --> 00:18:55.710
If somebody does a port scan across
the network, and they look for servers, or

368
00:18:55.710 --> 00:18:59.270
anything that responds, they can check
to see if port 22 is open right?

369
00:18:59.270 --> 00:19:01.810
Port 22 is the default port used by SSH.

370
00:19:01.810 --> 00:19:02.480
And so

371
00:19:02.480 --> 00:19:06.060
any time they see port 22 open somewhere
they know hey that's an SSH server.

372
00:19:06.060 --> 00:19:08.570
Let me try and connect and
log in as root right?

373
00:19:08.570 --> 00:19:12.290
So if you've got servers where you're
concerned about that, you can try and

374
00:19:12.290 --> 00:19:14.190
obscure SSH.

375
00:19:14.190 --> 00:19:16.590
Now it doesn't actually secure anything,
they can still find it,

376
00:19:16.590 --> 00:19:19.470
they can still connect, but
it makes it a little harder to detect.

377
00:19:19.470 --> 00:19:22.630
And you'll see in this same
configuration file way up at the top,

378
00:19:22.630 --> 00:19:25.040
I think it's at the very beginning,
yeah, right here.

379
00:19:25.040 --> 00:19:28.970
It's got the port number that SSH uses,
the default's 22.

380
00:19:28.970 --> 00:19:31.065
You could change that to something else.

381
00:19:31.065 --> 00:19:35.144
So for example, maybe I wanna
change mine over to port 2222.

382
00:19:35.144 --> 00:19:36.070
I'm not very cryptic here, right?

383
00:19:36.070 --> 00:19:37.230
>> Two two's, a lot of two two's.

384
00:19:37.230 --> 00:19:38.630
>> It's a ballet service.

385
00:19:38.630 --> 00:19:40.866
So I got lots of two's.

386
00:19:40.866 --> 00:19:44.273
And now, if I restart my SSH
service when I connect in,

387
00:19:44.273 --> 00:19:46.755
I have to provide a port number as well.

388
00:19:46.755 --> 00:19:50.186
And if someone does a port scan,
they normally scan one through 1,024,

389
00:19:50.186 --> 00:19:53.830
they look for common services, well,
this is outside of that range.

390
00:19:53.830 --> 00:19:57.770
And if they scan this range and
they hit 2222, do they know what it is?

391
00:19:57.770 --> 00:20:00.580
Maybe if they look at it and go,
that's a lot of twos, this must be SSH.

392
00:20:00.580 --> 00:20:03.968
But I could change it to something else,
like 33333, right?

393
00:20:03.968 --> 00:20:06.670
And now they look at that port and
don't know what it is.

394
00:20:06.670 --> 00:20:08.750
So they would have to actively try and

395
00:20:08.750 --> 00:20:12.730
connect with the SSH protocol to see if
that's what was answering on that port.

396
00:20:12.730 --> 00:20:15.950
They can do it, right,
it's not true security.

397
00:20:15.950 --> 00:20:17.570
But it makes their job a little harder.

398
00:20:17.570 --> 00:20:20.420
And most of the automated scans that are
out there will just move on to the next

399
00:20:20.420 --> 00:20:23.160
easier target than trying to focus on
one that's been configured a little

400
00:20:23.160 --> 00:20:24.120
more secure.

401
00:20:24.120 --> 00:20:27.130
So that's another decision that
you'll need to make as part of your

402
00:20:27.130 --> 00:20:28.250
security policy.

403
00:20:28.250 --> 00:20:29.960
Do we wanna change the default port?

404
00:20:29.960 --> 00:20:33.670
If we do, do we wanna change all of
our servers to use the same port?

405
00:20:33.670 --> 00:20:38.000
Or do we want to randomize it where
every server has a different SSH port?

406
00:20:38.000 --> 00:20:40.730
It becomes difficult to manage,
eventually, especially for

407
00:20:40.730 --> 00:20:42.485
something that's not
giving you true security.

408
00:20:42.485 --> 00:20:45.190
So plenty of people say, you know what?

409
00:20:45.190 --> 00:20:46.742
We're just going to leave it at 22.

410
00:20:46.742 --> 00:20:52.160
And if you use Firewall rules to say only
these IP addresses can connect on port 22,

411
00:20:52.160 --> 00:20:57.150
and then you use the server config to
say only these users are allowed to

412
00:20:57.150 --> 00:21:01.240
log in and you use certificate based
authentication, by the time you're done,

413
00:21:01.240 --> 00:21:04.930
that's really secure and
you didn't have to change the port,

414
00:21:04.930 --> 00:21:06.890
which makes life a little
easier on your administrator.

415
00:21:06.890 --> 00:21:10.830
So it's a decision you'll have to make but
the ability to change it is right there.

416
00:21:10.830 --> 00:21:12.110
It's not a big deal.

417
00:21:12.110 --> 00:21:15.680
One thing I will remind you though is
if you change the port number here,

418
00:21:15.680 --> 00:21:18.660
you will need to update your
firewall to allow that other port.

419
00:21:18.660 --> 00:21:24.251
Port 22 is cleared through the firewall,
port 2222 or 33333 is not, right?

420
00:21:24.251 --> 00:21:27.090
So whatever port you pick
you need to do that, and

421
00:21:27.090 --> 00:21:31.804
if you're running SELinux, you may need
to modify SELinux to allow that port for

422
00:21:31.804 --> 00:21:36.500
SSH as well because SSH is cleared for
port 22, not necessarily other ports.

423
00:21:36.500 --> 00:21:39.870
So there's actually a good bit involved
with changing that port number and

424
00:21:39.870 --> 00:21:41.620
doing it securely.

425
00:21:41.620 --> 00:21:45.250
But those are just some of the things
that we need to be aware of

426
00:21:45.250 --> 00:21:48.212
to make sure that we get
things configured securely and

427
00:21:48.212 --> 00:21:51.170
configured the way we want to
match our security policy.

428
00:21:51.170 --> 00:21:55.460
>> Awesome, well, configuring SSH,
becoming a Linux server administrator.

429
00:21:55.460 --> 00:21:57.450
Great information as usual, Don.

430
00:21:57.450 --> 00:21:58.930
Any last words?

431
00:21:58.930 --> 00:21:59.840
>> Not too much here.

432
00:21:59.840 --> 00:22:01.710
Remember that SSH is really important,

433
00:22:01.710 --> 00:22:04.380
because that's how you remotely
administer the server.

434
00:22:04.380 --> 00:22:06.950
So if you lock yourself out,
if you cause problems there,

435
00:22:06.950 --> 00:22:12.510
that can really severely hinder your
ability to work with the server.

436
00:22:12.510 --> 00:22:15.240
So we wanna make sure that
the service is kept healthy.

437
00:22:15.240 --> 00:22:17.340
Because the moment any
other service goes wrong,

438
00:22:17.340 --> 00:22:19.920
you're gonna rely on SSH
to get in there and fix it.

439
00:22:19.920 --> 00:22:22.620
Also remember there are other
configuration options in there.

440
00:22:22.620 --> 00:22:28.040
Like you can support SSH version 1, or
version 2, or both version 1 and 2.

441
00:22:28.040 --> 00:22:29.540
If you're doing both,

442
00:22:29.540 --> 00:22:33.960
then the security you create is equal to
the weakest level of security you support.

443
00:22:33.960 --> 00:22:35.610
So that means it's pretty weak.

444
00:22:35.610 --> 00:22:38.330
You wanna make sure you're
just doing SSH version 2 and

445
00:22:38.330 --> 00:22:42.380
that your clients are secure and you're
keeping your keys protected as well.

446
00:22:42.380 --> 00:22:45.000
We did have a question in the chat room
about whether you can do multiple ports

447
00:22:45.000 --> 00:22:45.520
for SSH.

448
00:22:46.650 --> 00:22:51.740
The easy answer would be no, but
the reality is you technically can.

449
00:22:51.740 --> 00:22:55.060
You have to have multiple IPs to do it.

450
00:22:55.060 --> 00:22:58.350
As far as I know,
you can only have one port per IP.

451
00:22:58.350 --> 00:23:00.159
So like my server only has one IP address,
and so

452
00:23:00.159 --> 00:23:02.130
it's got a single port that it's using.

453
00:23:02.130 --> 00:23:03.800
But if you have multiple IP addresses,

454
00:23:03.800 --> 00:23:06.440
there are ways to configure that
where you'll have additional ones.

455
00:23:06.440 --> 00:23:11.560
I've also seen where people will
take SSH and compartmentalize it,

456
00:23:11.560 --> 00:23:14.490
right, so they can assign different
port numbers that way too.

457
00:23:14.490 --> 00:23:17.250
You can use Nginx to proxy it or
other things.

458
00:23:17.250 --> 00:23:19.500
So there's a few different
ways you can achieve that.

459
00:23:19.500 --> 00:23:21.540
There's not normally
a whole lot of reason for

460
00:23:21.540 --> 00:23:24.620
that to have SSH running
on more than one port.

461
00:23:24.620 --> 00:23:26.210
If you're supporting
more than one customer,

462
00:23:26.210 --> 00:23:27.920
you usually manage that
all through user accounts,

463
00:23:27.920 --> 00:23:29.560
not necessarily the port numbers.

464
00:23:29.560 --> 00:23:31.510
But there are ways to make it happen.

465
00:23:31.510 --> 00:23:34.970
But the official answer would be no
there's not really a way to do that, but

466
00:23:34.970 --> 00:23:36.100
there are ways to do it.

467
00:23:36.100 --> 00:23:40.810
>> Awesome, well configure SSH and
becoming a Linux server administrator.

468

Great episode, and

00:23:41.789 --> 00:23:45.251
there's lots more content in becoming
a Linux server administrator.

470
00:23:45.251 --> 00:23:48.000
A lot of videos, make sure you watch
them all, you'll be very glad you did.

471
00:23:48.000 --> 00:23:50.609
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

472
00:23:50.609 --> 00:23:53.810
Remember, a good IT pro
is always learning.

I'm Zach Memos.

474
00:23:54.760 --> 00:23:55.590
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

475
00:23:55.590 --> 00:23:58.134
>> And we'll see you very soon.

Logging is kind of a critical
system on our servers.

14
00:00:43.580 --> 00:00:46.440
It's critical on workstations too but
on servers even more so.

15
00:00:46.440 --> 00:00:50.988
Because nobody is sitting

16
00:00:50.988 --> 00:00:52.530
I'm sitting in front of

I'm not going to see the errors

20

So we rely upon logs every single day

21
00:01:06.120 --> 00:01:09.060
If a failure occurred what caused it,
how do we troubleshoot?

22
00:01:09.060 --> 00:01:11.980
How do we just monitor
the health of a server?

23
00:01:11.980 --> 00:01:14.390
All of that is tied to logging.

24
00:01:14.390 --> 00:01:17.399
And when you start spinning servers
up in an enterprise environment,

25
00:01:17.399 --> 00:01:19.746
there is some logging that's
configured by default.

26
00:01:19.746 --> 00:01:23.611
But there's a lot of logging that we need
to get in and configure ourselves, and

27
00:01:23.611 --> 00:01:27.250
get set up, and get kind of working

28

In order to make sure we've got

29
00:01:29.660 --> 00:01:34.010
because there's nothing worse then
all of a sudden having a failure and

30
00:01:34.010 --> 00:01:36.220

00:01:36.220 --> 00:01:39.500
And so you're like, I really could use

32
00:01:39.500 --> 00:01:41.713
But it's not gonna help you,
because now it's after the failure.

33
00:01:41.713 --> 00:01:45.060
So logging is one of those things that
we need to get set up before we need it,

34
00:01:45.060 --> 00:01:46.030
not after we need it.

35
00:01:46.030 --> 00:01:48.877
And that's what we're gonna see
right here in this episode.

>> Well Don, don't we already
have logging on the server?

00:01:51.490 --> 00:01:53.880
Isn't it automatic?

00:01:53.880 --> 00:01:55.168
>> Well, to an extent, yes.

39

00:12:37.610 --> 00:12:41.450

00:12:41.450 --> 00:12:45.890

00:12:45.890 --> 00:12:48.610

00:12:48.610 --> 00:12:52.680

00:12:52.680 --> 00:12:54.890
if the network wasn't stable at the time.

00:12:54.890 --> 00:12:57.120

00:12:57.120 --> 00:13:00.300

00:13:00.300 --> 00:13:04.560
If a frame or a packet doesn't

00:13:04.560 --> 00:13:07.980

00:13:07.980 --> 00:13:09.470
So you need to make that decision, and

00:24:51.952 --> 00:24:56.830
of /bar/log, I do not have a journal
folder, I haven't made it, okay?

00:24:56.830 --> 00:25:02.611
But, if I do a systemctl, restart,

00:25:02.611 --> 00:25:07.279
systemd-jounald, right?

00:25:07.279 --> 00:25:09.229
I can restart that service.

485
00:25:09.229 --> 00:25:12.462
And I'm sudo-ing this, I'm actually in
a root session right now anyways, so

00:25:12.462 --> 00:25:13.415
it wouldn't matter.

487
00:25:13.415 --> 00:25:15.239
But there we go, so I'm gonna restart it.

488
00:25:15.239 --> 00:25:17.187
When I restart it,
it's gonna see the configuration file and

489
00:25:17.187 --> 00:25:18.961
it's gonna say,
I'm supposed to be persistent.

490
00:25:18.961 --> 00:25:20.921
And it's gonna see the folder as missing,
and

491
00:25:20.921 --> 00:25:22.638
it's gonna put the folder there for me.

492
00:25:22.638 --> 00:25:25.770
And it'll have the right permissions and
it'll be configured the right way.

493
00:25:25.770 --> 00:25:27.218
So this is the easiest
way to avoid mistakes.

494
00:25:27.218 --> 00:25:28.761
This is the way I recommend you do it.

495
00:25:28.761 --> 00:25:33.120
And by doing that,
now I've got a folder called journal.

496
00:25:33.120 --> 00:25:34.816
And that's where the data's being written.

497
00:25:34.816 --> 00:25:37.555
And if I reboot,
I don't lose all my journald anymore,

498
00:25:37.555 --> 00:25:38.968
now it's being preserved.

499
00:25:38.968 --> 00:25:41.588
If I go into that folder,
which is why I'm logged in as root.

500
00:25:41.588 --> 00:25:43.619
Normally I wouldn't even be
able to go into this folder.

501
00:25:43.619 --> 00:25:46.907
But if I go in there I
can see a binary file.

502
00:25:46.907 --> 00:25:51.217
And if I try and look at that file, right?

503
00:25:51.217 --> 00:25:54.392
It's gonna tell me oops,
sorry, that it is a directory,

504
00:25:54.392 --> 00:25:56.529
that's what it's gonna tell me first.

505
00:25:56.529 --> 00:25:58.756
And then when I get in there,
there's the file.

506
00:25:58.756 --> 00:26:03.026
And if I try and
pull that it's a binary file.

507
00:26:03.026 --> 00:26:05.031
So I just see junk, right?

508
00:26:05.031 --> 00:26:09.540
I can't actually read that file but
there is, system.journal.

509
00:26:09.540 --> 00:26:12.595
That's it, log in to the disk,
and put in that data in there and

510
00:26:12.595 --> 00:26:14.048
storing in a secured format.

511
00:26:14.048 --> 00:26:16.751
It's actually a binary
that's encrypted as well.

512
00:26:16.751 --> 00:26:19.830
So I can't mess with it, right?

513
00:26:19.830 --> 00:26:23.564
So we're safe, the data is stored there,
I can go in and

514
00:26:23.564 --> 00:26:27.065
pull data out of journal ctl
till the cows come home.

515
00:26:27.065 --> 00:26:27.876
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

516
00:26:27.876 --> 00:26:29.157
I can troubleshoot find my information.

517
00:26:29.157 --> 00:26:32.850
So if you wanna start using journal
ctl today, it's a good idea.

518
00:26:32.850 --> 00:26:35.986
You know journald and
journal ctl just make it persistent and

519
00:26:35.986 --> 00:26:38.087
that could be your go to logging source.

520
00:26:38.087 --> 00:26:44.500
And then in time sys log will go away,
but not every system has journald.

521
00:26:44.500 --> 00:26:47.879
There are still some systems that
are clinging on to the old sys v inits or

522
00:26:47.879 --> 00:26:50.482
upstart inits and
those are gonna be issuing sys logs.

523
00:26:50.482 --> 00:26:53.917
So if you learn sys log,
you'll have that everywhere, right?

524
00:26:53.917 --> 00:26:58.878
If you learn journald, you'll have it most
places and you're prepared for tomorrow.

525
00:26:58.878 --> 00:27:00.845
The best solution is
really to learn both and

526
00:27:00.845 --> 00:27:03.779
make sure you've got them configured and
set up the way you want.

527
00:27:03.779 --> 00:27:05.337
That persistence is really important.

528
00:27:05.337 --> 00:27:08.444
If you forget to configure it and
then you have a problem,

529
00:27:08.444 --> 00:27:10.988
you can't look back
beyond your last reboot.

530
00:27:10.988 --> 00:27:13.063
And it's too late at that point,
those logs are gone.

531
00:27:13.063 --> 00:27:16.282
We need to make sure we turn
this on ahead of time so

532
00:27:16.282 --> 00:27:19.828
we've got those log messages there and
ready for us.

533
00:27:19.828 --> 00:27:21.242
All right, let me just, before we wrap up,

534
00:27:21.242 --> 00:27:22.941
I'm getting the signal
we're running out of time.

535
00:27:22.941 --> 00:27:24.978
>> [LAUGH]
>> But just a couple of journal ctl

536
00:27:24.978 --> 00:27:26.850
commands that are handy for us.

537
00:27:26.850 --> 00:27:28.195
I showed you journalctl,

538
00:27:28.195 --> 00:27:31.324
let me get out of this folder
cuz it's like really long path.

539
00:27:31.324 --> 00:27:33.742
I showed you journalctl -f, which says,

540
00:27:33.742 --> 00:27:36.508
show me the last ten lines and
follow it, right?

541
00:27:36.508 --> 00:27:38.137
So that's one way we can do it.

542
00:27:38.137 --> 00:27:41.467
But you can also do journalctl -n and

543
00:27:41.467 --> 00:27:45.990
you can tell it to show me
a certain number of line.

544
00:27:45.990 --> 00:27:48.832
So I can say like show
me the first ten lines.

545
00:27:48.832 --> 00:27:52.532
And so here I'm getting lines 1
through 11 or whatever, or actually,

546
00:27:52.532 --> 00:27:55.823
this is our last ten lines,
I'm sorry, I need to get that right.

547
00:27:55.823 --> 00:27:58.395
So you can kinda modify what
it is that you're outputting.

548
00:27:58.395 --> 00:28:00.836
If you just run it by yourself,
you see the whole thing.

549
00:28:00.836 --> 00:28:04.031
And that beyond CVS what I normally
do cuz I'll pipe that in the grep and

550
00:28:04.031 --> 00:28:05.668
then I look for something, right?

551
00:28:05.668 --> 00:28:08.753
Maybe I'm troubleshooting HTPD and
so I'll grep for that.

552
00:28:08.753 --> 00:28:11.183
And then I get those entries back and
I can look at them and

553
00:28:11.183 --> 00:28:13.379
I can see that information and
get it out of there.

554
00:28:13.379 --> 00:28:16.956
So you can certainly pipe and then use
the utilities that you're used to.

555
00:28:16.956 --> 00:28:20.109
At that point, it's really no different
than how you work with syslog.

556
00:28:20.109 --> 00:28:22.352
Here, it's just a different
command that we're using.

557
00:28:22.352 --> 00:28:25.465
Some of the other things you can
do is you can filter by priority.

558
00:28:25.465 --> 00:28:27.360
Like maybe I just wanna see errors.

559
00:28:27.360 --> 00:28:30.104
Well, I used to have
this problem in syslog,

560
00:28:30.104 --> 00:28:34.295
where I would say like cat
/var/log/messages and I would pipe that

561
00:28:34.295 --> 00:28:38.525
into grep and I would do a case
insensitive search for the word error.

562
00:28:38.525 --> 00:28:41.756
Cuz maybe the e is capitalized,
maybe the whole word is capitalized,

563
00:28:41.756 --> 00:28:44.848
I don't know, and I could go in and
I could look for those, right?

564
00:28:44.848 --> 00:28:49.027
Or sometimes maybe just said err,
there's some more.

565
00:28:49.027 --> 00:28:51.211
I would have missed that just looking for
the word error, right?

566
00:28:51.211 --> 00:28:54.131
Well actually, these are interrupts,
so that doesn't even really count.

567
00:28:54.131 --> 00:28:56.700
So that's a challenge
that we had with syslog.

568
00:28:56.700 --> 00:29:02.596
But with journald,
we can actually say, journalctl -p.

569
00:29:02.596 --> 00:29:05.196
And I can look for
the priorities, and I can say,

570
00:29:05.196 --> 00:29:08.071
show me everything that has
an err priority, right?

571
00:29:08.071 --> 00:29:11.161
That's an error, I'm not getting all
those interrupts, they're there,

572
00:29:11.161 --> 00:29:12.119
I'm not getting them.

573
00:29:12.119 --> 00:29:15.645
I'm just seeing the ones that have
actually been flagged as some

574
00:29:15.645 --> 00:29:16.769
kind of error here.

575
00:29:16.769 --> 00:29:19.391
And I can look at what that is and
try and figure out what they are.

576
00:29:19.391 --> 00:29:23.237
Looks like I've got some kind of storage
issue on which is odd on a virtual machine

577
00:29:23.237 --> 00:29:24.210
but anyhow I see it.

578
00:29:24.210 --> 00:29:30.820
So that's a technique and you can also
filter by date and time if you want to,

579
00:29:30.820 --> 00:29:36.300

580
00:29:36.300 --> 00:29:39.447
So maybe I wanna see all

00:29:39.447 --> 00:29:44.394

So show me everything since that date, and

00:29:54.046 --> 00:30:01.272
And in here I can say,
until = '2017-02-01'

586
00:30:01.272 --> 00:30:05.770
00:00:00, all right?

587
00:30:05.770 --> 00:30:09.248
And by doing that I'm saying show me
everything that occurred between January

00:30:09.248 --> 00:30:10.415
1st and January 31st.

589
00:30:10.415 --> 00:30:13.138
Or if you're like me and you can't

590
00:30:13.138 --> 00:30:15.418
Then it's really all the way
up until February 1st.

591
00:30:15.418 --> 00:30:19.922
So by doing that now I'll just get those
log messages which it looks like I don't

00:30:19.922 --> 00:30:23.974
have any, which makes sense cuz I just
spun up this server two days ago.

593
00:30:23.974 --> 00:30:25.570
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So anyhow we can filter that

594
00:30:25.570 --> 00:30:27.430
way through journalctl very powerful.

595
00:30:27.430 --> 00:30:29.261
It is the way of the future,
it's the way we wanna learn it.

596
00:30:29.261 --> 00:30:32.579
And that's what you're gonna be
using now and in the future, but

597
00:30:32.579 --> 00:30:33.798
syslog is everywhere.

598
00:30:33.798 --> 00:30:37.509
Going back to Zach's original question

599
00:30:37.509 --> 00:30:40.196
If you want the same everywhere,

600
00:30:40.196 --> 00:30:43.131
And I do recommend that you learn both,

601
00:30:43.131 --> 00:30:45.482
>> Fantastic information, as always, Don.

602
00:30:45.482 --> 00:30:48.759
And like he's saying,
be prepared for the future, so

603
00:30:48.759 --> 00:30:51.618
configuring system logging,
any last words?

604
00:30:51.618 --> 00:30:53.747
>> The main thing,
config your log rotation, right?

00:30:53.747 --> 00:30:56.748
Don't assume the defaults are going to
be friendly for your security policy,

606
00:30:56.748 --> 00:30:57.842
definitely check that out.

607
00:30:57.842 --> 00:31:00.830
I encourage you to set up

608
00:31:00.830 --> 00:31:03.610
If you don't have one already, it's

609
00:31:03.610 --> 00:31:05.929
And you can even provide more

610
00:31:05.929 --> 00:31:09.053
You might have a remote logging server

611
00:31:09.053 --> 00:31:10.788
and another that's at disaster recovery.

612
00:31:10.788 --> 00:31:13.919
So now you've got two different
copies of those logs being sent out.

613
00:31:13.919 --> 00:31:15.720
You can do that, right?

614
00:31:15.720 --> 00:31:18.500
And then after that,
these are just text files, right?

615
00:31:18.500 --> 00:31:21.590
In sys log they could be compressed,
they become very, very small.

616
00:31:21.590 --> 00:31:23.991
So I know a lot of people use
scripts to automate that process,

617
00:31:23.991 --> 00:31:25.310
compressing logs down.

618
00:31:25.310 --> 00:31:27.100
With journal ctl,
they're encrypted binary, so

619
00:31:27.100 --> 00:31:30.109
they don't really compress all that well,
so we don't have to worry about it there.

620
00:31:30.109 --> 00:31:32.970
But definitely pay attention to
your maintenance schedule on those,

621
00:31:32.970 --> 00:31:35.974
double check it and probably the most
important thing that I can tell you,

00:31:35.974 --> 00:31:37.398
monitor your logs, look at them.

623
00:31:37.398 --> 00:31:39.044
A lot of people do log in,

00:31:39.044 --> 00:31:41.021
there's not a whole lot of point

00:31:41.021 --> 00:31:44.121
So, make sure you look at your logs, they

00:31:44.121 --> 00:31:45.899

15
00:00:38.320 --> 00:00:40.513

16
00:00:40.513 --> 00:00:43.440

00:00:43.440 --> 00:00:46.390

resources available for us to properly be

24
00:01:05.000 --> 00:01:07.180
So In this episode we're

25
00:01:07.180 --> 00:01:10.640
How to monitor and gather that data and

26
00:01:10.640 --> 00:01:14.130
>> So Don could give us an idea
of when we would need to view or

27
00:01:14.130 --> 00:01:15.380
monitor that performance?

28
00:01:15.380 --> 00:01:16.906
When or why?

29
00:01:16.906 --> 00:01:20.610
>> So there's two main times I find
myself monitoring performance.

30
00:01:20.610 --> 00:01:23.880
Whenever I deploy a brand new server,
so you get a new server.

31
00:01:23.880 --> 00:01:25.790
You're rolling it out the first time.

32
00:01:25.790 --> 00:01:27.540
You'll want to gather performance data.

33
00:01:27.540 --> 00:01:30.100
What you're doing is
called setting a baseline.

34
00:01:30.100 --> 00:01:33.660
You need to understand how that
server is running normally.

35
00:01:33.660 --> 00:01:35.770
When everything is working the way
that it is supposed to work,

36
00:01:35.770 --> 00:01:36.870
how does that server look?

37
00:01:36.870 --> 00:01:39.129
What percentage of CPU
utilization is it at?

38
00:01:39.129 --> 00:01:41.190
Let's say it's at 50% CPU.

39
00:01:41.190 --> 00:01:43.380
Okay, fine, great, It's at half.

40
00:01:43.380 --> 00:01:44.950
That's a perfectly good number.

41
00:01:44.950 --> 00:01:47.270
And that's where it's at normally.

42
00:01:47.270 --> 00:01:50.160
And then one day somebody calls on
the phone and is like Don quick.

43
00:01:50.160 --> 00:01:53.340
The servers are running super
slow customers are getting angry.

44
00:01:53.340 --> 00:01:55.540
All right I've got to log in and find out.

45
00:01:55.540 --> 00:01:57.320
Is the server running super slow?

46
00:01:57.320 --> 00:02:00.898
Well if I look and the CPU is at 50%.

47
00:02:00.898 --> 00:02:03.756
I might look at that and
say 50% is that high, is that low?

48
00:02:03.756 --> 00:02:05.219
I don't really know.

49
00:02:05.219 --> 00:02:06.467
I've got this baseline.

50
00:02:06.467 --> 00:02:08.988
When everything was working normally,
we were at 50%.

51
00:02:08.988 --> 00:02:11.810
Now we're at 50%, everything is fine.

52
00:02:11.810 --> 00:02:12.719
>> Makes sense.

53
00:02:12.719 --> 00:02:13.640
>> That happens.

54
00:02:13.640 --> 00:02:17.110
Sometimes people don't know
you need context to your data.

55
00:02:17.110 --> 00:02:19.146
That's really what monitoring
performance is all about,

56
00:02:19.146 --> 00:02:20.470
is being able to look and see.

57
00:02:20.470 --> 00:02:22.950
If somebody calls and
says a server is running slow and

58
00:02:22.950 --> 00:02:26.400
I pull up the report that says,
CPU is at 100%.

59
00:02:26.400 --> 00:02:28.080
It's completely maxed out.

60
00:02:28.080 --> 00:02:29.410
I know there's a problem.

61
00:02:29.410 --> 00:02:32.030
I can go in and
try to find why that problem is there.

62
00:02:32.030 --> 00:02:33.645
So that's the best example.

63
00:02:33.645 --> 00:02:35.558
The two times [INAUDIBLE] data is one,

64
00:02:35.558 --> 00:02:39.013
when we do a baseline to figure out
how things run normally and two,

65
00:02:39.013 --> 00:02:43.060
when we're troubleshooting to figure
out how things are running right now.

66
00:02:43.060 --> 00:02:45.504
And so I like to call that
real-time performance monitoring.

67
00:02:45.504 --> 00:02:47.690
Looking at how things are going right now.

68
00:02:47.690 --> 00:02:51.450
And as far as the Unix
like operating systems.

69
00:02:51.450 --> 00:02:55.002
There's a ton of utilities are just built

00:02:55.002 --> 00:02:58.305

00:03:11.519 --> 00:03:15.237

00:03:18.910 --> 00:03:22.570

00:03:46.910 --> 00:03:50.744

00:03:50.744 --> 00:03:53.950

00:03:53.950 --> 00:03:59.185
So for example if I were to fire up

00:03:59.185 --> 00:04:01.940
so I'm running that calculator as me.

00:04:01.940 --> 00:04:05.590

00:04:05.590 --> 00:04:09.720

00:04:09.720 --> 00:04:14.080
shell, the only thing I've run is bash to

00:04:14.080 --> 00:04:19.720

00:04:19.720 --> 00:04:21.670
Everybody's including mine and
other people's.

00:04:21.670 --> 00:04:23.860
I see dpezet as well as root and

00:04:23.860 --> 00:04:26.470
in summary here if I poked
around I'd find that calculator.

00:04:26.470 --> 00:04:28.605
Actually, it's right here,

00:04:28.605 --> 00:04:30.860
Gnome calculator right there right?

00:04:30.860 --> 00:04:32.318

00:04:32.318 --> 00:04:37.461
So PSAUX, now when I run that I'm

00:04:37.461 --> 00:04:40.877
And if you scroll up to the top you

101
00:04:40.877 --> 00:04:44.830
each one pertains to a little bit

00:04:44.830 --> 00:04:48.700
And CPU and memory are the two

00:04:48.700 --> 00:04:51.570
How much CPU is that

00:04:54.690 --> 00:04:58.580
So if my CPU is at 100%,

00:04:58.580 --> 00:05:03.440

00:05:07.630 --> 00:05:11.630

00:05:27.810 --> 00:05:30.140
The list is gonna change

So if I launch a larger program, let me

00:05:39.870 --> 00:05:42.490

00:05:42.490 --> 00:05:44.670
This is a real time view.

00:05:44.670 --> 00:05:47.419

00:05:47.419 --> 00:05:51.330

00:05:51.330 --> 00:05:52.931
So I now I can sit here and

00:05:52.931 --> 00:05:55.935
I can see the CPU and the memory right

00:05:55.935 --> 00:05:59.520
this is installed by default, on pretty

126
00:05:59.520 --> 00:06:02.410
It's considered a core utility.

00:06:02.410 --> 00:06:06.928
Now the default view is that

00:06:06.928 --> 00:06:09.990

00:06:09.990 --> 00:06:13.200
And so you can change the view

00:06:13.200 --> 00:06:17.700
So for example, I could hit the letter

131
00:06:17.700 --> 00:06:21.110
So, maybe I just want to

00:06:21.110 --> 00:06:23.630
And so I can filter down just to dpezet.

00:06:23.630 --> 00:06:25.720

00:06:25.720 --> 00:06:28.280

135
00:06:28.280 --> 00:06:30.430
So you lets you filter by user.

00:06:30.430 --> 00:06:35.049
You've got M to change the sort

137
00:06:35.049 --> 00:06:36.100
And it's a capital M.

138
00:06:36.100 --> 00:06:40.200
If I do a capital M now it's
sorting by memory utilization.

139
00:06:40.200 --> 00:06:45.140
The highest memory utilizer is first and
then it goes down from there okay.

140
00:06:45.140 --> 00:06:49.954
If I do a capital P, it'll go back
to being sorted by CPU right.

141
00:06:49.954 --> 00:06:54.178
But I'll M for memory,
capital C for CPU and then U,

142
00:06:54.178 --> 00:06:56.930
to pick a user and filter by it.

00:06:56.930 --> 00:07:00.850
Those three little short cuts are really
handy, they come in here and try and

00:07:00.850 --> 00:07:03.360

00:07:03.360 --> 00:07:06.900
If you see something that's running too

00:07:26.726 --> 00:07:31.270
here I've got my pretty good view here of

00:07:31.270 --> 00:07:32.920
I can look, I can see what's going on and

00:07:32.920 --> 00:07:35.970
get an idea of who's eating that CPU and
who's eating that memory.

159
00:07:35.970 --> 00:07:38.275
And see it all in one concise place.

00:07:38.275 --> 00:07:41.504

>> Sure.
Yeah,

disk is often times one of the other

00:07:44.973 --> 00:07:47.050
I don't see any of that information here,

00:07:50.380 --> 00:07:53.670
With disk,

00:07:53.670 --> 00:07:56.081
Usually we're worried about

00:07:56.081 --> 00:07:58.055
I think in the last episode,

00:07:58.055 --> 00:08:00.245

00:08:00.245 --> 00:08:01.176

00:08:01.176 --> 00:08:05.774
So we need a way to monitor What disks

00:08:05.774 --> 00:08:07.890

00:08:07.890 --> 00:08:10.305
The most common one that I use,

00:08:10.305 --> 00:08:13.588
df shows you the disks that you've got and

175
00:08:13.588 --> 00:08:15.980

00:08:15.980 --> 00:08:19.425
But in addition to that,
it shows how much space they have, and

00:08:19.425 --> 00:08:24.173
how much space you've used, as well as how

178
00:08:24.173 --> 00:08:25.593
So you can quickly glance down this.

179
00:08:25.593 --> 00:08:29.353
And if I see something like this,
83%, t hat's my storage drive,

00:08:29.353 --> 00:08:31.282
it's starting to run out of space.

00:08:31.282 --> 00:08:32.071

00:08:32.071 --> 00:08:34.601

It changes it, so

00:09:01.650 --> 00:09:05.540
I'm using 717 gigs, and

So while it is 83% full,

00:09:08.440 --> 00:09:11.810
I've got 150 gigs of space right there,

00:09:11.810 --> 00:09:12.680
>> It's a little bit.

197
00:09:12.680 --> 00:09:14.025
>> And so it's easier to see that.

198
00:09:14.025 --> 00:09:17.330
That was df -h, to be able to see that.

199
00:09:17.330 --> 00:09:20.543
Now, let's say that I was
worried about that drive.

00:09:20.543 --> 00:09:24.558
And I said, man, I really need to

00:09:24.558 --> 00:09:26.985
who is it that's eating all that space?

Well, if I take a look at /mnt/storage,
and I look.

203
00:09:31.800 --> 00:09:32.680
I've got a few things in there.
