00:09:32.680 --> 00:09:33.990
I've got my show notes.

205
00:09:33.990 --> 00:09:37.280
I've got a folder called ISOs
that has CD images in it.

206
00:09:37.280 --> 00:09:39.510
I've got my virtual machines
are tucked in here,

207
00:09:39.510 --> 00:09:42.600
my Google Drive,
which one is the guilty culprit?

00:09:42.600 --> 00:09:45.730
Who is it that's eating the most

Well, df doesn't tell me that,

So I can come in and I can do

00:10:02.537 --> 00:10:06.316
The h making it human-readable,
and -s cuz I'm pointing at a path.

00:10:06.316 --> 00:10:09.952
And I can point it at
something like /mnt/Storage.

216
00:10:09.952 --> 00:10:12.478
And it's gonna take a look at that disk,
and

00:10:12.478 --> 00:10:16.250
it's gonna tell me how much space is used,

00:10:17.830 --> 00:10:21.690
And then beyond that,
I can look at what's inside of it, right?

219
00:10:21.690 --> 00:10:23.500
What's inside of that folder.

00:10:23.500 --> 00:10:25.782
And now,
it'll show me each folder inside, and

00:10:25.782 --> 00:10:28.129

00:10:28.129 --> 00:10:33.677
So out of 717 gigs, only 173 of
that is in my virtual machines.

223
00:10:33.677 --> 00:10:36.333
I've got another 156 in my ISOs.

00:10:36.333 --> 00:10:39.140
I've got 3.8 gigs in my Show Notes.

00:10:39.140 --> 00:10:41.389
And my Google Drive is 1.6 gigs.

226
00:10:41.389 --> 00:10:44.714
It looks like I don't really

00:10:44.714 --> 00:10:48.650
I've got several folders that are all

00:10:48.650 --> 00:10:50.650
Now, I'm not a mathematician, but

00:11:06.610 --> 00:11:10.090
You need to make sure that

00:11:10.090 --> 00:11:12.300
that it can actually get
a better view of what's going on.

236
00:11:12.300 --> 00:11:14.610
And you might find additional
information turns up.

00:11:14.610 --> 00:11:17.130
In my case, I actually didn't

your permissions can skew the results of

00:11:32.620 --> 00:11:37.590
So we do have to be careful, to make sure

245
00:11:37.590 --> 00:11:41.985
of data, and understanding where

00:11:41.985 --> 00:11:43.938
So that's the du command.

00:11:43.938 --> 00:11:48.065

00:11:56.505 --> 00:11:58.555
how much is actually available, right?

00:11:58.555 --> 00:12:02.739
I'm gonna do a free -h,

00:12:02.739 --> 00:12:04.490
I like that, it's a little bit easier.

00:12:04.490 --> 00:12:07.940
And let me just show you this command,

255
00:12:07.940 --> 00:12:09.590
When I look at my system,

256
00:12:09.590 --> 00:12:12.720
sometimes it may look like you're

257
00:12:12.720 --> 00:12:16.040
My system has 31 gigs of memory, it says.

258
00:12:16.040 --> 00:12:20.300
And then I'm using 1.3 gigs,
and then free is 23 gigs.

259
00:12:21.490 --> 00:12:23.088
Well, that doesn't quite add up, does it?

260
00:12:23.088 --> 00:12:23.791
>> Uh-uh.

261
00:12:23.791 --> 00:12:29.974
>> 23 gigs plus another 1.3 that's 24.3
gigs, not 31, so what happened, right?

262
00:12:29.974 --> 00:12:34.550
Well, what happens is most operating
systems do caching, right?

263
00:12:34.550 --> 00:12:38.430
They cache information in memory and
hold it, in case I need it again.

264
00:12:38.430 --> 00:12:41.010
And if I need it, it's already there
waiting for me, I can grab it and

265
00:12:41.010 --> 00:12:42.310
I can use it, right?

266
00:12:42.310 --> 00:12:44.500
If I don't need it,
if I need to use it for something else,

267
00:12:44.500 --> 00:12:46.780
it'll overwrite that with the new data,
right?

268
00:12:46.780 --> 00:12:49.020
So that's that missing memory
that's showing up right there.

269
00:12:49.020 --> 00:12:51.080
So sometimes it can look
like you're missing memory,

270
00:12:51.080 --> 00:12:54.350
but it's actually available, it's just
cached and being held there, right?

271
00:12:54.350 --> 00:12:57.581
So while it's telling me
that I've got 23 gigs free,

272
00:12:57.581 --> 00:13:00.002
I've actually got 29 gigs available.

273
00:13:00.002 --> 00:13:05.256
And 29 Plus 1.3, that gets us closer to
that 31 gigs where I'm supposed to be.

274
00:13:05.256 --> 00:13:06.490
>> There it is.

00:13:06.490 --> 00:13:08.660
>> Now, on the performance side,

00:13:08.660 --> 00:13:12.470
the one that I really watch

00:13:12.470 --> 00:13:16.040

00:13:16.040 --> 00:13:17.520
But what happens if I run out?

00:13:17.520 --> 00:13:21.360
If I run out of memory,

00:13:21.360 --> 00:13:25.260

00:13:25.260 --> 00:13:29.410
But your hard drive is slower than your

00:13:29.410 --> 00:13:30.520
If you're swapping the hard drive,

00:13:30.520 --> 00:13:33.300
that means you need to add more

00:13:33.300 --> 00:13:40.060
Well, I can see right here, my swap is
15 gigs and I've used zero bytes of it.

285
00:13:40.060 --> 00:13:45.250
That's perfect, as long as I keep seeing
that zero there, I'm happy, right?

00:13:45.250 --> 00:13:48.310
If I'm just one time,
doing something that uses a lot of memory,

287
00:13:48.310 --> 00:13:49.690
I might see this start to get used.

288
00:13:49.690 --> 00:13:53.050
But if I'm regularly seeing
that swap space being used,

289
00:13:53.050 --> 00:13:55.110
it means I need to add
more memory to the system.

290
00:13:55.110 --> 00:13:56.560
So easy way to tell,

511
00:25:27.200 --> 00:25:31.970
Just explore them, learn them, get used to
them, and in the end, make use of them.

512
00:25:31.970 --> 00:25:34.920
>> Thanks again, Don,
becoming a Linux server administrator.

513
00:25:34.920 --> 00:25:38.160
There's a lot of content this series,
make sure you watch every video,

514
00:25:38.160 --> 00:25:39.260
you'll be glad you did.

515
00:25:40.260 --> 00:25:42.230
And thank you for watching ITPro TV.

516
00:25:42.230 --> 00:25:45.850
Remember, a good IT pro is
always learning, I'm Zack Memos.

517
00:25:45.850 --> 00:25:46.670
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

518
00:25:46.670 --> 00:25:49.033
>> And we'll see you very soon.

519
00:25:49.033 --> 00:25:54.973
[MUSIC]

520
00:25:54.973 --> 00:25:57.779
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss options in regards to configuring networking, restarting network service, SYSTEMCTL, configuring adapters, configuration using interface scripts, SYSCONFIG, configuration using global settings, configurations that apply to all NICs, name lookups, NetworkManager (NMCLI), and configuring using NetworkManager.
episodes.title: Configure Networking
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.001 --> 00:00:05.351
Welcome to ITProvTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:05.351 --> 00:00:11.922
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.922 --> 00:00:14.294
>> Hello, and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

4
00:00:14.294 --> 00:00:16.172
helping you learn wherever you go.

5
00:00:16.172 --> 00:00:17.678
I'm your host, Zach Memos,

6
00:00:17.678 --> 00:00:20.890
as we continue on with Becoming
a Linux Server Administrator.

7
00:00:21.990 --> 00:00:25.640
>> This topic right now is
configuring networking.

8
00:00:25.640 --> 00:00:26.756
Who's bringing you this information?

9
00:00:26.756 --> 00:00:28.004
Not me, no.

10
00:00:28.004 --> 00:00:29.942
The man, the myth, the legend Don Pezet.

11
00:00:29.942 --> 00:00:31.974
Don, nice to have you with us,
thanks for joining us.

12
00:00:31.974 --> 00:00:33.158
>> Thanks for having me, Zach.

13
00:00:33.158 --> 00:00:33.668
And yeah,

14
00:00:33.668 --> 00:00:37.950
we're gonna be jumping right back into
the world of Linux server administration.

15
00:00:37.950 --> 00:00:38.950
And in this particular episode,

16
00:00:38.950 --> 00:00:41.590
we're gonna take a look at
configuring networking, right.

17
00:00:41.590 --> 00:00:43.620
We need to get our network adapters up and
running.

18
00:00:43.620 --> 00:00:47.610
They need IP addresses, and subnet masks,
default routes, all the various things

19
00:00:47.610 --> 00:00:49.560
that we need to configure to
get our systems communicating.

20
00:00:49.560 --> 00:00:53.720
Because it is a rare day that we
implement systems now that are not

21
00:00:53.720 --> 00:00:54.770
connected to a network.

22
00:00:54.770 --> 00:00:57.762
So this is a really important step
in rolling out our systems into our

23
00:00:57.762 --> 00:00:58.980
production environment.

24
00:00:58.980 --> 00:01:01.680
So that's what we're gonna be taking
look at right here, in this episode.

25
00:01:01.680 --> 00:01:05.475
>> Well Dan, if we've already
configured network in the install,

26
00:01:05.475 --> 00:01:07.201
what else would we need to do?

27
00:01:07.201 --> 00:01:08.790
>> Well yeah, that's true.

28
00:01:08.790 --> 00:01:12.420
So if you've been watching all these
episodes, and started with installation,

29
00:01:12.420 --> 00:01:15.770
right, in the installation it
asked us to pick an IP address.

30
00:01:15.770 --> 00:01:20.530
It asked us to assign a subnet mask and
a default gateway.

31
00:01:20.530 --> 00:01:23.120
And we clicked Next on through that,
and it's already configured.

32
00:01:23.120 --> 00:01:26.450
So in the example of the server
I've been using this whole series,

33
00:01:26.450 --> 00:01:29.160
it's already configured for
a network, right?

34
00:01:29.160 --> 00:01:31.320
Well, that's true, but it's also not true.

35
00:01:31.320 --> 00:01:34.140
It's true in that it does some
basic network configuration.

36
00:01:34.140 --> 00:01:38.200
It's not true in that it doesn't
have anything advanced, and

37
00:01:38.200 --> 00:01:41.410
I only configured one network adapter.

38
00:01:41.410 --> 00:01:43.440
What if I have more than
one network adapter?

39
00:01:43.440 --> 00:01:44.804
Right, let met show you here on my server.

40
00:01:44.804 --> 00:01:48.070
So my server actually has four
different network adapters in it.

41
00:01:48.070 --> 00:01:51.690
A lot of servers will either have
two network adapters or four,

42
00:01:51.690 --> 00:01:53.180
that's very common today.

43
00:01:53.180 --> 00:01:56.040
I can't remember the last time I saw
a server that only had one network jack on

44
00:01:56.040 --> 00:01:57.490
it, so it's pretty rare.

45
00:01:57.490 --> 00:02:00.740
But if you go in and run, well, we've
got a few different commands we can run.

46
00:02:00.740 --> 00:02:07.400
The old school command is ifconfig, which
is the interface configuration command.

47
00:02:07.400 --> 00:02:10.990
And this command is available
on most UNIX systems.

48
00:02:10.990 --> 00:02:14.120
So it's usually what I go to,
cuz I know this command is gonna work.

49
00:02:14.120 --> 00:02:15.760
But that's not entirely true anymore.

50
00:02:15.760 --> 00:02:17.880
We're starting to see some
new commands replace this.

51
00:02:17.880 --> 00:02:20.800
But ifconfig will show me my adapters.

52
00:02:20.800 --> 00:02:25.253
And when I look,
I can see where I've got ens33, right?

53
00:02:25.253 --> 00:02:29.830
And it's got an IP address,
it's got a subnet mask.

54
00:02:29.830 --> 00:02:32.330
It's got a gateway, it's configured.

55
00:02:32.330 --> 00:02:34.470
That's what was set up during my install.

56
00:02:34.470 --> 00:02:39.165
But I've also got ens36, ens37, ens38.

57
00:02:39.165 --> 00:02:42.340
I've got three more network
adapters in there, right?

58
00:02:42.340 --> 00:02:44.410
And they were not configured
during the install.

59
00:02:44.410 --> 00:02:45.930
So they don't have IP addresses.

60
00:02:45.930 --> 00:02:48.840
They don't have subnet masks,
it's incomplete.

61
00:02:48.840 --> 00:02:53.350
Now that's very common, after an install
it's only got one adapter configured.

62
00:02:53.350 --> 00:02:56.737
The other scenario where we'd
need to do this configuration is,

63
00:02:56.737 --> 00:02:59.210
maybe I needed a driver for
my network adapter.

64
00:02:59.210 --> 00:03:02.070
And so the network adapter didn't
show up during the install, so

65
00:03:02.070 --> 00:03:03.530
it couldn't be configured.

66
00:03:03.530 --> 00:03:05.424
And you finished the install and
there you are, no adapters are configured.

67
00:03:05.424 --> 00:03:07.410
And now we've gotta do it by hand.

68
00:03:07.410 --> 00:03:10.060
And a third scenario would be
if you do a minimal install.

69
00:03:10.060 --> 00:03:13.880
A lot of minimal installs won't
configure a network adapter.

70
00:03:13.880 --> 00:03:15.770
So now they boot up, and
the network's not even set up.

71
00:03:15.770 --> 00:03:16.870
You've gotta go in and do it.

72
00:03:16.870 --> 00:03:20.160
So those are all scenarios where we might
need to get in there and configure.

73
00:03:20.160 --> 00:03:22.140
And the command that I ran, that ifconfig,

74
00:03:22.140 --> 00:03:24.660
I mentioned that we're seeing
it start to get replaced.

75
00:03:24.660 --> 00:03:29.368
In new systems released in the last few
years and going forward in the future,

76
00:03:29.368 --> 00:03:31.880
you'll wanna use the ip command.

77
00:03:31.880 --> 00:03:34.840
The ip command also lets
you see interfaces.

78
00:03:34.840 --> 00:03:38.833
Or so I can say something like,
ip addr, to see my IP addresses.

79
00:03:38.833 --> 00:03:41.137
And it shows me my four interfaces.

80
00:03:41.137 --> 00:03:43.170
Actually, I have five if
you count the loopback.

81
00:03:43.170 --> 00:03:48.030
And my four interfaces here, ens33 which
has a config, and then 36, 37, 38.

82
00:03:48.030 --> 00:03:50.315
These guys that are missing
a configuration,

83
00:03:50.315 --> 00:03:51.846
because they don't have one.

84
00:03:51.846 --> 00:03:55.550
So I can see that, and
I need to go in and start to work with it.

85
00:03:55.550 --> 00:03:59.332
The ip command is a lot more
powerful than the old ifconfig.

86
00:03:59.332 --> 00:04:01.460
The ifconfig just showed
you about the interfaces.

87
00:04:01.460 --> 00:04:05.420
But ip, I can say ip route and
it will show me my routing table.

88
00:04:05.420 --> 00:04:06.860
And so
I can see what my default routes are.

89
00:04:06.860 --> 00:04:10.008
So there's a lot more that you can do
with the ip command than ifconfig.

90
00:04:10.008 --> 00:04:12.270
So that's kinda the logical replacement.

91
00:04:12.270 --> 00:04:16.568
And we're starting to see some systems
that don't ship with ifconfig any more.

92
00:04:16.568 --> 00:04:21.196
If you do a brand new install with,
I believe it's CentOS 7,

93
00:04:21.196 --> 00:04:24.847
where it has ip, but
it doesn't have ifconfig.

94
00:04:24.847 --> 00:04:27.382
So just know that there's
two different commands for

95
00:04:27.382 --> 00:04:31.170
quickly viewing those adapters and seeing
what it is that we need to configure.

96
00:04:32.250 --> 00:04:36.660
Now it could be that we've already
configured things, but we made changes and

97
00:04:36.660 --> 00:04:38.420
they just haven't taken effect yet.

98
00:04:38.420 --> 00:04:40.270
So maybe we don't really
need to configure anything.

99
00:04:40.270 --> 00:04:42.050
We just need to restart
our networking stack.

100
00:04:42.050 --> 00:04:44.838
Maybe I just installed a driver, and
then after I restart the networking stack,

101
00:04:44.838 --> 00:04:45.880
everything works.

102
00:04:45.880 --> 00:04:47.580
You could reboot the whole server.

103
00:04:47.580 --> 00:04:50.290
Or you could just restart
the networking service, right?

104
00:04:50.290 --> 00:04:54.990
On older systems that use upstart or an
init, then what you would do is you would

105
00:04:54.990 --> 00:04:59.560
say, service network restart, like that.

106
00:04:59.560 --> 00:05:01.360
And that would restart the network stack.

107
00:05:01.360 --> 00:05:03.661
But most systems have
moved to systemd now.

108
00:05:03.661 --> 00:05:07.030
And if you're on a systemd system,
it's gonna look a little different.

109
00:05:07.030 --> 00:05:13.320
What you're gonna do is say,
systemctl restart network.service.

110
00:05:13.320 --> 00:05:14.570
Like that, okay?

111
00:05:14.570 --> 00:05:17.120
And that will restart your
networking subsystem.

112
00:05:17.120 --> 00:05:20.930
And any changes that hadn't taken
effect will now take effect, right?

113
00:05:20.930 --> 00:05:22.780
So it might not be that I
need to configure something.

114
00:05:22.780 --> 00:05:24.330
It might already be configured.

115
00:05:24.330 --> 00:05:26.800
I just need to restart and
let that kinda be detected.

116
00:05:26.800 --> 00:05:30.320
So those are ways that we can do that and
kinda get it put in place.

117
00:05:30.320 --> 00:05:34.100
>> So, how do we go about
configuring those adapters?

118
00:05:34.100 --> 00:05:37.970
>> Yeah, in my example,
a restart is not enough, right?

119
00:05:37.970 --> 00:05:38.820
It's not setup.

120
00:05:38.820 --> 00:05:41.910
If I take a look at that,
I still dont have IPs.

121
00:05:41.910 --> 00:05:43.990
I need to get things set up.

122
00:05:43.990 --> 00:05:47.050
There's a few different ways
these adapters can be managed.

123
00:05:47.050 --> 00:05:51.980
But in most systems,
each adapter has its own interface script.

124
00:05:51.980 --> 00:05:55.640
And the interface script defines
exactly what its configuration is.

125
00:05:55.640 --> 00:06:01.544
If you wanna look at them,
they're in /etc/sysconfig/,

126
00:06:01.544 --> 00:06:05.298
let's see, it is network-scripts.

127
00:06:05.298 --> 00:06:07.430
That folder right there, okay.

128
00:06:07.430 --> 00:06:09.479
And if you look in there,
you'll see a lot of stuff.

129
00:06:10.590 --> 00:06:13.940
But the main ones that we wanna look
at are right at the very beginning,

130
00:06:13.940 --> 00:06:22.500
these guys here where it says
ifcfg-ens33 or ifcfg-lo.

131
00:06:22.500 --> 00:06:25.786
Right, lo is my loopback adapter, and
it just points right back at yourself.

132
00:06:25.786 --> 00:06:30.360
But ens33, that's the network card
that l configured during setup.

133
00:06:30.360 --> 00:06:32.520
So l can see it right there.

134
00:06:32.520 --> 00:06:36.843
I don't have an ens36, or 37, or
38, they don't have a script.

135
00:06:36.843 --> 00:06:39.380
And with no script,
they're not configured.

136
00:06:39.380 --> 00:06:42.602
So when I restarted the network service,
all I did was look in here to see which

137
00:06:42.602 --> 00:06:45.391
interfaces had a script, and
pulled the information out of them.

138
00:06:45.391 --> 00:06:46.831
And off it goes, right?

139
00:06:46.831 --> 00:06:49.410
And if they don't have a script,
they don't get configured.

140
00:06:49.410 --> 00:06:53.206
So if I wanna configure my other
interfaces, I need to create scripts for

141
00:06:53.206 --> 00:06:54.540
them, all right?

142
00:06:54.540 --> 00:07:00.690
Now, one question that I usually get
is why is called ens33, in my case?

143
00:07:00.690 --> 00:07:03.053
Cuz you'll see different names, right?

144
00:07:03.053 --> 00:07:06.218
This is in a virtual machine,
this particular system.

145
00:07:06.218 --> 00:07:10.711
If I were to switch back
to my actual laptop and

146
00:07:10.711 --> 00:07:15.794
take a look at the same thing,
on my actual laptop,

147
00:07:15.794 --> 00:07:19.594
my interface is called enp3s0f1.

148
00:07:19.594 --> 00:07:21.916
All right, well, [LAUGH].

149
00:07:21.916 --> 00:07:22.821
>> Yay!

150
00:07:22.821 --> 00:07:24.819
>> So it starts with en, right?

151
00:07:24.819 --> 00:07:26.258
At least it's got that in common.

152
00:07:26.258 --> 00:07:29.556
But the whole rest of that thing,
that is just quite a mess.

153
00:07:29.556 --> 00:07:33.355
And you'll see,
wlp2so is another interface that I've got.

154
00:07:33.355 --> 00:07:35.340
These are valid interfaces on my laptop.

155
00:07:35.340 --> 00:07:37.250
So where are these names coming from?

156
00:07:37.250 --> 00:07:39.990
Well, the names are made up of
a couple of different pieces.

157
00:07:39.990 --> 00:07:41.060
Some of them you can kinda guess.

158
00:07:41.060 --> 00:07:43.420
en, that's short for ethernet.

159
00:07:43.420 --> 00:07:46.360
That lets me know that that's
a physical network jack.

160
00:07:46.360 --> 00:07:48.311
On my laptop, I have a physical
network jack on the side.

161
00:07:48.311 --> 00:07:52.931
And that's what I'm plugged into, and
it's an en, an ethernet interface.

162
00:07:52.931 --> 00:07:57.683
On my virtual machine,
it has an ethernet interface.

163
00:07:57.683 --> 00:08:00.043
So en, blah, blah, blah,
right, so that's what en is.

164
00:08:00.043 --> 00:08:02.152
And wl, that's wireless, right?

165
00:08:02.152 --> 00:08:07.440
So this is a wireless adapter that I'm
connected with here, wlp2s0, whatever.

166
00:08:07.440 --> 00:08:08.531
So that wl's wireless.

167
00:08:08.531 --> 00:08:10.980
So en and wl,
pretty good indicators there.

168
00:08:12.020 --> 00:08:14.310
You might see lo for LoopBack.

169
00:08:14.310 --> 00:08:16.800
I've got vi for
some of my virtual interfaces.

170
00:08:16.800 --> 00:08:19.610
I'm running VMware Workstations, so
I have some virtual interfaces in place.

171
00:08:19.610 --> 00:08:22.072
You might see ww, which are for WAN cards,

172
00:08:22.072 --> 00:08:25.296
like if you have a wireless
cellular card or something.

173
00:08:25.296 --> 00:08:28.841
It's not very common, but you might have
one of those, so you'll see that in place.

174
00:08:28.841 --> 00:08:33.827
Now the next part, though, see how I've
got a p here versus in the virtual machine

175
00:08:33.827 --> 00:08:36.490
where I had an s, that kind of thing?

176
00:08:36.490 --> 00:08:39.147
The p means it's a pci card, right?

177
00:08:39.147 --> 00:08:42.020
This is a pci card that's
actually my system.

178
00:08:42.020 --> 00:08:43.350
Well, I've got a laptop.

179
00:08:43.350 --> 00:08:45.640
Until it's integrated into the system,
it's not a card.

180
00:08:45.640 --> 00:08:47.080
I can't take it out.

181
00:08:47.080 --> 00:08:51.544
So it's soldered into the motherboard but
it's soldered under the pci bus, so enp or

182
00:08:51.544 --> 00:08:54.480
wlp is telling me it's on the pci bus.

183
00:08:54.480 --> 00:09:00.690
In my virtual machine it shows as ens and
that s means that it's a hot plug device.

184
00:09:00.690 --> 00:09:02.767
And a hot plug device is usually a USB,
right?

185
00:09:02.767 --> 00:09:06.379
Well, I know my virtual machine is not
actually a USB, but in a virtual machine

186
00:09:06.379 --> 00:09:10.430
you don't truly have a pci bus, and so it
just adds it like any other USB adapter.

187
00:09:10.430 --> 00:09:11.972
So it kind of shows it that way.

188
00:09:11.972 --> 00:09:17.100
But s isn't just USB, it could be FireWire
or Thunderbolt or other technologies, too.

189
00:09:17.100 --> 00:09:19.104
So don't, in your mind,
just tie that to USB.

190
00:09:19.104 --> 00:09:22.080
But it's hot plug devices
will show an x right there.

191
00:09:22.080 --> 00:09:26.853
All right, now the rest of it
is a bit more of mystery, right?

192
00:09:26.853 --> 00:09:29.195
This is actually determined
by your operating system.

193
00:09:29.195 --> 00:09:32.945
Different operating systems will give
them different nomenclature after that

194
00:09:32.945 --> 00:09:36.235
depending on what number of
the interface it is and so on.

195
00:09:36.235 --> 00:09:38.595
So you'll see different
things kinda pop up in here.

196
00:09:38.595 --> 00:09:42.615
But that first part gives us the clue
to what kind of interface that is.

197
00:09:42.615 --> 00:09:44.515
That's kind of where
those names come from.

198
00:09:44.515 --> 00:09:48.150
So when I'm trying to figure out which
adapters I need to configure, and

199
00:09:48.150 --> 00:09:52.330
I'm looking at this server,
I can use IPADDR or

200
00:09:52.330 --> 00:09:54.740
I have config to look of
the interfaces I've got.

201
00:09:54.740 --> 00:09:58.990
And I can see, hey, I've got ens 36,
that has not been configured.

202
00:09:58.990 --> 00:10:02.437
I need to get that one configured, so
I need to create a script for ens 36.

203
00:10:02.437 --> 00:10:06.710
And if I looked in here,
I don't have one, right?

204
00:10:06.710 --> 00:10:07.960
So I can create one.

205
00:10:07.960 --> 00:10:10.170
And you do need to be
an administrator to do this.

206
00:10:10.170 --> 00:10:13.249
Actually a lot of what I'm gonna do
needs to be an administrator, so

207
00:10:13.249 --> 00:10:16.011
I'm gonna go ahead and
elevate my privileges with sudo -s.

208
00:10:16.011 --> 00:10:20.459
I'm switching over to a root user, just so
I don't have to sudo every command, but

209
00:10:20.459 --> 00:10:22.340
I can certainly do that way, too.

210
00:10:22.340 --> 00:10:25.220
And I'm gonna edit a file, right?

211
00:10:25.220 --> 00:10:28.320
The file that I'm gonna edit is
gonna be called ifcfg, right,

212
00:10:28.320 --> 00:10:33.400
so interface configuration-ens 36, right?

213
00:10:33.400 --> 00:10:35.550
I'm gonna write a script for
that interface.

214
00:10:36.610 --> 00:10:37.970
And in that script,

215

00:17:27.747 --> 00:17:31.705
And now it's dropped
me down to runlevel 1.

339
00:17:32.810 --> 00:17:33.788
The system didn't reboot.

340
00:17:33.788 --> 00:17:38.760
It just re-ran the scripts that were
appropriate for the new runlevel.

341
00:17:38.760 --> 00:17:41.170
And it chucked me down to this.

342
00:17:41.170 --> 00:17:50.180
And if I do like a ps -p 1 I can still
see that init is that first process.

343
00:17:50.180 --> 00:17:52.999
And if I run the runlevel command I

344
00:17:52.999 --> 00:17:57.152
can see that my current
runlevel is single user.

345
00:17:57.152 --> 00:18:01.260
I'm in that 1,
which moved me into single user mode.

346
00:18:01.260 --> 00:18:02.110
So I can spot that.

347
00:18:02.110 --> 00:18:05.638
And then if I transition again,
I can just say, well, I'm already root so

348
00:18:05.638 --> 00:18:06.933
I don't have to sudo this.

349
00:18:06.933 --> 00:18:11.477
But I will init and bump into,
let's say, runlevel 3.

350
00:18:11.477 --> 00:18:16.720
So now I'm multi-user again,
but now I will have networking.

351
00:18:16.720 --> 00:18:19.780
So I can see it's pulling IP
information from my network adapter.

352
00:18:19.780 --> 00:18:23.280
And it's going through and doing the boot.

353
00:18:23.280 --> 00:18:27.720
And then I'll get back to a log in shell
that's a little more what I'm used to.

354
00:18:27.720 --> 00:18:30.593
And I'll get logged in here.

355
00:18:30.593 --> 00:18:32.580
I'll break the rules and log in as root.

356
00:18:32.580 --> 00:18:36.000
But once I'm in I can
pull up that runlevel.

357
00:18:36.000 --> 00:18:39.810
And now I see I've switched from
single user mode into runlevel 3.

358
00:18:39.810 --> 00:18:43.140
So I'm doing all of this transitioning
without every actually rebooting.

359
00:18:43.140 --> 00:18:45.150
We can just move back and
forth and that's it.

360
00:18:45.150 --> 00:18:51.578
So let me put it back into runlevel 5,
so my screen will look nice [LAUGH].

361
00:18:51.578 --> 00:18:58.372
And let me get out of the zoom,
and get logged back in.

362
00:18:58.372 --> 00:19:00.660
So, there's how we can quickly and
easily transition.

363
00:19:00.660 --> 00:19:02.930
And that was pretty fast,
a lot faster than rebooting.

364
00:19:02.930 --> 00:19:04.150
>> That was very fast.

365
00:19:04.150 --> 00:19:08.300
How do we know what systems
run at each runlevel?

366
00:19:08.300 --> 00:19:11.900
>> Okay, so right now,
I showed you guys those scripts.

367
00:19:11.900 --> 00:19:13.220
And the scripts are fine.

368
00:19:13.220 --> 00:19:15.440
If you wanna go through and
dig through those scripts,

369
00:19:15.440 --> 00:19:17.530
you can learn a lot about
what your system does.

370
00:19:17.530 --> 00:19:20.740
But if you've got upstart, like I do,

371
00:19:20.740 --> 00:19:24.370
then there's a whole suite of utilities
we can use to make this a lot easier.

372
00:19:24.370 --> 00:19:28.410
In the old init days,
if you just had true sysvinit

373
00:19:28.410 --> 00:19:32.430
the way I would answer Zach's question
is you go to those rc.d folders and

374
00:19:32.430 --> 00:19:34.720
you find the runlevel and
you look at the services and you do that.

375
00:19:34.720 --> 00:19:36.280
That's the hard way.

376
00:19:36.280 --> 00:19:38.130
But Upstart made it easy.

377
00:19:38.130 --> 00:19:41.780
With Upstart you have two
commands that are really handy.

378
00:19:41.780 --> 00:19:47.580
The first one is the chkconfig command,
the check configuration command.

379
00:19:47.580 --> 00:19:51.270
And this lets you check services to see
what runlevels they're configured for.

380
00:19:51.270 --> 00:19:56.150
And you can set them to start at some
runlevels and not start at others and

381
00:19:56.150 --> 00:19:57.610
to start automatically.

382
00:19:57.610 --> 00:19:59.500
This is the command that we would use for
that.

383
00:19:59.500 --> 00:20:02.260
So, for example, SSH.

384
00:20:02.260 --> 00:20:03.590
SSH is important to me.

385
00:20:03.590 --> 00:20:07.090
I want it running if I'm in runlevel 3,
multiuser with networking.

386
00:20:07.090 --> 00:20:10.978
And if I'm in runlevel 5,
multi-user with graphical user interface,

387
00:20:10.978 --> 00:20:12.430
I want SSH running.

388
00:20:12.430 --> 00:20:15.880
But if I drop to single user mode,
I don't want SSH running.

389
00:20:15.880 --> 00:20:19.570
So I might want it in runlevels 3 and
5 but not in runlevel 1.

390
00:20:19.570 --> 00:20:25.300
Well, I can say chkconfig --list and
then the name of a service.

391
00:20:26.340 --> 00:20:32.550
So I could say sshd and it will show
me the runlevels that it's active for.

392
00:20:32.550 --> 00:20:34.850
Remember cups a moment ago where
I had to hunt and find it?

393
00:20:34.850 --> 00:20:36.280
>> Yeah.
>> That was super annoying.

394
00:20:36.280 --> 00:20:39.970
I could've just come in and
said, let me find cups.

395
00:20:39.970 --> 00:20:42.490
And there it is, and
it tells me the runlevels.

396
00:20:42.490 --> 00:20:46.930
And if I look at ssh,
it's turned on not for runlevel 1.

397
00:20:46.930 --> 00:20:49.830
So it's off for
that cuz it's single user mode.

398
00:20:49.830 --> 00:20:53.720
It's on for runlevel 2 and
3, on for runlevels 4 and

399
00:20:53.720 --> 00:20:55.570
5 and then off for 0 and 6.

400
00:20:55.570 --> 00:20:58.490
Everything should be off for 0 and
6 cuz the system is shutting down.

401
00:20:58.490 --> 00:21:00.910
So it's actually kinda set
the way that I want it anyway.

402
00:21:01.970 --> 00:21:04.780
But I can get in there and
I can modify that.

403
00:21:04.780 --> 00:21:08.890
A lot of people use a very basic
form of the chkconfig command.

404
00:21:08.890 --> 00:21:15.180
They do chkconfig and
then they'll say something like sshd off.

405
00:21:16.560 --> 00:21:21.580
And that will turn off the sshd service.

406
00:21:21.580 --> 00:21:27.320
But what it's really doing is
turning it off for those runlevels.

407
00:21:27.320 --> 00:21:33.703
And when you say chkconfig sshd on,
we think we're turning that service on.

408
00:21:33.703 --> 00:21:39.748
But what it's really doing is it's just
saying turn it on for these runlevels.

409
00:21:39.748 --> 00:21:44.210
And when it did it, it turned it on for
runlevels 2, 3, 4, and 5.

410
00:21:44.210 --> 00:21:47.910
Well, we don't really use
runlevel 2 very much.

411
00:21:47.910 --> 00:21:50.320
And runlevel 4 is not even defined.

412
00:21:50.320 --> 00:21:50.998
That's an empty one.

413
00:21:50.998 --> 00:21:53.480
It's one that you can use if you
wanna create a custom runlevel 3 for

414
00:21:53.480 --> 00:21:54.890
your own needs.

415
00:21:54.890 --> 00:21:59.690
So what if I wanna be really literal and
say I just want runlevel 3 and 5?

416
00:21:59.690 --> 00:22:02.584
Well, I can turn it back off again.

417
00:22:02.584 --> 00:22:05.990
So now it's off for all runlevels.

418
00:22:05.990 --> 00:22:09.420
And when I use that
chkconfig sshd on command,

419
00:22:09.420 --> 00:22:12.130
I can add a little bit more to it.

420
00:22:12.130 --> 00:22:18.020
I can say chkconfig --level followed by
the runlevels that I want to support.

421
00:22:18.020 --> 00:22:21.080
I'm gonna say 3 and 5, like that.

422
00:22:21.080 --> 00:22:26.200
So by saying checkconfig
--level 35 sshd on

423
00:22:26.200 --> 00:22:29.920
now I'm just gonna turn it on for
runlevels 3 and 5.

424
00:22:29.920 --> 00:22:32.490
And when I look at
the new list there it is.

425
00:22:32.490 --> 00:22:36.990
Runlevel 2 and
runlevel 4 will not start ssh.

426
00:22:36.990 --> 00:22:40.710
So now I'm dictating which runlevels
these services will run at.

427
00:22:40.710 --> 00:22:43.970
And I can go through and
customize every service if I wanted.

428
00:22:43.970 --> 00:22:47.240
If I wanted to be able to print
while I was in single user mode,

429
00:22:47.240 --> 00:22:49.900
I could set cups so
that it was on in runlevel 1.

430
00:22:49.900 --> 00:22:52.380
And so now yeah,
I booted in single user mode.

431
00:22:52.380 --> 00:22:54.380
But I can still print out my reports or

432
00:22:54.380 --> 00:22:55.730
whatever it is that I'm
trying to generate.

433
00:22:55.730 --> 00:22:58.290
Maybe the forensics guys need that,
they can do that.

434
00:22:58.290 --> 00:22:59.830
They set that up.

435
00:22:59.830 --> 00:23:02.990
Now, it's defined here in the runlevel.

436
00:23:02.990 --> 00:23:07.750
And, so if I reboot, or if I use the init
command, and move into runlevel 3 or

437
00:23:07.750 --> 00:23:10.750
5, then sshd is going to start.

438
00:23:10.750 --> 00:23:14.340
So, that's how we manage
it on a permanent basis.

439
00:23:14.340 --> 00:23:18.070
But on a temporary basis,
let's say I wanna start sshd right now but

440
00:23:18.070 --> 00:23:20.140
I don't wanna reboot the system.

441
00:23:20.140 --> 00:23:23.410
Then we can always use the service
command to help with that.

442
00:23:23.410 --> 00:23:27.130
But the service command is not persistent,
it's a temporary thing.

443
00:23:27.130 --> 00:23:32.710
If I say service sshd start,
actually let me sudo that,

444
00:23:32.710 --> 00:23:36.950
I can start sshd, or I can stop it.

445
00:23:36.950 --> 00:23:40.330
But, if I stop it and I reboot, or

446
00:23:40.330 --> 00:23:43.880
anytime I enter runlevel 3 or
runlevel 5 it's gonna start it again.

447
00:23:43.880 --> 00:23:49.092
So the service command is how we
temporarily interact with init or upstart.

448
00:23:49.092 --> 00:23:52.690
But chkconfig is how
we make it persistent.

449
00:23:52.690 --> 00:23:53.866
And so we normally have to use both.

450
00:23:53.866 --> 00:23:58.289
And when you read instructions,
like how you install service X, Y,

451
00:23:58.289 --> 00:24:02.346
Z they'll usually say,
we need you to go in and do a chkconfig.

452
00:24:02.346 --> 00:24:04.426
Sshd on, right?

453
00:24:04.426 --> 00:24:07.517
And that's gonna turn off on for
the run level and

454
00:24:07.517 --> 00:24:10.950
then follow the up with
a service sshd start, right?

455
00:24:10.950 --> 00:24:14.720
So we put the permanent change in place,
and then we temporarily start it

456
00:24:14.720 --> 00:24:18.300
knowing that on the next reboot it'll
be put back the way that we want and

457
00:24:18.300 --> 00:24:19.700
everything kinda goes in there.

458
00:24:19.700 --> 00:24:24.578
And you can always do a service
status sshd to look at the current

459
00:24:24.578 --> 00:24:28.363
status of it and see,
oops, I got it backwards.

460
00:24:28.363 --> 00:24:34.450
It's service shhd status,
there we go, and permission denied.

461
00:24:34.450 --> 00:24:37.431
Well actually, it's kind of
fortunate that I got that because.

462
00:24:37.431 --> 00:24:38.830
>> [LAUGH] Live action debugging.

463
00:24:38.830 --> 00:24:40.720
>> Look at the permission
that I got denied on, right?

464
00:24:40.720 --> 00:24:45.390
So I ran service shhd status,
tell me the status of that service, right?

465
00:24:45.390 --> 00:24:46.840
And do you see the error?

466
00:24:46.840 --> 00:24:51.440
/etc/init.d/sshd, so
it was init carrying out that role, and

467
00:24:51.440 --> 00:24:56.118
if I run it with the actual permissions,
then I can see right here that

468
00:24:56.118 --> 00:25:00.895
it's being powered by openssh and
it's currently running, right?

469
00:25:00.895 --> 00:25:03.753
So init, you may have never heard of it.

470
00:25:03.753 --> 00:25:06.339
Prior to watching this show, this may be
the first time you've ever heard of init

471
00:25:06.339 --> 00:25:07.920
or Upstart for that matter, right?

472
00:25:07.920 --> 00:25:13.210
But in reality you've been using it every
single moment you've been on your system.

473
00:25:13.210 --> 00:25:16.940
And as a desktop administrator,
or a home user,

474
00:25:16.940 --> 00:25:18.930
or just a hobbyist you
may not care about that.

475
00:25:18.930 --> 00:25:21.100
So you may have never interacted with it,
but

476
00:25:21.100 --> 00:25:24.660
as a server administrator,
it's really important.

477
00:25:24.660 --> 00:25:28.150
Because you could have a server configured
perfectly, have a MySQL database up and

478
00:25:28.150 --> 00:25:29.270
it's running great.

479
00:25:29.270 --> 00:25:31.380
And then something happens and
the server reboots and

480
00:25:31.380 --> 00:25:33.620
now everything's not running anymore,
right?

481
00:25:33.620 --> 00:25:36.010
Or things run in the wrong order,
or something happens and

482
00:25:36.010 --> 00:25:37.500
that service is broken.

483
00:25:37.500 --> 00:25:38.860
This is really important,

484
00:25:38.860 --> 00:25:41.750
we've got to make sure that the
initialization system knows what we want

485
00:25:41.750 --> 00:25:45.120
started, what we need to have that
server performing its functions.

486
00:25:45.120 --> 00:25:46.610
And so these are the ways that we do that.

487
00:25:46.610 --> 00:25:52.440
So the key things to take away here
are the inittab file, /etc/inittab.

488
00:25:52.440 --> 00:25:54.955
That sets your default run level.

489
00:25:54.955 --> 00:26:00.300
Chkconfig can easily allow us to assign
services to one run level or another.

490
00:26:00.300 --> 00:26:06.000
And then service can temporarily start and
stop services and get them running.

491
00:26:06.000 --> 00:26:10.519
So between those three places we got
everything we need to interact with

492
00:26:10.519 --> 00:26:11.962
the init and Upstart.

493
00:26:11.962 --> 00:26:18.524
>> Fantastic information as usual Don, so
cisv, init, and Upstart, any final words?

494
00:26:18.524 --> 00:26:21.360
>> I did mention that systemd
is the replacement for this.

495
00:26:22.730 --> 00:26:28.870
Most distros that are running systemd
actually still honor the init commands.

496
00:26:28.870 --> 00:26:32.490
So if you go onto a systemd system and
use the service command or

497
00:26:32.490 --> 00:26:36.400
you use the chkconfig command, most of
them will translate it into systemd land.

498
00:26:36.400 --> 00:26:40.850
So you can still get away with it,
but if you're on an init system,

499
00:26:40.850 --> 00:26:43.484
it will not take the systemd commands.

500
00:26:43.484 --> 00:26:46.760
So I do encourage people to
learn both sets of commands.

501
00:26:46.760 --> 00:26:48.730
If you're just using Upstart today,

502
00:26:48.730 --> 00:26:51.050
you wanna learn systemd
because it's the future.

503
00:26:51.050 --> 00:26:52.915
And if you're just using systemd today,

504
00:26:52.915 --> 00:26:55.990
it's still useful to learn init
because you may encounter it.

505
00:26:55.990 --> 00:26:58.270
It's still very very common out there.

506
00:26:58.270 --> 00:27:01.380
It's gonna be a while before
everybody is completely on systemd.

507
00:27:01.380 --> 00:27:05.370
But every current distro being
released is systemd based,

508
00:27:05.370 --> 00:27:06.690
all the major ones at least.

509
00:27:06.690 --> 00:27:09.380
Ubuntu, Debian, Red Hat, CentOS,

510
00:27:09.380 --> 00:27:13.920
Fedora, they've all moved to systemd so
that is the way of the future.

511
00:27:13.920 --> 00:27:16.040
>> Great information,
Don, thanks very much.

512
00:27:16.040 --> 00:27:18.160
And becoming a Linux server administrator.

513
00:27:18.160 --> 00:27:21.100
There's a lot of video
content in the series.

514
00:27:21.100 --> 00:27:22.560
Make sure you watch each and every video.

515
00:27:22.560 --> 00:27:26.110
You'll be glad you did and
thank you for watching ITProTV.

516
00:27:26.110 --> 00:27:29.980
Remember, a good IT pro is
always learning, I'm Zach Memos.

517
00:27:29.980 --> 00:27:30.650
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

518
00:27:30.650 --> 00:27:33.478
>> And we will see you very soon.

519
00:27:33.478 --> 00:27:39.389
[MUSIC]

520
00:27:39.389 --> 00:27:41.420
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

00:00:15.265 --> 00:00:17.425

9
00:00:17.425 --> 00:00:19.999
I'm your host Zach Memos as
we continue on with Becoming

10
00:00:19.999 --> 00:00:21.491
a Linux Server Administrator.

11
00:00:21.491 --> 00:00:25.076
The topic right now is systemd, and
we're gonna learn all about it.

12
00:00:25.076 --> 00:00:26.648
And who's gonna bring us
to all that information?

13
00:00:26.648 --> 00:00:29.534
Don Pezet, our IT pro himself, right here.

14
00:00:29.534 --> 00:00:31.162
>> And I am glad to be on the show.

15
00:00:31.162 --> 00:00:36.112
In the last episode I had talked
about upstart and init, sysvinit.

16
00:00:36.112 --> 00:00:38.341
And during that whole
episode I kept saying, well,

17
00:00:38.341 --> 00:00:40.883
you do wanna learn about systemd

18
00:00:40.883 --> 00:00:42.945
So I'm kinda glad in this episode-

19
00:00:42.945 --> 00:00:44.596
>> We get to be in the future [LAUGH].

20
00:00:44.596 --> 00:00:45.960
>> That's right.

21
00:00:45.960 --> 00:00:50.070
>> So in this episode, we're gonna be
taking a look at what systemd is, how it

22
00:00:50.070 --> 00:00:55.360
works, how it does its job, how it has
effectively replaced sysvinit and upstart.

23
00:00:55.360 --> 00:00:57.550
And how it is what we're gonna
be using to manage our system.

24
00:00:57.550 --> 00:01:00.220
So if we're deploying servers
that are running systemd,

25
00:01:00.220 --> 00:01:03.810
it is critical to keeping
our systems up and running.

26
00:01:03.810 --> 00:01:05.660
So it's important we have
a basic understanding of it and

27
00:01:05.660 --> 00:01:07.310
how to interact with it and maintain it.

28
00:01:07.310 --> 00:01:10.120
And that's all stuff that we're gonna
see right here in this episode.

29
00:01:10.120 --> 00:01:12.730
>> And like you just mentioned, in a
previous episode we learned about upstart.

30
00:01:12.730 --> 00:01:16.242
Why would we use systemd over upstart?

31
00:01:16.242 --> 00:01:19.950
>> All right, so for most people
the reason they're gonna switch to systemd

32
00:01:19.950 --> 00:01:22.615
is simply because whichever distro
they're using has switched.

33
00:01:22.615 --> 00:01:24.500
[LAUGH] And so that's it, right?

34
00:01:24.500 --> 00:01:29.640
If you're running Red Hat Enterprise Linux
6 then you're using upstart, right?

35
00:01:29.640 --> 00:01:32.830
And then when you upgrade to
Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7,

36
00:01:32.830 --> 00:01:36.120
they've switched to systemd which
means you've now switched to systemd.

37
00:01:36.120 --> 00:01:37.810
So that's what's gonna
happen to a lot of people.

38
00:01:37.810 --> 00:01:39.170
They're gonna switch because of that.

39
00:01:39.170 --> 00:01:43.402
And honestly, many people on a workstation
you wouldn't notice the difference.

40
00:01:43.402 --> 00:01:47.948
There's not really anything there that's
gonna show to the end user, right?

41
00:01:47.948 --> 00:01:51.570
But why are the distros
picking the switch to systemd?

42
00:01:51.570 --> 00:01:53.980
Obviously, they have to do a lot of
work to make a change like that.

43
00:01:53.980 --> 00:01:56.700
So what would motivate them
to make a change like that?

44
00:01:56.700 --> 00:02:01.050
The main thing is in nit,
a couple of problems.

45
00:02:01.050 --> 00:02:05.530
One problem was it didn't deal with
hot plug hardware really well.

46
00:02:05.530 --> 00:02:07.816
And in this day and age,
we are USB crazy, right?

47
00:02:07.816 --> 00:02:09.134
>> Yeah.
>> USB hard drives and mice and

48
00:02:09.134 --> 00:02:11.110
keyboards and all sorts of stuff.

49
00:02:11.110 --> 00:02:15.260
And init liked to do all of its
work when the system booted up or

50
00:02:15.260 --> 00:02:18.950
when the system changed run levels, which
normally was when you rebooted, right?

51
00:02:18.950 --> 00:02:20.490
We didn't change run levels very often.

52
00:02:20.490 --> 00:02:22.720
So it didn't handle hot
plug hardware very well.

53
00:02:22.720 --> 00:02:28.190
Now, let me make sure I'm clear on this,
you can have hot plug software under

54
00:02:28.190 --> 00:02:31.938
a NIT based systems and upstart systems,
it just doesn't handle it very well.

55
00:02:31.938 --> 00:02:36.940
So with systemd, what they said is
we're not just gonna start up and

56
00:02:36.940 --> 00:02:39.620
run some scripts and
then clock out, right?

57
00:02:39.620 --> 00:02:40.970
We're gonna start up and

58
00:02:40.970 --> 00:02:45.550
stay running and keep doing our job all
throughout the life cycle of this system,

59
00:02:45.550 --> 00:02:49.860
which makes it really easy for
it to detect and handle hot-plug hardware.

60
00:02:49.860 --> 00:02:53.700
In the server world, that's usually gonna
be hot-plug hard drives and detection for

61
00:02:53.700 --> 00:02:55.280
that, so it handles that really well, but

62
00:02:55.280 --> 00:02:58.500
also just additional hardware,
it does a great job with.

63
00:02:58.500 --> 00:03:01.980
But the other thing is,
it focused really on configuration.

64
00:03:01.980 --> 00:03:05.034
In the init world,
you have a ton of scripts right,

65
00:03:05.034 --> 00:03:09.579
all of these scripts that are in slash
etc slash rc.d, and a typo in any one of

66
00:03:09.579 --> 00:03:13.656
those scripts could really derail
your system and cause problems.

67
00:03:13.656 --> 00:03:17.101
Problems that might show up in one run
level and not show up in another run level

68
00:03:17.101 --> 00:03:20.705
or might cause where some of your services
run fine, and then there's this point

69
00:03:20.705 --> 00:03:24.160
where you get broken and then all
the other services don't run fine.

70
00:03:24.160 --> 00:03:26.750
It's really difficult to troubleshoot and
work with.

71
00:03:26.750 --> 00:03:29.980
And so with systemd, they took
the approach of saying, you know what?

72
00:03:29.980 --> 00:03:35.170
Instead of a bunch of scripts, let's go
with what's called a monolithic binary,

73
00:03:35.170 --> 00:03:36.760
one big binary program.

74
00:03:36.760 --> 00:03:40.260
Systemd, it's a program and
it's running in the background.

75
00:03:40.260 --> 00:03:43.680
And then it's gonna load
configuration files,

76
00:03:43.680 --> 00:03:45.460
all these different configuration files.

77
00:03:45.460 --> 00:03:48.988
And because it's loading config
files if one of them is messed up,

78
00:03:48.988 --> 00:03:50.510
it's not a script, right.

79
00:03:50.510 --> 00:03:53.009
It's a config file, so
we can just ignore it and move on and

80
00:03:53.009 --> 00:03:56.292
all the other ones are fine and
it can handle that much, much better.

81
00:03:56.292 --> 00:04:01.110
So systemd is more reliable and stable for

82
00:04:01.110 --> 00:04:05.080
environment where we may
potentially have errors like that.

83
00:04:05.080 --> 00:04:08.010
You will see a lot of
arguments on the Internet.

84
00:04:08.010 --> 00:04:11.200
There are people out

85
00:04:11.200 --> 00:04:15.070
And the main argument is that
it is this monolithic binary,

86
00:04:15.070 --> 00:04:17.220
this binary that does more than one thing.

87
00:04:17.220 --> 00:04:21.060
And in the Unix world, we normally try and
keep things very task focused.

88
00:04:21.060 --> 00:04:23.859
A system does one job, and
it does it really well.

89
00:04:23.859 --> 00:04:25.275
With systemd it's bigger, and

00:04:25.275 --> 00:04:28.358
it's got a lot of protections
to stop us from making mistakes.

00:04:28.358 --> 00:04:31.800
So the hardcore Unix administrators
will say, well, you know how I do that?

00:04:31.800 --> 00:04:32.520

00:04:33.660 --> 00:04:37.290

Don Pezet, make mistakes and so

00:04:37.290 --> 00:04:39.077

00:04:39.077 --> 00:04:41.120

00:04:41.120 --> 00:04:42.600

00:04:42.600 --> 00:04:44.185
So we all make mistakes.

00:04:44.185 --> 00:04:46.710
Systemd makes those mistakes less painful.

00:04:46.710 --> 00:04:48.420
And so I like it.

00:04:48.420 --> 00:04:50.104
The distros like it.

00:04:50.104 --> 00:04:54.454
You are seeing where Ubuntu,

cis via net to be in also.

00:05:08.140 --> 00:05:10.915
So, they're a little more on the fence,
but most of the distros have moved over,

107
00:05:10.915 --> 00:05:11.529
all the big ones.

00:05:11.529 --> 00:05:15.640
The big distros that we usually worry

So, that's one of the main reasons

00:07:56.969 --> 00:08:00.123

00:08:00.123 --> 00:08:04.037
Well, here all of the configuration

00:08:04.037 --> 00:08:07.420
So we're lumping all those

00:08:07.420 --> 00:08:11.681
And then we're defining things a little

00:08:11.681 --> 00:08:13.279
every file has an extension.

00:08:27.162 --> 00:08:30.245

00:08:30.245 --> 00:08:35.720

00:08:38.730 --> 00:08:45.860

00:09:30.790 --> 00:09:34.480

00:09:40.520 --> 00:09:42.520

00:09:42.520 --> 00:09:46.200

00:09:56.696 --> 00:10:01.570

00:10:01.570 --> 00:10:07.852

00:10:07.852 --> 00:10:11.980

00:10:11.980 --> 00:10:15.710
A unit is an individual thing,

00:10:15.710 --> 00:10:18.870

00:10:18.870 --> 00:10:20.981

00:10:20.981 --> 00:10:25.470

00:10:31.020 --> 00:10:33.590

00:10:33.590 --> 00:10:39.040

00:10:39.040 --> 00:10:43.220

00:10:43.220 --> 00:10:46.640

00:10:46.640 --> 00:10:52.005

00:10:52.005 --> 00:10:55.455

00:11:10.683 --> 00:11:12.148

00:11:12.148 --> 00:11:14.730
So I can easily activate a target.

00:11:14.730 --> 00:11:19.060
And when the target runs,

00:11:19.060 --> 00:11:21.550
So this is kind of a hierarchy.

00:11:21.550 --> 00:11:25.655
And so yes, there's a ton of stuff

00:11:25.655 --> 00:11:29.150

00:11:29.150 --> 00:11:31.336
And then you've got

00:11:31.336 --> 00:11:33.174
wants really cool.

00:11:33.174 --> 00:11:37.315
That's saying look,

00:11:37.315 --> 00:11:41.379

00:11:41.379 --> 00:11:46.860
And the timers.target might rely on

00:12:18.772 --> 00:12:21.490
And systemd reads these configurations.

00:12:21.490 --> 00:12:24.860
And it builds the proper boot order

00:12:24.860 --> 00:12:25.620

That's what it does.

00:12:26.860 --> 00:12:27.530
That's it's job.

00:12:27.530 --> 00:12:29.940
systemd is very powerful.

00:12:29.940 --> 00:12:34.600

496
00:25:31.740 --> 00:25:33.334
they feel like it just does too much,
right?

497
00:25:33.334 --> 00:25:35.880
>> [LAUGH]
>> That the old init system

498
00:25:35.880 --> 00:25:39.372
just ran a series of scripts,
and you controlled those scripts.

499
00:25:39.372 --> 00:25:43.563
But systemd does a lot more,
and you don't control it.

500
00:25:43.563 --> 00:25:45.403
I mean, you could,
you could go get the source code and

501
00:25:45.403 --> 00:25:48.170
modify it and compile it yourself,
but most people won't do that.

502
00:25:48.170 --> 00:25:49.920
And so
we're losing a little bit of control.

503
00:25:49.920 --> 00:25:51.235
But in exchange,
you're getting lot of power.

504
00:25:51.235 --> 00:25:54.787
Your system boots faster,
systemd is a little more efficient,

505
00:25:54.787 --> 00:25:57.540
especially on memory consumption.

506
00:25:57.540 --> 00:26:01.480
So it's a trade off, and so far,

507
00:26:01.480 --> 00:26:04.420
all the major distros have agreed,
it's the way to go.

508
00:26:04.420 --> 00:26:08.850
So very powerful software,
it is the heart and soul of your system,

509
00:26:08.850 --> 00:26:09.772
after the Linux kernel, right?

510
00:26:09.772 --> 00:26:11.921
The Linux kernel,
that's the most important part, but

511
00:26:11.921 --> 00:26:13.710
then what does Linux kernel do?

512
00:26:13.710 --> 00:26:16.750
It fires up systemd, and
then systemd does the rest of the work.

513
00:26:16.750 --> 00:26:20.043
So it is really the workhorse that's
keeping your system running and

514
00:26:20.043 --> 00:26:22.720
doing its job after the kernel
has turned over control.

515
00:26:22.720 --> 00:26:23.888
So really powerful stuff,

516
00:26:23.888 --> 00:26:27.048
definitely something you want to be
comfortable with and familiar with.

517
00:26:27.048 --> 00:26:31.074
And fortunately, it's not so
hard using systemctl.

518
00:26:31.074 --> 00:26:33.930
>> And it sounds like systemd
can make our lives a lot easier.

519
00:26:33.930 --> 00:26:36.290
So thanks a lot, Don, great information.

520
00:26:36.290 --> 00:26:38.140
Anything else you'd like to add?

521
00:26:38.140 --> 00:26:41.190
>> The only thing I
didn't mention is systemd

522
00:26:41.190 --> 00:26:43.615
actually has some neat troubleshooting
tools that are a part of it.

523
00:26:43.615 --> 00:26:48.205
So if something ever goes wrong with the
older style like init, you have to go and

524
00:26:48.205 --> 00:26:50.355
dig through scripts and try and
find where the error is.

525
00:26:50.355 --> 00:26:52.445
With systemd, you can actually
do some fun stuff with it.

526
00:26:52.445 --> 00:26:58.445
So there's a command, let me show you
guys real quick, systemd -analyze.

527
00:26:58.445 --> 00:27:01.215
If you run that, it'll actually
take a look at your boot time, and

528
00:27:01.215 --> 00:27:03.346
it'll say how long did it
take your system to boot.

529
00:27:03.346 --> 00:27:06.215
And it'll show you that, because
systemd was the first thing to run, so

530
00:27:06.215 --> 00:27:08.220
it knows how long everything took to boot.

531
00:27:08.220 --> 00:27:11.867
It's showing how long the kernel took to
do its job, user space, and init, and

532
00:27:11.867 --> 00:27:13.680
it gives you all that laid out.

533
00:27:13.680 --> 00:27:18.263
And my favorite command is
systemd -analyze blame [LAUGH].

534
00:27:18.263 --> 00:27:22.680
And that's saying if your
boot took a long time, why?

535
00:27:22.680 --> 00:27:24.035
Who was it that took the longest time?

536
00:27:24.035 --> 00:27:31.090
And it'll look, and it'll show you each
unit ordered by how long they took.

537
00:27:31.090 --> 00:27:34.780
And so I can see the network
manager was my biggest bottleneck.

538
00:27:34.780 --> 00:27:36.850
It added five and
half seconds to my boot time.

539
00:27:36.850 --> 00:27:38.070
>> Five seconds.

540
00:27:38.070 --> 00:27:41.020
>> And so if that's a problem,
I might not wanna use the network manager.

541
00:27:41.020 --> 00:27:44.390
I don't need it, I could use scripts
to control my network interfaces, so

542
00:27:44.390 --> 00:27:45.240
I could get rid of it.

543
00:27:45.240 --> 00:27:47.900
Now I just shaved five and
a half seconds off my boot time, right?

544
00:27:47.900 --> 00:27:51.957
Or, I'm probably okay with that,
cuz it's five seconds, whatever, right?

545
00:27:51.957 --> 00:27:54.314
>> [LAUGH]
>> So there's tools like that,

546
00:27:54.314 --> 00:27:58.080
it can actually scan your config files
to look for errors and stuff in there.

547
00:27:58.080 --> 00:27:59.970
It can do a lot of really neat things.

548
00:27:59.970 --> 00:28:01.610
Take some time, dive into the technology,

549
00:28:01.610 --> 00:28:03.530
you'll find that systemd's
pretty rewarding.

550
00:28:03.530 --> 00:28:07.700
>> Great information on systemd,
becoming a Linux server administrator.

551
00:28:07.700 --> 00:28:10.460
There's a lot of videos in this series.

552
00:28:10.460 --> 00:28:14.170
You wanna make sure you watch every single
one of them, you'll be very glad you did.

553
00:28:14.170 --> 00:28:17.440
Great job Don, and
thank you for watching ITProTV.

554
00:28:17.440 --> 00:28:19.579
Remember, a good IT pro
is always learning.

555
00:28:19.579 --> 00:28:20.850
I'm Zach Memos.

556
00:28:20.850 --> 00:28:21.700
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

557
00:28:21.700 --> 00:28:23.968
>> And we will see you soon.

558
00:28:23.968 --> 00:28:29.861
[MUSIC]

559
00:28:29.861 --> 00:28:33.508
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss what BIND is, why we would choose BIND over other DNS servers, installing the BIND packages, editing the configuration file, define the listen ports, restrict recursive lookups, verify Configuration files, cleanup permissions, named.servce, and allowing BIND through firewalld.
episodes.title: Installing BIND
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:01.293
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.293 --> 00:00:08.148
I'm your host
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.148 --> 00:00:12.036
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:12.036 --> 00:00:14.607
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:14.607 --> 00:00:16.760
Helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:16.760 --> 00:00:18.060
I'm your host Zach Memos.

7
00:00:18.060 --> 00:00:21.872
As we continue on with becoming
a Linux server administrator, and

8
00:00:21.872 --> 00:00:24.740
in this episode we're
gonna be installing BIND.

9
00:00:24.740 --> 00:00:28.487
Now, the person bringing us all
the information we need is our ITPro and

10
00:00:28.487 --> 00:00:31.122
resident nice guy,
Don Pezet, right over here.

11
00:00:31.122 --> 00:00:32.590
[LAUGH] Good morning Don.

12
00:00:32.590 --> 00:00:33.465
>> Good morning Zack, and

13
00:00:33.465 --> 00:00:36.241
yep, we are continuing our adventure
through being a Linux server admin.

14
00:00:36.241 --> 00:00:39.234
And we're gonna be kicking off here
with a really important service, and

15
00:00:39.234 --> 00:00:40.156
that's DNS, right?

16
00:00:40.156 --> 00:00:42.250
DNS, the Domain Naming System.

17
00:00:42.250 --> 00:00:46.650
It's what we use to resolve names to
IPs and IPs to names, pretty critical.

18
00:00:46.650 --> 00:00:48.630
And so when you're standing up
servers in your environment,

19
00:00:48.630 --> 00:00:50.690
the odds are you've got
a DNS server somewhere.

20
00:00:50.690 --> 00:00:54.700
So in this episode, we're gonna
see how to do that by using BIND

21
00:00:54.700 --> 00:00:58.010
running on top of a Linux distro,
which is a really common scenario.

22
00:00:58.010 --> 00:00:59.851
And definitely one that you'll
encounter out in the real world.

23
00:00:59.851 --> 00:01:02.320
So that's what we're gonna see
right here in this episode.

24
00:01:02.320 --> 00:01:06.340
>> Now, Don why are we picking
BIND over other DNS servers?

25
00:01:06.340 --> 00:01:07.246
>> All right, a good question, right?

26
00:01:07.246 --> 00:01:09.520
Cuz there are several other DNS
servers that are out there.

27
00:01:09.520 --> 00:01:11.070
BIND just happens to be one of them.

28
00:01:11.070 --> 00:01:12.680
Well, I shouldn't say
just happens to be one.

29
00:01:12.680 --> 00:01:15.058
It happens to be the original, right?

30
00:01:15.058 --> 00:01:16.400
>> Bum bum bum.
>> So, BIND stands for

31
00:01:16.400 --> 00:01:18.970
the Berkeley Internet Naming Domain.

32
00:01:18.970 --> 00:01:22.850
And it was developed at the University of
California at Berkeley as part of BSD way,

33
00:01:22.850 --> 00:01:24.340
way back in the day.

34
00:01:24.340 --> 00:01:27.590
And it's been used for
name resolution for a long, long time.

35
00:01:27.590 --> 00:01:30.760
In fact,
all the other DNS servers out there

36
00:01:30.760 --> 00:01:33.410
work to maintain capability with BIND.

37
00:01:33.410 --> 00:01:35.328
So if you learn Bind and
know how it works, and

38
00:01:35.328 --> 00:01:36.753
understand all the ins and outs.

39
00:01:36.753 --> 00:01:39.517
Then you actually know how to do this
stuff with the other DNS servers that

40
00:01:39.517 --> 00:01:40.255
are out there too.

41
00:01:40.255 --> 00:01:42.420
You're really just swapping out
binaries for the most part.

42
00:01:42.420 --> 00:01:44.280
So you can definitely look at others, and

43
00:01:44.280 --> 00:01:47.260
we've actually got a whole series
here on ITPro.TV just on DNS servers.

44
00:01:47.260 --> 00:01:48.800
You're welcome to go and check it out.

45
00:01:48.800 --> 00:01:51.660
But as far as this one,
I wanted to stick with the most common.

46
00:01:51.660 --> 00:01:54.360
And the most common DNS server is BIND.

47
00:01:54.360 --> 00:01:58.040
And you'll find that it's really easy for
us to get it installed, get it configured.

48
00:01:58.040 --> 00:02:00.160
And have a DNS server up and
running before we know it.

49
00:02:00.160 --> 00:02:01.570
>> So, it makes sense then.

50
00:02:01.570 --> 00:02:02.894
How do we get it installed?

51
00:02:02.894 --> 00:02:04.390
I wanna see this.

52
00:02:04.390 --> 00:02:08.560
>> All right, well, on a lot of distros
you'll find where it's already installed.

53
00:02:08.560 --> 00:02:11.100
You don't even have to install it,
it's already there for you.

54
00:02:11.100 --> 00:02:15.653
But on some it isn't, so let's act on
the assumption that it's not installed.

55
00:02:15.653 --> 00:02:18.088
And you might ask yourself,
if I'm not doing a DNS server,

56
00:02:18.088 --> 00:02:19.960
why would BIND already be installed?

57
00:02:19.960 --> 00:02:22.427
Some distros actually use it for
an internal name lookups as well, so

58
00:02:22.427 --> 00:02:23.499
that's why it might have it.

59
00:02:23.499 --> 00:02:25.496
But on ours, who knows, right?

60
00:02:25.496 --> 00:02:28.849
So I'm on a Red Hat Enterprise Linux
7.3 machine.

61
00:02:28.849 --> 00:02:33.177
And so I'm gonna take this server and
I'm gonna install BIND, right?

62
00:02:33.177 --> 00:02:37.625
So, one thing that I've done is I'm
logged in as my user account, D.Pezet.

63
00:02:37.625 --> 00:02:40.173
But I'm gonna do a lot of stuff
that you need to be root for,

64
00:02:40.173 --> 00:02:41.798
that you need elevated privileges.

65
00:02:41.798 --> 00:02:45.908
So I'm gonna do a sudo-s, just to switch
to a root shell while I work on this.

66
00:02:45.908 --> 00:02:49.003
If you don't do that you'll just have
to sudo every command that we run in

67
00:02:49.003 --> 00:02:49.679
this episode.

68
00:02:49.679 --> 00:02:50.640
>> And that can be tiring.

69
00:02:50.640 --> 00:02:51.600
>> So yeah, it gets old.

70
00:02:51.600 --> 00:02:55.260
So, I'm gonna come in here and
just do a quick yum install.

71
00:02:55.260 --> 00:02:59.190
If I was on Debian or
Ubuntu I'd be saying, apt-install.

72
00:02:59.190 --> 00:03:02.143
If I was on Fedora I would
be doing dnf-install, right.

73
00:03:02.143 --> 00:03:03.424
So subtle difference there.

74
00:03:03.424 --> 00:03:05.620
But I'm gonna do yum install BIND.

75
00:03:05.620 --> 00:03:08.310
And technically that's all I need.

76
00:03:08.310 --> 00:03:11.110
If I install that,
thats gonna install the BIND DNS server.

77
00:03:11.110 --> 00:03:17.050
But its a good idea to add one extra
little package here called bind utils.

78
00:03:17.050 --> 00:03:18.460
Technically I dont need this.

79
00:03:18.460 --> 00:03:21.340
Its a collection of command line
utilities that help me to work with bind.

80
00:03:21.340 --> 00:03:24.270
I could already have
those on my work station.

81
00:03:24.270 --> 00:03:25.610
So I don`t need to have
them on the server,

82
00:03:25.610 --> 00:03:27.180
I just need them on a work station.

83
00:03:27.180 --> 00:03:29.450
But here Im going to install
them both on the same machine.

84
00:03:29.450 --> 00:03:30.430
It doesn't hurt.

85
00:03:30.430 --> 00:03:33.050
Some people don't like to increase their
security footprint, so they wanna keep

86
00:03:33.050 --> 00:03:36.650
the tools off the server, you can
certainly do that when you install both.

87
00:03:36.650 --> 00:03:39.510
All right, and then install should
happen pretty quick and I might find,

88
00:03:39.510 --> 00:03:42.130
I actually don't know here, but I might
find that they're already installed.

89
00:03:42.130 --> 00:03:45.260
And in my case, actually they are, so it's
gonna go ahead and get those installed.

90
00:03:45.260 --> 00:03:46.160
And get them put in place.

91
00:03:46.160 --> 00:03:48.170
Now bind is not very big.

92
00:03:48.170 --> 00:03:50.510
You'll see 7.3 megabytes on the disk.

93
00:03:50.510 --> 00:03:51.490
It's very small.

94
00:03:51.490 --> 00:03:52.980
Because this was written a long time ago.

95
00:03:52.980 --> 00:03:57.020
It's very simple at what it does,
but it's very powerful.

96
00:03:57.020 --> 00:04:00.610
And it is really one of the most
common DNS servers now in the world.

97
00:04:01.890 --> 00:04:06.939
Once that command runs,
it's installed and that was easy, right?

98
00:04:06.939 --> 00:04:09.110
>> [LAUGH] That wasn't very easy,
my goodness.

99
00:04:09.110 --> 00:04:11.100
>> But it's technically
not doing anything, right?

100
00:04:11.100 --> 00:04:13.860
So there's some basic configuration that
we need to do to get in there to tweak

101
00:04:13.860 --> 00:04:15.980
things and
just kind of make it ready to work.

102
00:04:15.980 --> 00:04:19.280
Now, I'm not gonna start BIND just yet.

103
00:04:19.280 --> 00:04:22.010
Usually when we install a service
like this we immediately follow it up

104
00:04:22.010 --> 00:04:25.270
with a system CTL start, whatever, right?

105
00:04:25.270 --> 00:04:27.050
But in this case I'm gonna hold off for
just a moment.

106
00:04:27.050 --> 00:04:30.100
Cuz there's some basic configuration
that we need to work on, right?

107
00:04:30.100 --> 00:04:34.280
Binds primary configuration
is stored in the ETC folder.

108
00:04:34.280 --> 00:04:36.990
And if I'm going into /etc and
poke around in here.

109
00:04:36.990 --> 00:04:40.640
It's a little bit hard to find because
you might jump in here looking to Bs and

110
00:04:40.640 --> 00:04:42.030
looking for BIND.

111
00:04:42.030 --> 00:04:43.070
It's not there.

112
00:04:43.070 --> 00:04:43.960
Well, let me go look for DNS,

113
00:04:43.960 --> 00:04:47.500
let me jump over to the Ds and
it's not there either, right?

114
00:04:47.500 --> 00:04:49.210
So where the heck is this thing?

115
00:04:49.210 --> 00:04:53.630
Well, it's actually called
the naming daemon or named.

116
00:04:53.630 --> 00:04:58.130
So if you look in the n's which
are around here, here we go.

117
00:04:58.130 --> 00:05:00.430
We've got named.conf.

118
00:05:00.430 --> 00:05:02.150
That's the one that I'm looking for.

119
00:05:02.150 --> 00:05:05.240
That's the primary configuration file for
BIND.

120
00:05:05.240 --> 00:05:08.600
So when I want to work with it,
I need to edit /etc/named.conf.

121
00:05:08.600 --> 00:05:13.430
And that's one of those things
that you just have to memorize.

122
00:05:13.430 --> 00:05:15.670
The service itself is
actually called named,

123
00:05:15.670 --> 00:05:17.990
so named.conf is what I'm going for.

124
00:05:19.060 --> 00:05:22.460
And in that file you're
gonna see a lot of stuff.

125
00:05:22.460 --> 00:05:25.020
This file is packed full of
configuration information.

126
00:05:25.020 --> 00:05:29.580
But what I want to focus on,
here is right at the very beginning.

127
00:05:29.580 --> 00:05:33.400
You've got this Options, and
then a listen on port, okay?

128
00:05:33.400 --> 00:05:36.110
See how it says listen on port 53?

129
00:05:36.110 --> 00:05:40.170
Well, DNS uses UDP and
TPC port 53 by default, right?

130
00:05:40.170 --> 00:05:41.460
So it's listening on port 53.

131
00:05:41.460 --> 00:05:44.260
You don't normally want to change that,
but

132
00:05:44.260 --> 00:05:48.300
this IP address is what I wanna change.

133
00:05:48.300 --> 00:05:50.060
The IP address is 127.0.0.1 So

134
00:05:50.060 --> 00:05:55.440
by default this bind server is only
listening on the loop back interface.

135
00:05:55.440 --> 00:05:58.360
So that means on the server
I can run lookups again so

136
00:05:58.360 --> 00:05:59.800
it can get results, right.

137
00:05:59.800 --> 00:06:03.070
But if I was on a client connecting
over the network it wouldn't work.

138
00:06:03.070 --> 00:06:06.100
So I need to change this address,
I need to change it

139
00:06:06.100 --> 00:06:10.810
to match the address of my server,
the address that I wanna be listening on.

140
00:06:10.810 --> 00:06:13.570
And usually you wanna keep
the loop back in there so

141
00:06:13.570 --> 00:06:15.600
that you can do look ups
from the server itself.

142
00:06:15.600 --> 00:06:19.860
And you wanna add any
extra IPs afterwards.

143
00:06:19.860 --> 00:06:24.890
So I'm gonna leave 127.0.0.1; and then
after that I'm gonna add 172.16.0.100,

144
00:06:24.890 --> 00:06:27.890
that's the IP address of this server.

145
00:06:27.890 --> 00:06:32.200
if I had more than one network
interface I could just continue add.

146
00:06:32.200 --> 00:06:34.810
Do another semicolon,
add the next address and so on.

147
00:06:34.810 --> 00:06:38.110
You're adding the IP address
that's attached to the interface.

148
00:06:38.110 --> 00:06:41.400
So now BIND is listening on the loopback

149
00:06:41.400 --> 00:06:44.030
as well as listening on
my network interface.

150
00:06:44.030 --> 00:06:47.180
And now the clients on my network will
be able to reach out to this server and

151
00:06:47.180 --> 00:06:48.500
ask it and say.

152
00:06:48.500 --> 00:06:53.100
Hey I have this name can you tell me the
IP and my server will figure it out and

153
00:06:53.100 --> 00:06:54.220
give them an answer.

154
00:06:54.220 --> 00:06:56.060
So that's a key thing to get configured.

155
00:06:56.060 --> 00:06:57.710
And a lot of people skip that step.

156
00:06:57.710 --> 00:06:59.170
And then can't figure out
why BIND doesn't work.

157
00:06:59.170 --> 00:07:01.060
It works fine from the server,
it's not working for

158
00:07:01.060 --> 00:07:02.910
my client, must be a firewall issue.

159
00:07:02.910 --> 00:07:05.680
And it's not a firewall issue,
it's just DNS or

160
00:07:05.680 --> 00:07:08.610
bind doesn't know to listen on that
interface until we plug this in.

161
00:07:08.610 --> 00:07:11.850
So, that's one of the most important
things that we need to configure in here.

162
00:07:11.850 --> 00:07:16.050
We get that set, and
now we're in pretty good shape.
