the group at the same time.

393
00:18:23.870 --> 00:18:29.064
So I could've said I wanna change
the owner, and I wanna do root:named.

394
00:18:29.064 --> 00:18:33.330
I wanna set the user to root,
and the group to named.

395
00:18:33.330 --> 00:18:38.250
And then specify /var/named,

396
00:18:38.250 --> 00:18:41.065
like that, okay?

397
00:18:41.065 --> 00:18:47.208
Now I am gonna do that for
/etc/named.conf, okay?

398
00:18:47.208 --> 00:18:50.055
If I copied that from another server,
then those might be set wrong, so

399
00:18:50.055 --> 00:18:51.146
I'm just gonna run that and

400
00:18:51.146 --> 00:18:54.340
make sure that the permissions are set
correctly on the configuration file.

401
00:18:54.340 --> 00:18:56.360
Bind needs to be able to read
that configuration file.

402
00:18:56.360 --> 00:18:58.110
It should be right on your system already,
but

403
00:18:58.110 --> 00:19:00.700
it's just something to double check and
make sure that it's there.

404
00:19:00.700 --> 00:19:04.610
More importantly, though,
if you're running SE Linux.

405
00:19:04.610 --> 00:19:10.420
In SE Linux, Security Enhanced Linux, a
service is restricted so that it can only

406
00:19:10.420 --> 00:19:15.800
access certain folders and if you're doing
a clean install like I am, that's fine.

407
00:19:15.800 --> 00:19:20.530
But if you're bringing this over from
another system it usually breaks SE Linux.

408
00:19:20.530 --> 00:19:24.290
And so we just need to kind of reset
the SE Linux context for these folders.

409
00:19:24.290 --> 00:19:27.310
And there's two commands we can use for
that which are not too bad.

410
00:19:27.310 --> 00:19:31.420
I'll say restorecon, right,
I'm restoring the context.

411
00:19:31.420 --> 00:19:36.320
And I'll do -rv, -r makes it recursive so
I'll hit subfolders as well.

412
00:19:36.320 --> 00:19:39.980
And v is verbose so I'll get extra output
on the screen if there's any errors.

413
00:19:39.980 --> 00:19:43.242
And I'm gonna hit /var/named.

414
00:19:43.242 --> 00:19:48.505
So I'm gonna make sure that that
folder has the right SE Linux context,

415
00:19:48.505 --> 00:19:52.820
and then I'll do the same thing for
/etc/named.conf.

416
00:19:52.820 --> 00:19:56.009
Okay, now hopefully you don't have to do
these commands on a clean installation.

417
00:19:56.009 --> 00:19:58.658
But realistically in the real world,
you've usually

418
00:19:58.658 --> 00:20:02.057
got one DNS server set up already and
you're setting up secondaries or

419
00:20:02.057 --> 00:20:05.860
you're moving to a new system and
you're copying your config files over.

420
00:20:05.860 --> 00:20:08.360
And that's why I've gotten into
the habit of doing these commands even

421
00:20:08.360 --> 00:20:09.580
though they're not always necessary.

422
00:20:09.580 --> 00:20:12.360
This is just a way to make
sure that we're protected.

423
00:20:12.360 --> 00:20:17.680
Okay, now if I was having a problem,
I wouldn't have been able to start bind.

424
00:20:17.680 --> 00:20:18.890
Now, I should be able to start it, right?

425
00:20:18.890 --> 00:20:22.800
So, I should be able to
fire in system CTL start.

426
00:20:22.800 --> 00:20:25.680
Well, actually before I start,
I need to do an enable, right?

427
00:20:25.680 --> 00:20:28.540
I need to enable the bind service so
that system d will recognize it.

428
00:20:28.540 --> 00:20:33.548
So I'm going to say system CTL
enable named.service, right?

429
00:20:33.548 --> 00:20:37.800
Not bind.service, even if though
bind is what we're actually running,

430
00:20:37.800 --> 00:20:38.660
named is what it's called.

431
00:20:38.660 --> 00:20:43.470
So I'm gonna enable it, and
then I'm going to start it.

432
00:20:43.470 --> 00:20:48.160
And so when I start that, if I get
an error here, I know I've got a problem.

433
00:20:48.160 --> 00:20:51.641
But because we checked all our
permissions, we used the named check

434
00:20:51.641 --> 00:20:55.258
config, we knew our config was clean,
it shouldn't get any errors.

435
00:20:55.258 --> 00:20:58.790
They should start right up which mine did,
and it looks like we're good.

436
00:20:58.790 --> 00:21:01.220
The only thing I haven't
done is the firewall, right?

437
00:21:01.220 --> 00:21:05.240
I am running firewall d,
because Red Hat 7 runs it by default.

438
00:21:05.240 --> 00:21:07.700
So I need to open up some
holes in the firewall.

439
00:21:07.700 --> 00:21:12.520
I put that ACL in on bind to allow
clients to be able to connect in, but if

440
00:21:12.520 --> 00:21:16.240
the firewall is blocking them then they'll
never even get to bind to hit that ACL.

441
00:21:16.240 --> 00:21:17.940
So I need to issue a couple
of extra commands.

442
00:21:17.940 --> 00:21:20.679
I'm gonna say

443
00:21:20.679 --> 00:21:28.901
firewall-cmd--add-service=dns.

444
00:21:28.901 --> 00:21:31.640
Now, this is assuming that
I've only got one zone.

445
00:21:31.640 --> 00:21:33.870
If you have more than one
zone on your DNS server,

446
00:21:33.870 --> 00:21:38.280
maybe you have a zone that faces the
Internet and a zone that faces the inside.

447
00:21:38.280 --> 00:21:41.845
Then you might need to add
--zone equals public, or

448
00:21:41.845 --> 00:21:44.680
--zone equals private,
whatever the zone name is.

449
00:21:44.680 --> 00:21:47.890
But for me, I've just got the one zone,
the default zone.

450
00:21:47.890 --> 00:21:51.350
So I'm gonna add DNS to it,
and that's gonna open that up.

451
00:21:51.350 --> 00:21:55.330
Remember with firewall CMD though,
those commands don't get saved to disk,

452
00:21:55.330 --> 00:21:57.360
that's just modifying
the config in memory.

453
00:21:57.360 --> 00:22:03.340
So I need to run it a second time and
add the --permanent to it.

454
00:22:03.340 --> 00:22:08.090
So, let me add that, --permanent.

455
00:22:08.090 --> 00:22:11.290
And don't think that you can just run
permanent because that writes the disk but

456
00:22:11.290 --> 00:22:12.165
it doesn't write to memory, right?

457
00:22:12.165 --> 00:22:13.810
>> Mm-hm.
>> So you really do need to run both.

458
00:22:13.810 --> 00:22:16.680
So that way it takes effect right now and
it writes it to disk so

459
00:22:16.680 --> 00:22:18.620
it'll be there after a reboot.

460
00:22:18.620 --> 00:22:25.758
And you can kind of verify that real
quick, by doing a firewall-cmd--list-all.

461
00:22:25.758 --> 00:22:28.172
And you can take a look at everything
that's been allowed through.

462
00:22:28.172 --> 00:22:33.144
And looking here at my active zone, I can
see that I've got DNS is now added to

463
00:22:33.144 --> 00:22:38.680
the services, to allow that to come in on
my interface, and be able to communicate.

464
00:22:38.680 --> 00:22:40.369
So that should do everything that we need.

465
00:22:42.200 --> 00:22:45.920
If we had already started
named at some point,

466
00:22:45.920 --> 00:22:48.090
we might wanna restart it
just to be on the safe side,

467
00:22:48.090 --> 00:22:51.170
but I haven't changed my configuration
since we started it so I'm fine there.

468
00:22:51.170 --> 00:22:54.215
But otherwise, we should now be up.

469
00:22:54.215 --> 00:22:57.485
Clients should be able to connect over
the network and start to do look ups.

470
00:22:57.485 --> 00:22:59.965
Well, except we don't
really have any zones.

471
00:22:59.965 --> 00:23:02.115
That's gonna kinda be our
next step on that one.

472
00:23:02.115 --> 00:23:03.085
>> Yes, zones are coming.

473
00:23:03.085 --> 00:23:06.680
Becoming a Linux server administrator,
installing bind.

474
00:23:06.680 --> 00:23:07.880
Don, wonderful job.

475
00:23:07.880 --> 00:23:09.320
Now is there any last words?

476
00:23:09.320 --> 00:23:10.821
>> All right,
I mentioned zones a few times.

477
00:23:10.821 --> 00:23:13.417
That is the logical next step we just
don't have enough time in this episode

478
00:23:13.417 --> 00:23:13.960
to get to them.

479
00:23:13.960 --> 00:23:17.210
So stay tuned for the next episode because
we're going to take a look at how to setup

480
00:23:17.210 --> 00:23:19.410
forward lookup zones and
reverse lookup zones,

481
00:23:19.410 --> 00:23:21.700
which is really where you'll
spend most of your time.

482
00:23:21.700 --> 00:23:24.230
Everything we saw on this episode,
you usually just do once.

483
00:23:24.230 --> 00:23:25.740
You do it once, it's setup, right?

484
00:23:25.740 --> 00:23:27.026
All the other work-
>> Once and done.

485
00:23:27.026 --> 00:23:28.750
>> -is gonna be done in the zone file.

486
00:23:28.750 --> 00:23:31.130
So stay tuned,
that's coming up in the next episode.

487
00:23:31.130 --> 00:23:32.210
>> Awesome job as usual.

488
00:23:32.210 --> 00:23:34.160
Becoming a Linux server administrator.

489
00:23:34.160 --> 00:23:36.430
There is a lot of video
content in this series,

490
00:23:36.430 --> 00:23:37.890
make sure you watch all the videos.

491
00:23:37.890 --> 00:23:39.660
You'll be very glad you did.

492
00:23:39.660 --> 00:23:41.230
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

493
00:23:41.230 --> 00:23:44.880
Remember, a good ITPro is always learning.

494
00:23:44.880 --> 00:23:45.830
I'm Zach Mendez.

495
00:23:45.830 --> 00:23:46.590
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

496
00:23:46.590 --> 00:23:48.511
>> And we will see you soon.

497
00:23:48.511 --> 00:23:54.397
[MUSIC]

498
00:23:54.397 --> 00:23:57.926
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: Don and Zach explain getting started with Forward Lookup Zones, creating a Zone File, creating Core Records, what SOA is, Name Servers (NS), adding the Zone to BIND, Verify Syntax, and Cleanup Permissions.
episodes.title: Configuring Zones and Records
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.515
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.515 --> 00:00:06.546
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.546 --> 00:00:08.528
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.528 --> 00:00:12.093
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.093 --> 00:00:14.365
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing ITPRO.TV,

6
00:00:14.365 --> 00:00:16.170
helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:16.170 --> 00:00:19.590
I'm your host Zach Memos as we
continue on with becoming a Linux

8
00:00:19.590 --> 00:00:20.970
server administrator.

9
00:00:20.970 --> 00:00:23.370
Configuring zones and records.

10
00:00:23.370 --> 00:00:24.630
That's a great topic and

11
00:00:24.630 --> 00:00:28.080
Don Pezet right here, he's going to help
us out with all of that, aren't you Don?

12
00:00:28.080 --> 00:00:30.780
>> Absolutely, if you are watching all
these episodes in order, in the last

13
00:00:30.780 --> 00:00:34.380
episode we saw how to setup a DNS server
and we brought up the bind service,

14
00:00:34.380 --> 00:00:37.080
which is one of the most common
DNS servers in the world.

15
00:00:37.080 --> 00:00:39.040
But we didn't set up a terribly
effective one, right?

16
00:00:39.040 --> 00:00:44.070
We built what's called a caching DNS
server because it has no local zones.

17
00:00:44.070 --> 00:00:47.930
And so we really need to get local
zones created before we can actually

18
00:00:47.930 --> 00:00:49.260
really put this stuff to work.

19
00:00:49.260 --> 00:00:51.530
So a local zone,
it's gonna take one of two forms, right.

20
00:00:51.530 --> 00:00:54.000
You've got forward lookup zones and
reverse lookup zones.

21
00:00:54.000 --> 00:00:58.410
Forward zones are doing where it converts
a name to an IP address, and our reversal

22
00:00:58.410 --> 00:01:01.610
lookup zone is just the opposite,
converts an IP address to a name.

23
00:01:01.610 --> 00:01:04.500
Well, all that configuration
is stored in files,

24
00:01:04.500 --> 00:01:08.965
files that we need to create from bind
to use to then be able to serve up.

25
00:01:08.965 --> 00:01:13.165
If you don't do that, it's just forwarding
all those requests on to another DNS

26
00:01:13.165 --> 00:01:15.285
server somewhere and caching the result.

27
00:01:15.285 --> 00:01:19.230
So while we did actually set up an
effective DNS server in the last episode.

28
00:01:19.230 --> 00:01:20.340
We really need to go a step further.

29
00:01:20.340 --> 00:01:22.280
And that's what we're doing
right here in this episode,

30
00:01:22.280 --> 00:01:24.240
we're looking at zones and records.

31
00:01:24.240 --> 00:01:27.930
>> So Don, I'm excited, how do we get
started with forward looking zones?

32
00:01:27.930 --> 00:01:30.290
>> All right, let's start with forward
because that is the most common.

33
00:01:30.290 --> 00:01:32.570
In fact most of the representatives
are pretty much optional.

34
00:01:32.570 --> 00:01:34.080
You don't necessarily have to have them.

35
00:01:34.080 --> 00:01:35.850
They can speed up certain operations.

36
00:01:35.850 --> 00:01:38.230
But four lookup zones those
are the ones you're going to want.

37
00:01:38.230 --> 00:01:40.330
And you want to convert names to IP.

38
00:01:40.330 --> 00:01:43.120
I can remember www.google.com.

39
00:01:43.120 --> 00:01:45.335
I can't remember whatever
IP address they have.

40
00:01:45.335 --> 00:01:46.810
Which I don't know [LAUGH].

41
00:01:46.810 --> 00:01:48.940
>> It's long, whatever it is, it's long.

42
00:01:48.940 --> 00:01:50.410
>> And that's what DNS helps us do, right?

43
00:01:50.410 --> 00:01:51.810
It's like the speed
dial in your cellphone.

44
00:01:51.810 --> 00:01:53.530
It helps you not remember phone numbers.

45
00:01:53.530 --> 00:01:55.220
So I need to get that created.

46
00:01:55.220 --> 00:01:57.460
So I've already got my
DNS server stood up.

47
00:01:57.460 --> 00:01:58.600
Now, I just need those zone files.

48
00:01:58.600 --> 00:02:02.370
And I mentioned in the last episode
those zone files are actually

49
00:02:02.370 --> 00:02:05.730
stored in a folder /var/named, okay?

50
00:02:05.730 --> 00:02:08.800
That folder right there and
that's where you'll have your zone files.

51
00:02:08.800 --> 00:02:11.220
Now, I don't have any zone
files cuz I haven't made any.

52
00:02:11.220 --> 00:02:12.270
So I'm gonna need to do that.

53
00:02:12.270 --> 00:02:13.670
I need to get them created.

54
00:02:13.670 --> 00:02:15.420
And put in place right here.

55
00:02:15.420 --> 00:02:17.720
So, step one is to create a file here.

56
00:02:17.720 --> 00:02:19.900
Now, you do need to be root to
mess around in this directory,

57
00:02:19.900 --> 00:02:22.070
or you need to be a member of
the name D group, one or the other.

58
00:02:23.490 --> 00:02:26.150
I am, right now,
I'm logged in as D pazet, but

59
00:02:26.150 --> 00:02:31.430
I did a sudu /S to elevate my privileges,
so I'm effectively running as root here.

60
00:02:31.430 --> 00:02:33.090
And I'm going to create a file in here.

61
00:02:33.090 --> 00:02:37.310
So inside of the /var /name D,
I'm going to create a file for my zone.

62
00:02:37.310 --> 00:02:41.170
Now technically,
you can name the file whatever you want.

63
00:02:41.170 --> 00:02:43.400
The name can be literally anything.

64
00:02:43.400 --> 00:02:45.980
Any extension,
whatever it is that you want.

65
00:02:45.980 --> 00:02:51.920
But normally most of us will name it as
the domain we're planning on serving.

66
00:02:51.920 --> 00:02:55.590
Followed by a .dns extension, but
that's not a hard and fast rule,

67
00:02:55.590 --> 00:02:58.000
it's just what most people do
because it makes life easy.

68
00:02:58.000 --> 00:03:00.810
If you're hosting more than one zone,
you need to tell them apart and

69
00:03:00.810 --> 00:03:03.530
if you gave them nonsensical names,
it's not gonna help you.

70
00:03:03.530 --> 00:03:07.780
Like if I call it Zone 1, and
then I create a Zone 2, what is Zone 1?

71
00:03:07.780 --> 00:03:12.530
So it makes a lot more sense to call
it something like Lab.itpro.tv cuz

72
00:03:12.530 --> 00:03:17.570
that's the zone that I might wanna
host example.com or whatever.

73
00:03:17.570 --> 00:03:21.030
Now I could leave it at that but
I'm gonna add a .DNS to it just so

74
00:03:21.030 --> 00:03:23.010
that I can remember that
this is a DNS zone file.

75
00:03:23.010 --> 00:03:26.070
But again this is just my own personal
preference and what a lot of other

76
00:03:26.070 --> 00:03:28.859
administrators out there do you're
welcome to call it whatever you want.

77
00:03:30.160 --> 00:03:34.220
Now when I edit that file I
get a nice empty file and

78
00:03:34.220 --> 00:03:36.290
there's no hand holding in the DNS world.

79
00:03:36.290 --> 00:03:38.030
You got to know what to put in here and

80
00:03:38.030 --> 00:03:42.910
there's a couple of critical entries that
you have to have in every zone file.

81
00:03:42.910 --> 00:03:44.130
A lot of entries are optional.

82
00:03:44.130 --> 00:03:45.420
You can kinda pick and choose.

83
00:03:45.420 --> 00:03:48.280
But there's a few entries that
we absolutely have to have.

84
00:03:48.280 --> 00:03:49.890
So let's start right there.

85
00:03:49.890 --> 00:03:52.600
The first one is you need what's
called a start of authority.

86
00:03:52.600 --> 00:03:56.850
A start of authority is an entry that
says, this server is responsible for

87
00:03:56.850 --> 00:03:57.530
this domain.

88
00:03:57.530 --> 00:03:58.760
That we're allowed to answer for
the domain.

89
00:03:58.760 --> 00:04:00.410
We don't have to go to somebody else.

90
00:04:00.410 --> 00:04:01.880
We are the authority.

91
00:04:01.880 --> 00:04:06.280
And so whenever you refer to this server,
you can do that or

92
00:04:06.280 --> 00:04:10.260
this domain,
by using an alias which is the at symbol.

93
00:04:10.260 --> 00:04:13.730
The at symbol says this domain,
the domain that I'm working with.

94
00:04:13.730 --> 00:04:18.710
And I can come in and I can tell it
that I want it to be an SOA record.

95
00:04:18.710 --> 00:04:20.340
Now when you create records in the for

96
00:04:20.340 --> 00:04:23.230
lookup zone, the first entry
is who you're referring to.

97
00:04:23.230 --> 00:04:27.740
So it might be a name or
an alias like this with the app.

98
00:04:27.740 --> 00:04:30.030
Then we need to tell it what
kind of record I'm creating.

99
00:04:30.030 --> 00:04:32.960
Now there's actually a number of
different record types out there,

100
00:04:32.960 --> 00:04:37.350
but there's only one that's really in use
on the Internet and that is the IM record.

101
00:04:37.350 --> 00:04:39.150
I'm creating an Internet record.

102
00:04:39.150 --> 00:04:41.990
But if you ever wanna walk
down the history lane of DNS

103
00:04:41.990 --> 00:04:45.040
there's records like the Chaos records and
a few others.

104
00:04:45.040 --> 00:04:46.920
That were used for
testing and development,

105
00:04:46.920 --> 00:04:48.670
all back in the early days of DNS.

106
00:04:48.670 --> 00:04:50.910
We don't need those any more so
we really just use IN.

107
00:04:52.290 --> 00:04:55.770
Then I need to tell it what
kind of record this is, and

108
00:04:55.770 --> 00:05:00.340
this Is an SOA, or
start of authority record.

109
00:05:00.340 --> 00:05:02.620
Okay, so
I'm creating a start of authority record.

110
00:05:02.620 --> 00:05:06.130
And I'm gonna tell it that
there's a server out there,

111
00:05:06.130 --> 00:05:08.780
usually this one, that is going
to be the start of authority.

112
00:05:08.780 --> 00:05:14.750
And so let's say that this server
was called dns1.lab.itpro.tv, okay?

113
00:05:14.750 --> 00:05:17.980
So I'm gonna be entering
dns1.lab.itpro.tv,

114
00:05:17.980 --> 00:05:20.520
right here is the start of authority.

115
00:05:20.520 --> 00:05:23.300
And there's an interesting
thing I have to do here.

116
00:05:23.300 --> 00:05:28.300
When you write domain names inside a bind,
you have to include a trailing at the end.

117
00:05:28.300 --> 00:05:29.360
Now, most of us don't do that, right?

118

00:02:14.395 --> 00:02:16.155
>> And not a bad car either.

00:02:16.155 --> 00:02:19.335
>> [LAUGH] Yeah it's kind of
along the same lines there.

00:02:19.335 --> 00:02:24.705

00:02:24.705 --> 00:02:28.135

don't have to download it from them or

47
00:02:28.135 --> 00:02:30.670
anything, it's typically
right there with your system.

48
00:02:30.670 --> 00:02:35.593
Right, now I'm using a Red Hat
Enterprise Linux 7 server on CentOS,

00:02:35.593 --> 00:02:38.780

00:02:38.780 --> 00:02:40.520
We can use YUM or DNf to install it.

00:02:47.405 --> 00:02:51.160
If I wanna get it installed,
I can just come in and I can say,

sudo yum install dhcp, like that, and
when I do that, it's gonna reach out and

55
00:02:56.196 --> 00:02:59.909

56
00:02:59.909 --> 00:03:02.993
Now there is another package of
available called dhcp-client and

58
00:03:05.370 --> 00:03:09.500
That's usually installed by default so

59
00:03:09.500 --> 00:03:12.160
what I'm doing is setting
myself up to be a server.

60
00:03:12.160 --> 00:03:17.152
So the package that's just called DHCP,
that's the server and it looks like

61
00:03:17.152 --> 00:03:20.955
there're gonna be updates for some of my
dependencies and see how I got dhc-client

62
00:03:20.955 --> 00:03:24.930
or dh-client, dhcp-common, dhcp-libs,
those are all being updated as well.

63
00:03:24.930 --> 00:03:28.330
So I'll go ahead and let those install and

64
00:03:28.330 --> 00:03:32.530

65
00:03:32.530 --> 00:03:34.160
I can spin it up if I want.

00:03:37.328 --> 00:03:39.458

69
00:03:43.262 --> 00:03:45.961
DHCP does not have a good
default configuration,

00:03:45.961 --> 00:03:49.220
it doesn't know what IP
addresses to hand out, right?

71
00:03:49.220 --> 00:03:53.020
So if I try and jump in and immediately
start it, a lot of times you get errors.

72
00:03:53.020 --> 00:03:56.080
Let's see if I get errors on this one.

A lot of times you get errors because
there's this lease database that needs to

00:04:19.337 --> 00:04:23.363
The service is called DHCP, right,

00:04:23.363 --> 00:04:24.423

83
00:04:24.423 --> 00:04:25.003
>> Right.

84
00:04:25.003 --> 00:04:29.420
>> System CTL enabled DHCP Whoops,
D.service.

85
00:04:29.420 --> 00:04:32.600
So it'll get that started up and
then I'll try and actually start it.

86
00:04:32.600 --> 00:04:36.430
Now, I may pull an error here

87
00:04:36.430 --> 00:04:37.370
There, perfect.

00:04:37.370 --> 00:04:40.210

So it's not as easy as setting up a web

And that's kinda the bare minimum

00:05:03.420 --> 00:05:05.250

00:05:05.250 --> 00:05:08.020

00:05:08.020 --> 00:05:11.947
If you browse around, it's one of

folder you're going to find

00:05:21.927 --> 00:05:26.293
But you can find your DHCP server listed

00:05:26.293 --> 00:05:30.741
So I'm running DHCP 4.2.5 right?

00:05:30.741 --> 00:05:33.399
And so if I, whoops, [LAUGH].

00:05:33.399 --> 00:05:39.155
So if I get into that folder,

00:05:39.155 --> 00:05:43.090

Inside of there,

00:05:55.840 --> 00:05:59.983
Now, that example has a lot of stuff

So you could create your own config
file from scratch with a very

00:06:46.370 --> 00:06:48.320
Okay, so

00:06:48.320 --> 00:06:53.065

00:06:53.065 --> 00:06:55.362

00:06:55.362 --> 00:06:58.070
And you know what let me do a little,

00:07:04.385 --> 00:07:10.409

00:07:15.866 --> 00:07:16.902

00:07:16.902 --> 00:07:20.993

00:07:20.993 --> 00:07:25.710
And I'm gonna get into /etc/dhcp,

00:07:25.710 --> 00:07:29.150
I sudo'd the copy command and so that

00:07:29.150 --> 00:07:30.680

00:07:30.680 --> 00:07:34.761

00:07:34.761 --> 00:07:36.688

00:07:36.688 --> 00:07:41.482

00:07:41.482 --> 00:07:43.670

will use if you don't include them.

162
00:08:26.860 --> 00:08:30.870

designed as kind of a learning file.

00:08:30.870 --> 00:08:32.425

00:08:32.425 --> 00:08:36.170

165
00:08:36.170 --> 00:08:39.370
A subnet to tell it what

00:13:40.780 --> 00:13:43.390

00:13:43.390 --> 00:13:46.060

00:13:46.060 --> 00:13:48.660

287
00:13:48.660 --> 00:13:52.960
So it's faster, it's a smaller window, but
you're still kicking people out, okay?

288
00:13:52.960 --> 00:13:54.310
If you don't wanna kick people out though,

289
00:13:54.310 --> 00:13:59.550

another utility called apachectl.

290
00:13:59.550 --> 00:14:02.650
Apache's CTL just for
managing the web server.

291
00:14:02.650 --> 00:14:05.560
And you could say Apache CTL, graceful.

292
00:14:05.560 --> 00:14:06.980
And this one is really neat.

293
00:14:06.980 --> 00:14:10.920
If anyone's got an open session,
it lets them finish that session and

294
00:14:10.920 --> 00:14:13.240
then it restarts as soon as it can.

295
00:14:13.240 --> 00:14:17.170
And so this way will not interrupt
the users on your website.

296
00:14:17.170 --> 00:14:20.110
Now there is still gonna be a brief
moment while the system's restarting but

297
00:14:20.110 --> 00:14:22.200
if somebody tries to connect
while it's restarting.

298
00:14:22.200 --> 00:14:24.570
They're not gonna be very happy, right?

299
00:14:24.570 --> 00:14:25.930
But it's very brief.

300
00:14:25.930 --> 00:14:28.220
And so
this is really the best way to restart it.

301
00:14:28.220 --> 00:14:30.480
It reloads the configuration,
and gets things going.

302
00:14:30.480 --> 00:14:34.010

through like I'm gonna be the rest of

00:14:34.010 --> 00:14:34.940

00:14:34.940 --> 00:14:37.130

00:14:37.130 --> 00:14:40.380

00:14:40.380 --> 00:14:43.250

00:14:43.250 --> 00:14:46.500

00:14:52.520 --> 00:14:55.840

00:04:57.350 --> 00:04:59.170

it's not like you lose money.

642
00:31:13.080 --> 00:31:16.900
But do it early, get them renewed,
don't let them lapse.

643
00:31:16.900 --> 00:31:18.480
>> Great advice, Don.

644
00:31:18.480 --> 00:31:20.170
And don't forget the leap year,
by the way.

645
00:31:20.170 --> 00:31:22.000
If you're gonna be a Linux
server administrator,

646
00:31:22.000 --> 00:31:24.660
there's a whole bunch of
videos in this series.

647
00:31:24.660 --> 00:31:26.660
Make sure you watch every
single one of them.

648
00:31:26.660 --> 00:31:28.189
You'll be very glad that you did.

649
00:31:28.189 --> 00:31:30.412
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

650
00:31:30.412 --> 00:31:33.500
Remember a good IT Pro is always learning.

651
00:31:33.500 --> 00:31:34.450
I'm Zach Memos.

652
00:31:34.450 --> 00:31:35.130
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

653
00:31:35.130 --> 00:31:36.540
>> And we will see you soon.

654
00:31:36.540 --> 00:31:43.680
[MUSIC]

655
00:31:43.680 --> 00:31:46.769
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss what MariaDB is, how to install, basic security settings, critical configuration options, getting the server on-line, and adding additional users to the server.
episodes.title: Installing MariaDB
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.360 --> 00:00:01.631
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.631 --> 00:00:02.943
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.943 --> 00:00:06.452
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.452 --> 00:00:08.361
>> [MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.361 --> 00:00:11.988
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.988 --> 00:00:14.130
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing ITProTV.

7
00:00:14.130 --> 00:00:16.560
Helping you learn wherever you go.

8
00:00:16.560 --> 00:00:21.280
I'm your host Zach Memos as we continue on
with becoming a Linux Sever Administrator.

9
00:00:21.280 --> 00:00:23.658
We're going to be installing
MariaDB aren't we?

10
00:00:23.658 --> 00:00:26.960
And Don Pezet is going to tell us
how to do just that, aren't you Don?

11
00:00:26.960 --> 00:00:27.530
>> That's right.

12
00:00:27.530 --> 00:00:29.580
So, in this episode we're going
to be taking a look at MariaDB,

13
00:00:29.580 --> 00:00:32.030
which is a open source,
relational database engine.

14
00:00:32.030 --> 00:00:33.200
It's extremely popular.

15
00:00:33.200 --> 00:00:37.810
If you haven't heard of MariaDB you
might know it by its other name, or

16
00:00:37.810 --> 00:00:40.770
you know, sort of other name, MySQL.

17
00:00:40.770 --> 00:00:43.080
MySQL is a open source,
relational database,

18
00:00:43.080 --> 00:00:45.640
been around a long time,
huge install base out there.

19
00:00:45.640 --> 00:00:48.120
Unfortunately it's
controlled by Oracle and

20
00:00:48.120 --> 00:00:51.670
Oracle made some rule changes that
people are pretty unhappy with.

21
00:00:51.670 --> 00:00:55.680
So they forked it and split it off
into a separate project MariaDB.

22
00:00:55.680 --> 00:00:58.260
>> I like the MariaDB better
than the other name, actually.

23
00:00:58.260 --> 00:01:00.080
>> It rolls off the tongue
>> Yes, it does.

24
00:01:00.080 --> 00:01:03.110
>> Well what's important
to us is that MariaDB and

25
00:01:03.110 --> 00:01:07.010
MySQL are fully compatible with each
other and a majority of the commands and

26
00:01:07.010 --> 00:01:09.440
pretty much everything I'm going
to show you in this episode,

27
00:01:09.440 --> 00:01:14.240
works in either product, so
if you want to do MySQL, you just usually

28
00:01:14.240 --> 00:01:17.920
change anywhere where I say MariaDB
with MySQL, and you get that result.

29
00:01:17.920 --> 00:01:20.750
You'll actually where see some
of the commands that we run

30
00:01:20.750 --> 00:01:24.680
in MariaDB still say MySQL for
full feature compatibility.

31
00:01:24.680 --> 00:01:28.730
So, this episode really could
be titled installing MariaDB or

32
00:01:28.730 --> 00:01:32.450
MySQL because we're kind of
gonna see both sides of it.

33
00:01:32.450 --> 00:01:34.650
But that's what we've got lined
up right here in this show.

34
00:01:34.650 --> 00:01:36.270
>> So what software do we need?

35
00:01:36.270 --> 00:01:38.900
>> All right, well, there's two
components that we wanna get installed.

36
00:01:38.900 --> 00:01:40.540
Technically there's only one
component that we need and

37
00:01:40.540 --> 00:01:42.480
that's the MariaDB server, right.

38
00:01:42.480 --> 00:01:44.560
The actual server itself we can install.

39
00:01:44.560 --> 00:01:46.900
But it's kind of hard to work with
it if you don't have the client.

40
00:01:46.900 --> 00:01:49.490
So normally when we get it set
up you're gonna install both.

41
00:01:49.490 --> 00:01:53.480
Now a lot of distros actually package the
client as part of their default install,

42
00:01:53.480 --> 00:01:55.440
so you might already have the client.

43
00:01:55.440 --> 00:01:58.520
But most do not package the server, and

44
00:01:58.520 --> 00:02:01.110
the reason is they don't
install it by default.

45
00:02:01.110 --> 00:02:02.690
They have a package, it's not installed.

46
00:02:02.690 --> 00:02:05.990
And that's because the default
install is not secure, and

47
00:02:05.990 --> 00:02:10.020
there's a number of exploits that are out
there that compromise these databases.

48
00:02:10.020 --> 00:02:12.730
So, if we're gonna deploy we'll
need to make sure to secure it and

49
00:02:12.730 --> 00:02:14.210
that's kind of a key component.

50
00:02:14.210 --> 00:02:17.810
So, if we only get this set up,
we just need to install the client and

51
00:02:17.810 --> 00:02:20.920
the server so I'm here on
a Red Hat Enterprise Linux box.

52
00:02:20.920 --> 00:02:24.570
So these are gonna be the steps for
Red Hat and Centos for

53
00:02:24.570 --> 00:02:27.768
Fedora, anywhere I use YUM,
you would just change to DNF.

54
00:02:27.768 --> 00:02:31.210
And for Devian or Ubuntu,
anywhere I use YUM,

55
00:02:31.210 --> 00:02:34.540
you would just do APT,
like APT install instead of YUM install.

56
00:02:34.540 --> 00:02:37.690
And the rest of the steps are all
the same after the installer.

57
00:02:37.690 --> 00:02:39.190
That's kind of the nice part of Linux,
is that,

58
00:02:39.190 --> 00:02:40.590
you might have a different installer, but

59
00:02:40.590 --> 00:02:43.270
once they're installed,
all the services kind of run the same.

60
00:02:43.270 --> 00:02:47.340
So I'm gonna do a YUM install and
I guess before I do this,

61
00:02:47.340 --> 00:02:50.240
let me just point out that
I am at a elevated prompt.

62
00:02:50.240 --> 00:02:54.950
So I logged in as regular user but
I did a sudu-s to get to a root shell.

63
00:02:54.950 --> 00:02:57.740
Every command we're about to run
needs to be done as a root user

64
00:02:57.740 --> 00:02:59.000
until the day this is up and running.

65
00:02:59.000 --> 00:03:04.390
And then I could switch off to a regular
user if I wanted, but you can run MariaDB

66
00:03:04.390 --> 00:03:07.690
as a user application but
then it's tied to your account.

67
00:03:07.690 --> 00:03:11.270
And so you gotta do things to keep
it running even if you log out

68
00:03:11.270 --> 00:03:15.410
verses as a root user you can have it
running as a service all the time.

69
00:03:15.410 --> 00:03:18.240
So I'm gonna do a YUM install and
there's two components I want.

70
00:03:18.240 --> 00:03:21.610
There's MariaDB which is the client.

71
00:03:21.610 --> 00:03:25.730
And then there is MariaDB-server,

72
00:03:25.730 --> 00:03:29.652
which you probably picked up
on was the server, right?

73
00:03:29.652 --> 00:03:30.470
>> Hm-mm [LAUGH].

74
00:03:30.470 --> 00:03:32.470
>> You may already have
MariaDB as the client.

75
00:03:32.470 --> 00:03:35.753
If I was doing MySQL it would be MySQL and
then MySQL-server.

76
00:03:35.753 --> 00:03:37.960
And so, basically, I'm going to run this.

77
00:03:37.960 --> 00:03:39.140
And it's going to look, and

78
00:03:39.140 --> 00:03:41.490
it'll probably find that I've
already got the client, and!

79
00:03:41.490 --> 00:03:42.060
I don't!

80
00:03:42.060 --> 00:03:43.270
Actually, I don't have either.

81
00:03:43.270 --> 00:03:44.070
That's interesting.

82
00:03:44.070 --> 00:03:44.570
So [LAUGH].

83
00:03:44.570 --> 00:03:45.940
I thought I'd have it by default.

84
00:03:45.940 --> 00:03:48.050
But either way,
it's going to go ahead and install them.

85
00:03:48.050 --> 00:03:48.620
Really small.

86
00:03:48.620 --> 00:03:51.540
I mean, if you look here, we get about
20 megs of data, which is tiny, so

87
00:03:51.540 --> 00:03:53.510
I'll just go ahead and say yes to that.

88
00:03:53.510 --> 00:03:54.890
It's going to get installed.

89
00:03:54.890 --> 00:03:58.250
And then I've now installed MariaDB,
right?

90
00:03:58.250 --> 00:04:00.380
Shortest episode ever and that's it.

91
00:04:00.380 --> 00:04:01.661
>> That was just too difficult.

92
00:04:01.661 --> 00:04:03.160
>> [LAUGH] There is a little more to it,

93
00:04:03.160 --> 00:04:07.050
but it does have a default
configuration that I can start.

94
00:04:07.050 --> 00:04:09.700
So I can come in here and
I can do a system CTL enable.

95
00:04:09.700 --> 00:04:13.300
Actually I should probably start it first.

96
00:04:13.300 --> 00:04:16.510
Well no I'll do a system
CTL enable MariaDB.

97
00:04:16.510 --> 00:04:18.920
And this is a little weird cuz remember

98
00:04:18.920 --> 00:04:21.892
when I used to package
MariaDB is the client.

99
00:04:21.892 --> 00:04:24.730
And MariaDB-server is the server but

100
00:04:24.730 --> 00:04:28.960
when I do the actual demon
it's called just MariaDB.

101
00:04:28.960 --> 00:04:30.360
That's the server demon.

102
00:04:30.360 --> 00:04:35.020
So I'm gonna say system
CTL enable MariaDB, and

103
00:04:35.020 --> 00:04:37.830
then I'll start it up as well.

104
00:04:37.830 --> 00:04:41.870
And that's gonna start up the database
server with a default configuration.

105
00:04:41.870 --> 00:04:46.200
And the default configuration
is not terribly secure.

106
00:04:46.200 --> 00:04:47.420
For example, it's got a blank password.

107
00:04:47.420 --> 00:04:48.490
That's not a good idea.

108
00:04:48.490 --> 00:04:50.400
So there are some more steps
we'll need to go through.

109
00:04:50.400 --> 00:04:54.070
But as far as getting the database
installed and up and running, that's it,

110
00:04:54.070 --> 00:04:54.630
we're done.

111
00:04:54.630 --> 00:04:57.610
We now have a MariaDB server,
it's up and it's running.

112
00:04:57.610 --> 00:05:00.170
>> So what is the minimum
configuration we need to get started?

113
00:05:00.170 --> 00:05:03.300
>> Well I guess, you could say we've
kinda already done the minimum,

114
00:05:03.300 --> 00:05:04.040
it really isn't, right?

115
00:05:04.040 --> 00:05:06.760
So I would say this is not the minimal
install because it's not secure.

116
00:05:06.760 --> 00:05:07.280
Right.

117
00:05:07.280 --> 00:05:08.590
So we need to take a step further.

118
00:05:08.590 --> 00:05:11.960
And I'm not the only one who knows
the default installer is not secure.

119
00:05:11.960 --> 00:05:12.530
They know it, too.

120
00:05:12.530 --> 00:05:15.880
And they have a script that we can run,
one that's built into the installer that

121
00:05:15.880 --> 00:05:19.330
goes through what is considered the actual
minimal to get this up and running.

122
00:05:19.330 --> 00:05:20.600
So let me show you that.

123
00:05:20.600 --> 00:05:24.110
This script is one of the commands
that still retains the old name.

124
00:05:24.110 --> 00:05:25.820
This came from MySQL.

125
00:05:25.820 --> 00:05:31.643
So if you run MySQL _secure_installation.

126
00:05:31.643 --> 00:05:36.820
This is a script that was
installed in /user/bin.

127
00:05:36.820 --> 00:05:37.790
That's where it's stored.

128
00:05:37.790 --> 00:05:40.040
If you messed with your path you
can do the full path if you want.

129
00:05:40.040 --> 00:05:43.155
But it should be in your path.

130
00:05:43.155 --> 00:05:45.450
[LAUGH] So
we run MySQL_secure_installation.

131
00:05:45.450 --> 00:05:47.402
It's a simple script and
it goes through and

132
00:05:47.402 --> 00:05:51.290
fixes those basic security problems that
we might need to worry about all right.

133
00:05:51.290 --> 00:05:55.750
So if we run this it's gonna ask me
first what's the current root password,

134
00:05:55.750 --> 00:05:58.040
now this is not root for your Linux box,

135
00:05:58.040 --> 00:06:01.990
you have a root user on your Linux
distros, that's not this one.

136
00:06:01.990 --> 00:06:05.330
MySQL MariaDB maintain
their own user database,

137
00:06:05.330 --> 00:06:07.850
users that are internal
to the database server.

138
00:06:07.850 --> 00:06:09.430
And the root user is created by default.

139
00:06:09.430 --> 00:06:11.830
They're one of only a couple
users created by default.

140
00:06:11.830 --> 00:06:15.200
And they have full access to the system,
and this is a critical account.

141
00:06:15.200 --> 00:06:18.020
Well, guess what the current
password is by default?

142
00:06:18.020 --> 00:06:18.920
It's blank, all right?

143
00:06:18.920 --> 00:06:19.990
So it's empty.

144
00:06:19.990 --> 00:06:22.580
And if I just press Enter
it's gonna tell me, okay,

145
00:06:22.580 --> 00:06:25.540
it was empty, do you wanna set a password?

146
00:06:25.540 --> 00:06:26.470
Well heck yeah I do.

147
00:06:26.470 --> 00:06:27.720
>> Yes you do.

148
00:06:27.720 --> 00:06:29.120
>> So I'm gonna say yes to that and

149
00:06:29.120 --> 00:06:32.000
I'm gonna assign a password
to the root user account.

150
00:06:32.000 --> 00:06:36.610
At a minimum you want to assign
a password to your root user account.

151
00:06:36.610 --> 00:06:40.360
You can actually rename the root
user account later on if you want,

152
00:06:40.360 --> 00:06:42.230
but at a minimum we just need
to change that password.

153
00:06:42.230 --> 00:06:42.890
Right.

154
00:06:42.890 --> 00:06:45.800
Then the root user isn't
the only user by default.

155
00:06:45.800 --> 00:06:49.240
There's another user that
represents the anonymous users.

156
00:06:49.240 --> 00:06:50.780
Users that haven't logged in.

157
00:06:50.780 --> 00:06:52.290
And that's enabled by default.

158
00:06:52.290 --> 00:06:54.370
Anonymous users can connect and
read the database.

159
00:06:54.370 --> 00:06:55.710
And maybe that's what you want.

160
00:06:55.710 --> 00:06:56.680
But most of us, it isn't.

161
00:06:56.680 --> 00:07:00.280
And so it offers,
do you wanna remove the anonymous users?

162
00:07:00.280 --> 00:07:01.230
Yes is the default.

163
00:07:01.230 --> 00:07:02.390
I'm gonna go with that.

164
00:07:02.390 --> 00:07:04.090
I wanna remove anonymous users.

165
00:07:04.090 --> 00:07:04.780
All right?

166
00:07:04.780 --> 00:07:08.950
And then,
do I wanna disallow root login remotely?

167
00:07:08.950 --> 00:07:12.350
Now by default, the root user
can connect from anywhere, and

168
00:07:12.350 --> 00:07:15.730
attackers know that the root
user exists by default,

169
00:07:15.730 --> 00:07:18.580
and they know that the root user
has a blank password by default.

170
00:07:18.580 --> 00:07:23.062
So there are worms that crawl the internet
looking for MySQL servers and

171
00:07:23.062 --> 00:07:25.060
MariaDB servers that have
a root user with no password.

172
00:07:25.060 --> 00:07:26.760
They constantly scan and look for that.

173
00:07:26.760 --> 00:07:29.060
So it's a good idea to say, you know what?

174
00:07:29.060 --> 00:07:31.400
I should never be using the root
user on the network anyway.

175
00:07:31.400 --> 00:07:34.080
So let's restrict it, so
that it can only log in locally.

176
00:07:34.080 --> 00:07:37.040
And that's what we're gonna say here,
disallow root login remotely.

177
00:07:37.040 --> 00:07:40.860
So by doing that, now the root user can
only log in when they're on this machine,

178
00:07:40.860 --> 00:07:43.199
in other words, like a service
on this machine that's running.

179
00:07:44.580 --> 00:07:48.130
When you install it,
it does create a test database by default.

180
00:07:48.130 --> 00:07:50.846
Now the test database just
has some sample data in it.

181
00:07:50.846 --> 00:07:54.527
It's there just so you kinda see
the database server's working.

182
00:07:54.527 --> 00:07:57.549
Because it's a known entity,
attackers know it exists, and

183
00:07:57.549 --> 00:07:59.940
they can formulate attacks based on that.

184
00:07:59.940 --> 00:08:02.190
So if this is a production server,
it's a good idea to remove it.

185
00:08:02.190 --> 00:08:05.600
If you're just learning about MySQL or
MariaDB, though, leave it, and

186
00:08:05.600 --> 00:08:08.230
you can mess around with it in C or
you can create your own.

187
00:08:08.230 --> 00:08:10.280
I'm gonna go ahead and leave mine here.

188
00:08:10.280 --> 00:08:12.510
But know that in production,
I always remove this.

189
00:08:12.510 --> 00:08:14.760
I always say yes to get
rid of that database.

190
00:08:15.760 --> 00:08:19.420
All right, then its gonna ask if we
wanna reload the privilege table.

191
00:08:19.420 --> 00:08:20.660
This is really important.

192
00:08:20.660 --> 00:08:24.030
Anytime you modify permissions
in MariaDB or MySQL,

193
00:08:24.030 --> 00:08:25.590
it doesn't take effect immediately.

194
00:08:25.590 --> 00:08:27.386
You have to reload the privilege table.

195
00:08:27.386 --> 00:08:29.290
It's called flushing the permissions.

196
00:08:29.290 --> 00:08:30.660
And if I don't do it,

197
00:08:30.660 --> 00:08:33.270
all the changes I just made don't
take effect until my next restart.

198
00:08:33.270 --> 00:08:34.220
And thats not something I want.

199
00:08:34.220 --> 00:08:36.850
So I wanna say yes to this so
it reloads those privileges.

200
00:08:37.902 --> 00:08:44.220
Now MariaDB is up and running, and
it's at least got basic security on it.

201
00:08:44.220 --> 00:08:48.190
And now I've got a functioning database
server that I can turn over to my DBAs or

202
00:08:48.190 --> 00:08:51.780
whoever it is that's gonna be working on
the system and give them that access.

203
00:08:51.780 --> 00:08:55.700
>> Are there any other critical
configuration options?

204
00:08:55.700 --> 00:08:56.340
>> There's some.
So

205
00:08:56.340 --> 00:08:58.600
it depends on how you
wanna use the server.

206
00:08:58.600 --> 00:09:01.160
By default it's really set up for
local access.

207
00:09:01.160 --> 00:09:04.010
And if you've got a web server, and it's
running right here on this system, and

208
00:09:04.010 --> 00:09:07.290
it's accessing the database,
then it's probably set up well enough for

209
00:09:07.290 --> 00:09:08.670
you to make use of.

210
00:09:08.670 --> 00:09:12.390
But if your web servers are running on a
separate system, and they're reaching out

211
00:09:12.390 --> 00:09:16.300
to the database server here, we're gonna
need to enable some network access.

212
00:09:16.300 --> 00:09:20.580
And the network access takes
a few different sides.

213
00:09:20.580 --> 00:09:22.961
First off, I might need to allow
it through the firewall, right?

214
00:09:22.961 --> 00:09:30.385
So I could always come in and
say like firewall-cmd --add service=mysql.

215
00:09:30.385 --> 00:09:31.990
And that will allow MySQL thru.

216
00:09:31.990 --> 00:09:36.190
MySQL runs on TCP port 33 or 3306.

217
00:09:36.190 --> 00:09:40.260
3306, however you wanna say it.

218
00:09:40.260 --> 00:09:41.290
So 3306 by default.

219
00:09:41.290 --> 00:09:42.770
And so I can add that service in.

220

448
00:20:30.340 --> 00:20:32.460

it's the percent symbol.

449
00:20:32.460 --> 00:20:35.140

450
00:20:35.140 --> 00:20:38.030

user like this, like a developer,

451
00:20:38.030 --> 00:20:41.130

host so they can connect from anywhere.

452
00:20:41.130 --> 00:20:44.700

that, how restrictive you wanna be.

453
00:20:44.700 --> 00:20:48.790
But basically you'll just come in and
you'll say, CREATE USER.

454
00:20:48.790 --> 00:20:50.040
I'm gonna add a user.

455
00:20:50.040 --> 00:20:51.100
I'll create a user for me.

456
00:20:51.100 --> 00:20:53.270
So I'll just do dpezet.

457
00:20:53.270 --> 00:20:59.240
Right, and actually because I'm providing
text values, I need to put a single quote

00:20:59.240 --> 00:21:04.940
mark around them, so I'll do dpezet@ and
then the host they're gonna connect from.

459
00:21:04.940 --> 00:21:07.790
And again, I could do a percent sign if
I wanted it to allow me to connect from

460
00:21:07.790 --> 00:21:10.110
anywhere, or I could say, you know what?

461
00:21:10.110 --> 00:21:11.920
This is just localhost.

462
00:21:11.920 --> 00:21:15.180
I only want you to be able to connect
if you're on the local host, right, or

463
00:21:15.180 --> 00:21:16.250
wherever it is.

464
00:21:16.250 --> 00:21:19.430
And I can run this command more than once
to provide different hosts if I want.

465
00:21:19.430 --> 00:21:21.670
It's up to me to just
specify how I want that.

466
00:21:21.670 --> 00:21:24.130
Right, so I'm gonna add myself just for
local host.

467
00:21:24.130 --> 00:21:26.320
And then this is where it

00:21:26.320 --> 00:21:28.740
We say IDENTIFIED BY.

00:21:29.930 --> 00:21:31.685
So how do we identify the user?

470
00:21:31.685 --> 00:21:33.930
Well, the password is what

00:21:33.930 --> 00:21:35.630
their name combined with a password.

00:21:35.630 --> 00:21:37.560
The name is public,
the password is private.

473
00:21:37.560 --> 00:21:39.710
And so then I need to provide
what that password is.

474
00:21:39.710 --> 00:21:43.299
And again, I'll use the single quote mark
and I'll just give myself a password of

475
00:21:43.299 --> 00:21:46.543
password123, cuz I'm employing
proper security practices today.

476
00:21:46.543 --> 00:21:49.850
>> [LAUGH] Strong,
strong with the force, yeah.

477
00:21:49.850 --> 00:21:54.590
>> All right, so I'm gonna go ahead and
run that, and when it's done, I can rerun

00:21:54.590 --> 00:21:59.350
the select user command and there I
see my entry that dpezet right there.

00:21:59.350 --> 00:22:02.505
I've got access, and notice how my
password is different than the root user?

480
00:22:02.505 --> 00:22:04.970
And that's well,
cuz my password's different.

481
00:22:04.970 --> 00:22:08.000
But that's password123,
it's been hashed, stored right there and

00:22:08.000 --> 00:22:08.800

00:22:08.800 --> 00:22:12.083

approving different

hosts in setting whatever I want

Again, if I wanted to allow

I can just rerun that command and

whoops, inside the single ticks.

00:22:29.800 --> 00:22:32.740

00:22:32.740 --> 00:22:34.540
There we go and it's now got that percent.

00:22:34.540 --> 00:22:37.870
So now I can connect from anywhere,
localHost, or

00:22:37.870 --> 00:22:40.190

IP on my local network cuz the firewall's

00:22:57.173 --> 00:22:58.150

All right, now that I've got a user,

500
00:23:03.490 --> 00:23:05.630

00:23:09.055 --> 00:23:13.430

00:23:13.430 --> 00:23:14.620

00:23:29.460 --> 00:23:30.500

00:23:37.340 --> 00:23:42.218

00:23:42.218 --> 00:23:43.353

User=dpezet.

00:23:48.772 --> 00:23:51.850

00:23:51.850 --> 00:23:54.820

when I run it,

00:23:54.820 --> 00:23:57.850
it's gonna go through that database and

521
00:23:57.850 --> 00:24:02.680

Query OK, 2 rows affected.

522
00:24:02.680 --> 00:24:06.890
I said anywhere the username equals

00:24:06.890 --> 00:24:08.390

00:24:08.390 --> 00:24:11.120
That one command catches both entries.

525
00:24:11.120 --> 00:24:11.910
And so if I go and

00:24:11.910 --> 00:24:16.440

00:24:16.440 --> 00:24:18.160

528
00:24:18.160 --> 00:24:21.580
If you don't specify correctly, you might

00:24:21.580 --> 00:24:24.069

530
00:24:25.690 --> 00:24:29.190

I can start to provide access but this

I need to grant them privileges or

access to a certain set of resources.

And until I do that they're really

That means I have no access,

50
00:02:12.390 --> 00:02:15.455

00:02:15.455 --> 00:02:19.940
it' really important that you tell

52
00:02:19.940 --> 00:02:24.450

53
00:02:24.450 --> 00:02:27.310

00:02:27.310 --> 00:02:29.980

it sounds like you're

>> That's right, yeah, and
technically, I guess you are, right.

58
00:02:36.240 --> 00:02:38.620
You're getting rid of
the cached privileges and

59
00:02:38.620 --> 00:02:40.280

60
00:02:40.280 --> 00:02:43.702

61
00:02:43.702 --> 00:02:46.482
And I'll run that command

00:02:52.300 --> 00:02:53.240
>> Fantastic.

00:02:53.240 --> 00:02:56.239
>> Yep, Sequel servers, I'm sorry,

SQL servers-
>> That's right.

67

[LAUGH]

00:03:01.230 --> 00:03:04.102
>> SQL servers, they cache a lot in

00:03:04.102 --> 00:03:05.034

70
00:03:05.034 --> 00:03:08.183

it makes them run faster but

71
00:03:08.183 --> 00:03:10.504

up changes sometimes.

72
00:03:10.504 --> 00:03:12.770

73
00:03:12.770 --> 00:03:13.552

78
00:03:25.140 --> 00:03:27.100

79

a database, how we read data from a table.

80
00:03:31.050 --> 00:03:34.890
There's the update command,
that's how we change data in the table.

81
00:03:34.890 --> 00:03:39.170
And there's the delete command, that's
how we remove data from the table, okay.

82
00:03:39.170 --> 00:03:43.050
So those three things, select,
update, delete, actually,

83
00:03:43.050 --> 00:03:44.550
there's a fourth one, insert.

84
00:03:44.550 --> 00:03:46.540
Insert is how we add new records, right.

85
00:03:46.540 --> 00:03:48.790
>> Okay.
>> So update changes an existing record,

86
00:03:48.790 --> 00:03:49.970
insert adds a new one.

87
00:03:49.970 --> 00:03:53.030
So those four,
[LAUGH] I have to update myself here.

88
00:03:53.030 --> 00:03:57.590
So select, insert, update, delete, those
are the four permissions that we normally

89
00:03:57.590 --> 00:04:00.050
have to hand out for people in control.

90
00:04:00.050 --> 00:04:06.430
And so what you do is you say GRANT and
then permissions you want to give out.

91
00:04:06.430 --> 00:04:10.180
So I might say SELECT and UPDATE, right.

92
00:04:10.180 --> 00:04:13.680
So I'm gonna give these two permissions or
I could add INSERT and DELETE.

93
00:04:13.680 --> 00:04:15.910
Whatever it is that I wanna grant out.

94
00:04:15.910 --> 00:04:22.990
So I'll do select and update and I'm
gonna grant that ON the Company database.

95
00:04:22.990 --> 00:04:25.450
That's the database that I
added in the last episode.

96
00:04:25.450 --> 00:04:28.060
So I'm gonna grant this
permissions on the database.

97

actually starts by deleting
the database that's already there.

318
00:16:34.800 --> 00:16:36.640
So if you still have
the database it'll delete it.

319
00:16:36.640 --> 00:16:38.370
If you don't, then it doesn't do anything.

320
00:16:38.370 --> 00:16:41.290
And then it rebuilds
the database from that script,

321
00:16:41.290 --> 00:16:43.860
putting everything back
the way that it was.

322
00:16:43.860 --> 00:16:46.020
And getting the database fully restored.

323
00:16:46.020 --> 00:16:48.740
And if you wanna see that,
well, first of all,

324
00:16:48.740 --> 00:16:52.426
let's just assume that I only
have the compressed one, right?

325
00:16:52.426 --> 00:16:54.370
Let me get rid of that there.

326
00:16:54.370 --> 00:16:56.010
Right, so
I've only got the compressed one.

327
00:16:56.010 --> 00:16:58.361
So I'm gonna come in here and just say,

328
00:16:58.361 --> 00:17:01.297
gzip-d to decompress
that company.sql file.

329
00:17:01.297 --> 00:17:03.850
All right, so I'll decompress it.

330
00:17:03.850 --> 00:17:11.148
And now I've got company.sql again,
and from here, I can fire up MySQL.

331
00:17:11.148 --> 00:17:17.400
That's the MySQL client, not MySQL dump,
dump just exports, it doesn't import.

332
00:17:17.400 --> 00:17:21.675
So I'm gonna say MySQL-u root,
I wanna be that root user,

333
00:17:21.675 --> 00:17:23.820
-p to prompt for a password.

334
00:17:23.820 --> 00:17:28.570
And normally, I would just run this,
it would take me into the database, right.

335
00:17:28.570 --> 00:17:32.965
But what I wanna do is I wanna
connect to the company database,

336
00:17:32.965 --> 00:17:34.581
so I'll tell it that.

337
00:17:34.581 --> 00:17:39.694
And then I wanna tell it to restore,
and so I'm going to feed

338
00:17:39.694 --> 00:17:45.640
in that backup that I did that
was called company.sql, right?

339
00:17:45.640 --> 00:17:49.540
And so it's gonna read that file and
run it, and in that file

340
00:17:49.540 --> 00:17:54.157
are all the commands that I need to
execute and get this data restored.

341
00:17:54.157 --> 00:17:57.615
Now, I already have the company database,
that's why I'm specifying it here.

342
00:17:57.615 --> 00:17:59.535
If I didn't,
I would just leave that out, and

343
00:17:59.535 --> 00:18:01.915
it will recreate the company database for
me.

344
00:18:01.915 --> 00:18:06.044
So this was an all new server, I could
just leave that part out, log in and

345
00:18:06.044 --> 00:18:09.039
then it will feed the contents
of that file in there.

346
00:18:09.039 --> 00:18:12.763
But if I've already got it I can
connect right to it and run that.

347
00:18:12.763 --> 00:18:16.225
And that's gonna restore the database and
get put back,

348
00:18:16.225 --> 00:18:18.790
and now all that data is brought back in.

349
00:18:18.790 --> 00:18:21.970
The database is up and
running, and users can go.

350
00:18:21.970 --> 00:18:25.987
On the backup, MySQL dump can be
run while users are in the system.

351
00:18:25.987 --> 00:18:27.290
It can be done online, right?

352
00:18:27.290 --> 00:18:29.040
Users are in there,
they're working, that's great.

353
00:18:29.040 --> 00:18:30.220
You do the dump.

354
00:18:30.220 --> 00:18:31.973
There might be an IO hit, right?

355
00:18:31.973 --> 00:18:34.423
You're doing a lot of disk access
when you dump that database, and

356
00:18:34.423 --> 00:18:36.145
the larger that is,
the longer that happens.

357
00:18:36.145 --> 00:18:37.695
So you do get a performance hit.

358
00:18:37.695 --> 00:18:41.335
But otherwise, users can continue
to work like normal, right?

359
00:18:41.335 --> 00:18:43.555
The restore,
a little bit different, right?

360
00:18:43.555 --> 00:18:46.230
Cuz the database is getting killed and
restored.

361
00:18:46.230 --> 00:18:47.680
Users need to be out of the system.

362
00:18:47.680 --> 00:18:49.669
If they're in there,
they're just gonna get kicked out, and

363
00:18:49.669 --> 00:18:50.950
that means you can get data loss.

364
00:18:50.950 --> 00:18:52.760
So be careful with that.

365
00:18:52.760 --> 00:18:54.580
You might wanna restore
it to a different name.

366
00:18:54.580 --> 00:18:58.110
And if you wanna restore it to a different
name, you can just modify that SQL file.

367
00:18:58.110 --> 00:19:01.718
That's the text bar you can edit it and
change the database name and then they'll

368
00:19:01.718 --> 00:19:05.009
restore all the data to a different
database and then you can pick and chose

369
00:19:05.009 --> 00:19:08.600
the information out of it that you want,
to restore it to your production line.

370
00:19:08.600 --> 00:19:11.509
So you don't have to take users offline,
that's kind of up to you.

371
00:19:11.509 --> 00:19:15.230
This first step is having
the backup in the first place.

372
00:19:15.230 --> 00:19:17.760
So if you're standing up MySQL servers,

373
00:19:17.760 --> 00:19:20.235
you need to be using
MySQLdump to back that up, or

374
00:19:20.235 --> 00:19:25.780
a third party backup solutions out there
that all work well, they just cost money.

375
00:19:25.780 --> 00:19:28.220
MySQLdump is free,
it's built in, it's easy, and

376
00:19:28.220 --> 00:19:31.800
if you combine it with SSH,
you can do encrypted network backups.

377
00:19:31.800 --> 00:19:33.570
You an dump them to any location.

378
00:19:33.570 --> 00:19:36.760
You can write a simple script to
stick the date in the filename, so

379
00:19:36.760 --> 00:19:39.690
now you can kinda maintain
multiple days' worth of backups.

380
00:19:39.690 --> 00:19:41.470
Then it's pretty easy to get going.

381
00:19:41.470 --> 00:19:45.540
If you don't do it, though,
databases are really important.

382
00:19:45.540 --> 00:19:49.110
And the moment something goes wrong in
that database goes off line, it's gonna

383
00:19:49.110 --> 00:19:52.160
be, we have a couple of names for it, but-
>> [LAUGH]

384
00:19:52.160 --> 00:19:53.620
>> It's what I like to call a-

385
00:19:53.620 --> 00:19:55.020
>> Can you say them here?

386
00:19:55.020 --> 00:19:56.780
>> Career changing event.

387
00:19:56.780 --> 00:19:58.200
>> Okay.
>> [LAUGH] That you wanna

388
00:19:58.200 --> 00:19:59.660
make sure you to the back up.

389
00:19:59.660 --> 00:20:00.360
It's so easy to do.

390
00:20:00.360 --> 00:20:01.780
There's really no reason not to have it.

391
00:20:01.780 --> 00:20:05.680
So definitely something they
wanted to put some time into.

392
00:20:05.680 --> 00:20:06.970
Let's see, did I miss anything on that?

393
00:20:06.970 --> 00:20:09.330
I think it was pretty-
>> Pretty comprehensive.

394
00:20:09.330 --> 00:20:09.960
>> Pretty good there.

395
00:20:09.960 --> 00:20:13.330
There's obviously a lot more,
databases are really complex.

396
00:20:13.330 --> 00:20:17.500
Now you might have noticed in part one and
part two we did a lot of stuff here

397
00:20:17.500 --> 00:20:20.720
with standing the server up and creating
the database and creating user accounts.

398
00:20:20.720 --> 00:20:23.310
For most sysadmins,
that's all you have to do.

399
00:20:23.310 --> 00:20:25.500
That's the extent of your job Frank.

00:20:25.500 --> 00:20:29.680
But what if the developers

00:20:29.680 --> 00:20:32.030

That doesn't happen to most sysadmins but

So what I wanna do is I've covered
everything I wanna cover for

404
00:20:37.680 --> 00:20:40.330
just basic like standing
up a database server.

405
00:20:40.330 --> 00:20:42.570
But we're gonna do another episode,

00:20:42.570 --> 00:20:46.610
But this is just a separate episode on

407
00:20:46.610 --> 00:20:47.730
So stay tuned for that one.

408
00:20:47.730 --> 00:20:48.240
I'm just gonna come up.

00:20:50.760 --> 00:20:55.130

00:21:01.460 --> 00:21:03.810

00:21:05.010 --> 00:21:07.410

I think we've seen

Hopefully you guys have nice, stable

a lot of us need to work with more.

36
00:01:40.511 --> 00:01:43.990
And databases are becoming more and
more critical to businesses.

37
00:01:43.990 --> 00:01:45.260
So I think it is important to learn.

38
00:01:45.260 --> 00:01:47.180
So we're just gonna take a look at
that right here in this episode and

39
00:01:47.180 --> 00:01:49.460

40
00:01:49.460 --> 00:01:54.100
>> So Don, what commands are available
when you're working with database data?

41
00:01:54.100 --> 00:01:58.310
>> All right, so when we're communicating
with a relational database we're using

42
00:01:58.310 --> 00:01:59.140
SQL, right.

43
00:01:59.140 --> 00:02:02.234
SQL, the structured query language,
and with SQL you got

44
00:02:02.234 --> 00:02:06.103
a standard set of commands, a collection
of commands you can issue out.

45
00:02:06.103 --> 00:02:10.511
And they're really neat because they work
on anybody who follows the SQL standards.

46
00:02:10.511 --> 00:02:18.000
So they work on MariaDB, MySQL they work
on Oracle, they work on Microsoft SQL.

47
00:02:18.000 --> 00:02:21.722
All these different database platforms
out there, use the same commands.

48
00:02:21.722 --> 00:02:25.236
And we've kind of seen some of them,
already, like the create command,

49
00:02:25.236 --> 00:02:27.090
that I used to create a database.

50
00:02:27.090 --> 00:02:29.942
But, there's a ton of other ones,
that I wanna show you guys.

51
00:02:29.942 --> 00:02:33.750

52
00:02:33.750 --> 00:02:35.990
How do you verify the data's
actually there and readable?

53
00:02:35.990 --> 00:02:38.640
You use the select command to do it,
that's how we verify.

54
00:02:38.640 --> 00:02:39.630
How do you add data?

55
00:02:39.630 --> 00:02:44.000
You use the insert command, insert
lets you add new data to the database.

56
00:02:44.000 --> 00:02:47.962
There's a update command which lets you
change data that's in the database,

57
00:02:47.962 --> 00:02:50.073
and don't feverishly write these down.

58
00:02:50.073 --> 00:02:52.380
I'm gonna show you examples of
all these as the show goes on.

59
00:02:52.380 --> 00:02:54.103
>> There'll be some production
notes too I'm sure.

60
00:02:54.103 --> 00:02:56.908
>> Absolutely and they'll all be
in the show notes as well, but

61
00:02:56.908 --> 00:02:59.060
we're gonna kinda run
through each of those.

62
00:02:59.060 --> 00:03:01.870
There's the delete command for
taking things out, and

63
00:03:01.870 --> 00:03:03.520
then a lot of the commands have modifiers.

64
00:03:03.520 --> 00:03:07.495
So like the select command when I say I'm

65
00:03:07.495 --> 00:03:10.008
command to say where we're
getting the data from,

66
00:03:10.008 --> 00:03:12.183
or the where command, just like criteria.

67
00:03:12.183 --> 00:03:14.291
I might not want every row of a table,

68
00:03:14.291 --> 00:03:17.691
I might just want certain rows

69
00:03:17.691 --> 00:03:21.890
And then you can always organize your data

70
00:03:21.890 --> 00:03:25.124
Those are commands that let us change

71
00:03:25.124 --> 00:03:28.668
These are all part of SQL and

72
00:03:28.668 --> 00:03:31.960

verifying if a server is working,

73
00:03:31.960 --> 00:03:34.140

74

75
00:03:39.350 --> 00:03:43.950
A database server might be online but

76
00:03:43.950 --> 00:03:47.940
it might be responding poorly and we don't

77
00:03:47.940 --> 00:03:51.510
So we're gonna take a look at that SQL
that structured query language and

78
00:03:51.510 --> 00:03:54.669
see how to use it to
interact with that system.

79
00:03:54.669 --> 00:03:56.965
>> So Don I'm pretty exited about all

00:03:56.965 --> 00:03:58.555

>> Some of them yes, most of them are all

00:04:02.595 --> 00:04:06.165
and in the last two episodes we

00:04:06.165 --> 00:04:07.465
at least I don't remember creating one.

84
00:04:07.465 --> 00:04:09.127
So we created a database, and

85
00:04:09.127 --> 00:04:13.594
when you create a database there's not
all that much you can do with a database.

86
00:04:13.594 --> 00:04:16.390
You've really gotta have
the data put into it.

87
00:04:16.390 --> 00:04:22.344
And most of us don't necessarily think
of a database as what it really is,

88
00:04:22.344 --> 00:04:24.850
which is a container, right?

89
00:04:24.850 --> 00:04:27.760
>> Right.
>> Think of a database as backpack.

90
00:04:27.760 --> 00:04:30.990
If I get a backpack,
a brand new one from the store,

91
00:04:30.990 --> 00:04:34.530
it's not really useful while it's empty,
right?

92
00:04:34.530 --> 00:04:37.760
I have this potential to store data,
but otherwise it's useless.

93
00:04:37.760 --> 00:04:40.704
But once I start putting books in there,
now it's useful to me,

94
00:04:40.704 --> 00:04:44.191
now it makes it easier to carry those
books and I get them when I need them, and

95
00:04:44.191 --> 00:04:46.173
now I've got the information in my hands.

96
00:04:46.173 --> 00:04:49.169
So really, if we want to truly
start working with the database,

97
00:04:49.169 --> 00:04:51.835
we've got to get some data in there first.

98
00:04:51.835 --> 00:04:54.972
Now before I show you this,
as we get in creating things,

99
00:04:54.972 --> 00:04:58.882
I wanna make sure everybody's got a good
understanding of how a database works.

100
00:04:58.882 --> 00:05:03.682
I've fired up LibreOffice Calc, here,
which is just a spreadsheet program.

101
00:05:03.682 --> 00:05:08.032
Spreadsheets are actually really,
really simple databases.

102
00:05:08.032 --> 00:05:09.594
And with a spreadsheet,

103
00:05:09.594 --> 00:05:12.631
when we When we look at it we
normally see a table like this.

104
00:05:12.631 --> 00:05:15.094
And you've got rows and
you've got columns.

105
00:05:15.094 --> 00:05:17.816
And each row is an independent entity, and

106
00:05:17.816 --> 00:05:20.923
each column is a characteristic
of that entity.

107
00:05:20.923 --> 00:05:25.331
So when I lay in data into a database
this is kind of what it looks like.

108
00:05:25.331 --> 00:05:28.349
But the functionality a lot of people
don't take advantage of is down here at

109
00:05:28.349 --> 00:05:30.534
the bottom where we can have

then I'll tell it the user
that I'm going to use.

548
00:29:20.790 --> 00:29:24.160
I'm using the root user right now,
I'll tell it to prompt me for a password.

549
00:29:24.160 --> 00:29:27.890
And almost done, I need to tell
it the database that I'm using,

550
00:29:27.890 --> 00:29:29.890
I'm using the company database.

551
00:29:29.890 --> 00:29:32.940
And then finally the file
that I'm gonna load, and

552
00:29:32.940 --> 00:29:36.010
the file I'm gonna load
is in my home directory.

553
00:29:36.010 --> 00:29:40.660
So I'll just say till/employees.csv,
that's the file that I wanna load.

554
00:29:40.660 --> 00:29:44.290
All right, so that is one long command,

555
00:29:45.450 --> 00:29:48.950
and each part is kind of important.

556
00:29:48.950 --> 00:29:52.270
But a lot of it is optional,
if I didn't have a header,

557
00:29:52.270 --> 00:29:54.020
I could have left this part off.

558
00:29:54.020 --> 00:29:57.602
And if I had a tab-separated
values with no quote marks,

559
00:29:57.602 --> 00:30:00.190
I could have left these two parts off.

560
00:30:00.190 --> 00:30:03.830
And now the command becomes very short,
so if you've sanitized your data,

561
00:30:03.830 --> 00:30:06.560
if you've gotten it in the right format,
this can be a pretty easy process.

562
00:30:06.560 --> 00:30:09.803
But I wanted to show you guys the most
likely, and this CSV is really

563
00:30:09.803 --> 00:30:13.425
representative of what almost every
developer's ever come to me with.

564
00:30:13.425 --> 00:30:16.528
[LAUGH] It's just,
Microsoft Excel, LibraOffice,

565
00:30:16.528 --> 00:30:21.350
they all export CSVs very easy, and that's
where your data normally comes from.

566
00:30:21.350 --> 00:30:24.190
Now I could have errors in here, so
I do need to be careful with that.

567
00:30:24.190 --> 00:30:26.960
And the recommendation is,
before you do any kind of bulk import,

568
00:30:26.960 --> 00:30:28.680
you should back up your database first.

569
00:30:28.680 --> 00:30:31.450
And that way, if there's a problem,
if you import bad data,

570
00:30:31.450 --> 00:30:33.050
maybe you labeled a column wrong.

571
00:30:33.050 --> 00:30:35.050
It's easy to just blow
away the database and

572
00:30:35.050 --> 00:30:37.700
restore it, I showed how to
do that in the last episode.

573
00:30:37.700 --> 00:30:40.690
But if you know everything's gonna work,
or if you're in a test environment,

574
00:30:40.690 --> 00:30:42.530
then it's easy to run through this,
it's not a big deal.

575
00:30:42.530 --> 00:30:46.740
And I'll normally restore data like
this to a test database first,

576
00:30:46.740 --> 00:30:50.080
make sure it works, and
then move it over into production, repeat.

577
00:30:50.080 --> 00:30:53.570
So, I'm gonna run that,
it's gonna ask me for my password.

578
00:30:53.570 --> 00:30:57.149
And there it goes, it's loading data from
the local file, it's reading through it.

579
00:30:57.149 --> 00:31:02.052
It found 101 records, it deleted zero,
skipped zero, so that's good.

580
00:31:02.052 --> 00:31:07.105
I did get four warnings,
is what it's telling me, I did a verbose,

581
00:31:07.105 --> 00:31:12.130
and I didn't see any on the screen,
so they were just warnings.

582
00:31:12.130 --> 00:31:14.520
I'd need to go back and
look at my data and make sure.

583
00:31:14.520 --> 00:31:18.654
If it were anything bad, like if I had
a name that was more than 50 characters or

584
00:31:18.654 --> 00:31:22.852
whatever, then it would've given me a red
flag, it wouldn't be a warning, but

585
00:31:22.852 --> 00:31:23.804
an actual error.

586
00:31:23.804 --> 00:31:26.540
But in my case, it looks like it's
brought it in, so we can go and

587
00:31:26.540 --> 00:31:29.802
verify that real quick, and
make sure that it's actually there.

588
00:31:29.802 --> 00:31:34.390
I'm gonna get back into my server, and

589
00:31:34.390 --> 00:31:39.406
once I'm in here, I'll do a USE company,

590
00:31:40.662 --> 00:31:46.860
And I'll say SELECT * FROM employees.

591
00:31:46.860 --> 00:31:49.620
Open up that table, show me what's
in there, let's see what happened.

592
00:31:49.620 --> 00:31:54.000
I should have imported 101 records,
that's what it told me, at least.

593
00:31:54.000 --> 00:31:56.400
And so when I look,
well there's my warning,

594
00:31:56.400 --> 00:31:58.980
that will actually be the four
warnings right there.

595
00:31:58.980 --> 00:32:02.150
I must have had an extra carriage
return at the end of the file,

596
00:32:02.150 --> 00:32:03.270
which is a blank line.

597
00:32:03.270 --> 00:32:06.580
And so that would have accounted for
four blank fields, and

598
00:32:06.580 --> 00:32:09.590
that would have been my four warnings,
I should have cleaned the file.

599
00:32:09.590 --> 00:32:12.210
You do want to make sure your file
is in the right state of mind, and

600
00:32:12.210 --> 00:32:15.470
having that extra carriage return at
the end created an extra record here.

601
00:32:15.470 --> 00:32:16.980
So I did have 100 employees, though,

602
00:32:16.980 --> 00:32:21.280
and if I look at my list here,
I have 100 employees starting with 1,

603
00:32:21.280 --> 00:32:24.880
going all the way up to 100,
and they're all loaded in here.

604
00:32:24.880 --> 00:32:28.257
Now I've actually got data in
the table and ready to work with, now,

605
00:32:28.257 --> 00:32:30.541
that's the hard way of
getting data in there.

606
00:32:30.541 --> 00:32:33.783
There are easier ways, but
this was kind of that hard example.

607
00:32:33.783 --> 00:32:35.288
And it kinda took a little
longer than I planned, so

608
00:32:35.288 --> 00:32:37.039
I think we're gonna go into
a part two to show the other way.

609
00:32:37.039 --> 00:32:37.677
>> Part two.
>> But

610
00:32:37.677 --> 00:32:39.599
I wanna show you the easier
way to bring it in,

611
00:32:39.599 --> 00:32:42.410
the way that you hope that
the developers bring it to you.

612
00:32:42.410 --> 00:32:45.320
And then I wanna show you how
we can actually use this data,

613
00:32:45.320 --> 00:32:47.990
what a SQL query actually looks like,

614
00:32:47.990 --> 00:32:51.550
and how that data functions, so
we'll tackle that in part two.

615
00:32:51.550 --> 00:32:54.110
>> And that will be in part two,
working with data, and

616
00:32:54.110 --> 00:32:56.180
becoming a Linux server administrator.

617
00:32:56.180 --> 00:32:58.500
Wonderful job as usual, Don, fantastic,

618
00:32:58.500 --> 00:33:00.895
any last words you want
to tease people with?

619
00:33:00.895 --> 00:33:03.487
>> The main thing,
when you do an import like this, again,

620
00:33:03.487 --> 00:33:05.170
make sure that you do a backup first.

621
00:33:05.170 --> 00:33:08.090
In case something goes wrong,
you can check it out, and find it out.

622
00:33:08.090 --> 00:33:12.990
Sanitize your file like I didn't do here,
make sure that stuff's accounted for.

623
00:33:12.990 --> 00:33:17.850
Also, make sure that you test the import
somewhere else first before doing it

624
00:33:17.850 --> 00:33:21.230
in production, you don't wanna
impact your production database.

625
00:33:21.230 --> 00:33:24.950
And remember performance,
because the larger the import,

626
00:33:24.950 --> 00:33:26.550
the bigger a hit it's
gonna put on the server.

627
00:33:26.550 --> 00:33:27.798
So it may slow down access for

628
00:33:27.798 --> 00:33:31.451
other users if they're simultaneously in
the system, so be aware of all of those.

629
00:33:31.451 --> 00:33:32.892
>> Fantastic, and don't forget,

630
00:33:32.892 --> 00:33:35.418
we're gonna be showing you
the easier way to import data.

631
00:33:35.418 --> 00:33:37.129
>> [LAUGH]
>> And that's gonna be in part two of

632
00:33:37.129 --> 00:33:39.802
working with data and

00:33:39.802 --> 00:33:41.372
And it's a whole bunch of videos,

634
00:33:41.372 --> 00:33:43.870
in the becoming a Linux
server administrator series.

635
00:33:43.870 --> 00:33:47.050
Make sure you watch every single one,
you'll be very glad you did.

636
00:33:47.050 --> 00:33:49.454
And thank you for
watching ITProTV, remember,

637
00:33:49.454 --> 00:33:51.983
a good IT pro is always learning,
I'm Zach Memos.

638
00:33:51.983 --> 00:33:52.573
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

>> And we will see you very soon.

1

And continuing on with

00:00:34.480 --> 00:00:37.680
Remember in this series what we're

00:00:37.680 --> 00:00:40.420
what a normal Linux server

17
00:00:40.420 --> 00:00:44.890
And showing how we can actually interact

and we've been working with MariaDB and

19
00:00:47.390 --> 00:00:50.747
We saw in the last episode how to

00:00:50.747 --> 00:00:53.533

23

24

25
