But now you're gonna show us the easier
way to import the data, correct?

26
00:01:06.710 --> 00:01:10.950
>> Yes, absolutely, and the example
that I ended the last show with was,

27
00:01:10.950 --> 00:01:16.470
if a developer or somebody comes to you
with a CSV, a comma separated values file.

28
00:01:16.470 --> 00:01:19.473
How you can import that into
a table inside of MySQL and

29
00:01:19.473 --> 00:01:21.085
that is incredibly common.

30
00:01:21.085 --> 00:01:23.579
Nine times out of ten when somebody
comes to me with data with to load,

31
00:01:23.579 --> 00:01:24.832
that's the format that it's in.

32
00:01:24.832 --> 00:01:27.441
So that's why it was important and
I wanted to show you guys that first.

33
00:01:27.441 --> 00:01:28.360
>> Right, right.

34
00:01:28.360 --> 00:01:30.530
>> Now I wanna show you what
is called the easy way.

35
00:01:30.530 --> 00:01:34.100
And I always know that I'm
working at a company with

36
00:01:34.100 --> 00:01:37.950
great data handlers when they come
to me with data in the right format.

37
00:01:37.950 --> 00:01:41.692
And if you've got statisticians or
actuaries or

38
00:01:41.692 --> 00:01:46.250
whatever who really know how to handle
data, they won't bring you data as a CSV,

39
00:01:46.250 --> 00:01:48.440
they'll bring it a different form, right?

40
00:01:48.440 --> 00:01:51.650
And that form is an SQL script.

41
00:01:51.650 --> 00:01:55.450
An SQL script, it's a text file,
a lot like a CSV is.

42
00:01:55.450 --> 00:01:59.811
Except it's specifically designed to
be imported into a relational database.

43
00:01:59.811 --> 00:02:03.265
And it's really amazing,
it makes our job a lot easier, and

44
00:02:03.265 --> 00:02:06.510
it minimizes the chance
of us making a mistake.

45
00:02:06.510 --> 00:02:11.140
It lets the data handlers, they build and
craft the data the way they want.

46
00:02:11.140 --> 00:02:14.060
And that way they ensure the data
comes in, in the right format.

47
00:02:14.060 --> 00:02:17.670
So if they bring you your
data in an SQL script, boy,

48
00:02:17.670 --> 00:02:21.720
it just makes your job so much easier and
you can import that data.

49
00:02:21.720 --> 00:02:25.100
So I've got an example script
like that I wanna show you guys.

50
00:02:25.100 --> 00:02:29.048
So in the last episode I used
this employees.csv, right?

51
00:02:29.048 --> 00:02:33.550
And with employees.csv, all it does is,

52
00:02:33.550 --> 00:02:36.980
maybe you have a header line,
I do, you don't always have that.

53
00:02:36.980 --> 00:02:39.550
And it just says, here's the data, right?

54
00:02:39.550 --> 00:02:41.550
It just kinda lays it out,
and there it goes.

55
00:02:41.550 --> 00:02:45.970
But we saw that when we imported this
data that we had to do a lot more.

56
00:02:45.970 --> 00:02:49.687
We had to create the table first,
we had to set the data types, right?

57
00:02:49.687 --> 00:02:53.667
And if I just have this, how do I know
what data type I should be using for

58
00:02:53.667 --> 00:02:54.650
these, right?

59
00:02:54.650 --> 00:02:57.780
What should be the maximum characters for
first name?

60
00:02:57.780 --> 00:03:02.810
And 1, is it just gonna be an integer or
should I make i this a big int?

61
00:03:02.810 --> 00:03:05.480
There's different types of

62
00:03:05.480 --> 00:03:09.850
mathematical data types you can use
depending on the size of the number.

63
00:03:09.850 --> 00:03:12.620
This might be a number that
could get really, really large.

64
00:03:12.620 --> 00:03:14.560
It might not even be something
we wanna to treat as a number.

65
00:03:14.560 --> 00:03:17.990
If it's something like a Social Security
number, where it's three digits and

66
00:03:17.990 --> 00:03:21.800
a hyphen, two digits and a hyphen,
four digits, that's not a normal number.

67
00:03:21.800 --> 00:03:24.750
I wouldn't make that an integer,
you can't put a hyphen in an integer.

68
00:03:24.750 --> 00:03:27.850
So now I need to treat that
as a string of some sort.

69
00:03:27.850 --> 00:03:33.986
As a server admin, we're not equipped
to make those decisions, right?

70
00:03:33.986 --> 00:03:38.376
So in bigger data houses where they have
professionals that are handling the data,

71
00:03:38.376 --> 00:03:42.790
they won't give it to you as a CSV,
they'll give it to you as an SQL script.

72
00:03:42.790 --> 00:03:45.399
And that's what this other one is,
employees.sql,

73
00:03:45.399 --> 00:03:46.824
so let's take a look at that.

74
00:03:46.824 --> 00:03:48.192
And actually, you know what?

75
00:03:48.192 --> 00:03:50.157
I'm going to open it up in vim,

76
00:03:50.157 --> 00:03:52.670
cuz it will be, actually I don't
know if it will be colorized or not.

77
00:03:52.670 --> 00:03:55.470
I don't remember if I installed
the full vim on this or not.

78
00:03:55.470 --> 00:03:56.340
Good, it's colorized, there.

79
00:03:56.340 --> 00:03:57.000
>> Wonderful.

80
00:03:57.000 --> 00:03:58.550
>> So when it opens,

81
00:03:58.550 --> 00:04:01.500
it's helpful to do this colorized,
cuz you can actually see what's going on.

82
00:04:01.500 --> 00:04:05.406
But notice that right off the bat,
it's got SQL commands,

83
00:04:05.406 --> 00:04:08.621
it's got Structured Query Language
commands.

84
00:04:08.621 --> 00:04:12.263
Drop table employees,
if the employees table already exists,

85
00:04:12.263 --> 00:04:13.630
it's gonna delete it.

86
00:04:13.630 --> 00:04:14.680
Why would I do that?

87
00:04:14.680 --> 00:04:16.790
Because right afterwards it's
going to recreate the table and

88
00:04:16.790 --> 00:04:19.470
make sure that it's set the right way.

89
00:04:19.470 --> 00:04:22.320
They're creating it, they're saying,
we're gonna create an ID.

90
00:04:22.320 --> 00:04:25.260
And it's not just an integer,
it's a medium int,

91
00:04:25.260 --> 00:04:27.940
they've actually modified
to a different type, right?

92
00:04:27.940 --> 00:04:31.690
Then FirstName, LastName, they're
doing variable character 255, right?

93
00:04:31.690 --> 00:04:34.210
Much larger than I was
defining in the last episode.

94
00:04:34.210 --> 00:04:37.520
Hey, you might have somebody with a really
long last name or really long first name,

95
00:04:37.520 --> 00:04:39.435
you wanna be able to accommodate that.

96
00:04:39.435 --> 00:04:41.265
Then we've got the department number,

97
00:04:41.265 --> 00:04:45.005
the primary key is that ID,
it's set to auto increment.

98
00:04:45.005 --> 00:04:47.405
All those things that we had
to define by hand last time,

99
00:04:47.405 --> 00:04:48.535
they've already defined for us.

100
00:04:48.535 --> 00:04:51.805
They know the table they want,
they know the way it needs to be designed,

101
00:04:51.805 --> 00:04:53.720
they just need us to import it.

102
00:04:53.720 --> 00:04:57.780
And then right after it
are insert into commands.

103
00:04:57.780 --> 00:04:59.850
And look at these insert into commands.

104
00:04:59.850 --> 00:05:02.070
This is one actually,
I guess, colorized here,

105
00:05:02.070 --> 00:05:03.770
it doesn't necessarily help that much.

106
00:05:03.770 --> 00:05:07.438
Let me pull this up not colorized.

107
00:05:07.438 --> 00:05:11.020
I guess I could've turned off colors
in vim, but we'll do it this way.

108
00:05:11.020 --> 00:05:16.100
So when I look at all these insert intos,
see how it's insert into employees?

109
00:05:16.100 --> 00:05:19.440
And then FirstName,
LastName, Department, and

110
00:05:19.440 --> 00:05:20.900
then here's the values that are coming in.

111
00:05:20.900 --> 00:05:24.532
So we've got Willis Later,
Tasha Travis, Aiden Rasmussen.

112
00:05:24.532 --> 00:05:28.929
It's bringing each of these people in, and
they're doing more than one insert into,

113
00:05:28.929 --> 00:05:30.210
why is that?

114
00:05:30.210 --> 00:05:32.010
Well, if an error occurs,

115
00:05:32.010 --> 00:05:36.390
the entire insert into gets rolled back,
so they've broken it up into sections.

116
00:05:36.390 --> 00:05:40.650
So if an error occurs, they can
identify exactly which area it was, and

117
00:05:40.650 --> 00:05:42.118
then just fix that smaller piece.

118
00:05:42.118 --> 00:05:46.050
It makes it easier to handle the data,
makes it less likely to have errors.

119
00:05:46.050 --> 00:05:49.340
You can actually provide too much data
sometimes, and the script doesn't process.

120
00:05:49.340 --> 00:05:52.940
So they've broken it up into
several insert into statements.

121
00:05:52.940 --> 00:05:55.070
It looks like they're doing
about 10 records for each,

122
00:05:55.070 --> 00:05:58.850
and there's a 100 records, so
there's 10 insert into statements.

123
00:05:58.850 --> 00:06:02.120
All of this is gonna build the table and

124
00:06:02.120 --> 00:06:06.520
import the data all in one
hard-to-screw-up script, right?

125
00:06:06.520 --> 00:06:10.440
If they've written it the way that they
want it, now I just need to bring it in,

126
00:06:10.440 --> 00:06:12.080
that's why I call it the easy way.

00:25:20.270 --> 00:25:22.172
We typically use DNS for this now, but

516
00:25:22.172 --> 00:25:25.218
older WIndows machines used
this master browser solution.

517
00:25:25.218 --> 00:25:28.976
If you don't have any Windows machines on
your network, if you've got all Linux or

518
00:25:28.976 --> 00:25:32.548
Linux and Mac, and you just happen to be
using Samba because, because [LAUGH].

519
00:25:32.548 --> 00:25:34.567
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well, that can be a problem,

520
00:25:34.567 --> 00:25:37.760
because you need at least one
master browser on the network.

521
00:25:37.760 --> 00:25:41.840
So if I want my system to be
able to perform that role,

522
00:25:41.840 --> 00:25:44.570
I'll wanna turn on
the NMB service as well.

523
00:25:44.570 --> 00:25:47.200
Fortunately, it doesn't really have any
configuration that we need to mess with by

524
00:25:47.200 --> 00:25:49.140
default, it works pretty
well out of the box.

525
00:25:49.140 --> 00:25:56.270
So I'm gonna enable the NMB service, and

526
00:25:56.270 --> 00:25:59.200
That's going to allow me to become
the master browser, and I need to do that

527
00:25:59.200 --> 00:26:02.880

running Red Hat Enterprise Linux.

528
00:26:02.880 --> 00:26:06.706

529
00:26:06.706 --> 00:26:08.990
I think I've got another virtual

530
00:26:08.990 --> 00:26:10.970

531
00:26:10.970 --> 00:26:14.670
I need that master browser, so
I'm gonna start up the NMB service.

532
00:26:14.670 --> 00:26:17.584
Even if I had Windows machines,
I could still do this and

533
00:26:17.584 --> 00:26:20.008

become a master browser.

534
00:26:20.008 --> 00:26:23.720

535
00:26:23.720 --> 00:26:26.306
So that's up,
I'm technically running Samba,

536
00:26:26.306 --> 00:26:29.455
there's a couple commands we
can use to check it real quick.

537
00:26:29.455 --> 00:26:33.563
So for example, I could try and
connect to my user account,

538
00:26:33.563 --> 00:26:37.520
users aren't authorized in
Samba by default, though.

539
00:26:37.520 --> 00:26:39.220
So if I wanna test with like my account,

540
00:26:39.220 --> 00:26:42.620
my dpezet account,
I would need to assign a Samba password.

541
00:26:43.860 --> 00:26:47.870
If I was connected to a domain, that's
where the Samba passwords would come from.

542
00:26:47.870 --> 00:26:52.401
I'm not connected to a domain,
so I need to do smb passwd,

543
00:26:52.401 --> 00:26:55.092
and point that at my, oops, -a.

544
00:26:55.092 --> 00:26:58.191
So I'm gonna add a Samba
password to my user account, and

545
00:26:58.191 --> 00:27:00.980
I'll just provide what I
want that password to be.

546
00:27:00.980 --> 00:27:03.890
And that's gonna enable
my user account in Samba.

547
00:27:03.890 --> 00:27:07.220
If I've got ten user accounts,
I'll need to enable each one of them.

548
00:27:07.220 --> 00:27:09.690
It becomes a burden after awhile, so
when your network grows large enough,

549
00:27:09.690 --> 00:27:12.850
they expect you to have a Windows domain
controller to pull all this from.

550
00:27:12.850 --> 00:27:14.002
But in a small environment,

551
00:27:14.002 --> 00:27:16.940
you can just attach that
password right here to each one.

552
00:27:16.940 --> 00:27:21.340
So, now I can use the SMB client
to be able to connect and look and

553
00:27:21.340 --> 00:27:22.280
see how things are doing.

554
00:27:22.280 --> 00:27:28.920
So for example, I can say smb-l localhost,

555
00:27:28.920 --> 00:27:32.070
and I can examine the local host and
see how things are going.

556
00:27:32.070 --> 00:27:39.590
Now, shoot, it's, I forgot, I did a sudo
shell, so I'm actually running as root.

557
00:27:39.590 --> 00:27:43.420
And so what you'll see here is that my
root user is gonna fail, because I didn't

558
00:27:43.420 --> 00:27:48.925
do an smb passwd for my root user.

559
00:27:48.925 --> 00:27:52.640
Cuz normally, you wouldn't want your
root user functioning inside of Samba.

560
00:27:52.640 --> 00:27:56.330
So I'm gonna exit out of my root shell,
so now I'm back to being good old dpezet.

561
00:27:57.330 --> 00:28:02.940
And I'll do a Samba client-Localhost,

562
00:28:02.940 --> 00:28:06.720
and I'll provide my password, and there.

563
00:28:06.720 --> 00:28:10.102
So what we should see is that
it shows each of the shares.

564
00:28:10.102 --> 00:28:14.898
Print$, dpezet,
that's my home directory, and

565
00:28:14.898 --> 00:28:19.592
I'm seeing the server,
DonsLab is my workgroup.

566
00:28:19.592 --> 00:28:22.950
And then Lab/Server01 is
the master browser on the network.

567
00:28:22.950 --> 00:28:27.060
I can see that it's up, I can see
that it's working and it's running.

568
00:28:28.110 --> 00:28:33.020
It is, however, not the best view that
I've got, cuz remember, SE Linux,

569
00:28:33.020 --> 00:28:36.670
how I set it not to do home directories,
but I see my home directory right here.

570
00:28:36.670 --> 00:28:40.420
If I were to browse into it, it is gonna
be blocked, so it is being advertised,

571
00:28:40.420 --> 00:28:42.690
but I can't get to it,
cuz SE Linux is stopping it.

572
00:28:42.690 --> 00:28:44.230
And this is a local view, so

573
00:28:44.230 --> 00:28:46.550
it's not necessarily indicative
of what we'd get on the network.

574
00:28:46.550 --> 00:28:49.748
But it is a quick way to test and
make sure that everything is up and

575
00:28:49.748 --> 00:28:53.611
running, and I at least think that I'm
advertising this out to the network.

576
00:28:53.611 --> 00:28:56.717
>> So Don, do we have time for
talking about firewall access, or

577
00:28:56.717 --> 00:28:58.670
should we save that for a part two?

578
00:28:58.670 --> 00:29:02.152
>> Yeah, in an ideal world,
we just enough time [LAUGH].

579
00:29:02.152 --> 00:29:04.119
>> [LAUGH]
>> In an ideal world,

580
00:29:04.119 --> 00:29:06.900
we'd test this from
the network if I had more time.

581
00:29:06.900 --> 00:29:09.890
Right now I know I've go a problem with
the firewall, like Zach mentioned.

582
00:29:09.890 --> 00:29:13.990
It might look great right here from the
server itself, but when I go to my client,

583
00:29:13.990 --> 00:29:15.370
it doesn't look so great anymore.

584
00:29:15.370 --> 00:29:19.970
So I do need to do a little bit more,
I'm gonna switch back to

585
00:29:19.970 --> 00:29:24.980
a root shell, and I'm gonna do a quick

586
00:29:24.980 --> 00:29:31.680
firewall-cmd--permanent--add-service=sa-
mba.

587
00:29:31.680 --> 00:29:34.370
I need to add the Samba
service to the firewall list,

588
00:29:34.370 --> 00:29:36.230
to allow it to pass through.

589
00:29:36.230 --> 00:29:40.403
And if I'm on a client, or even on
the server, I need to do -client as well,

590
00:29:40.403 --> 00:29:44.170
because that's gonna allow
the client protocols to connect in.

591
00:29:44.170 --> 00:29:47.342
So I want to be able to have
those cleared and authorized.

592
00:29:47.342 --> 00:29:50.090
Now, I did those as permanent, so
it'll only take effect after reboot.

593
00:29:50.090 --> 00:29:54.450
I could reload the firewall, or I can
just run it again without permanent, and

594
00:29:54.450 --> 00:29:56.060
that'll get that going, so
that clears the firewall.

595
00:29:56.060 --> 00:29:57.050
So now in theory,

596
00:29:57.050 --> 00:30:01.250
people on the network should be able
to browse through and get to me.

597
00:30:01.250 --> 00:30:05.480
Now, to test from somebody else, I could
use the Samba client to connect and

598
00:30:05.480 --> 00:30:06.540
look and see how things are going.

599
00:30:06.540 --> 00:30:10.280
I could test a few other things,
I didn't test NMB, so

600
00:30:10.280 --> 00:30:14.430
I did a smb client-Localhost.

601
00:30:14.430 --> 00:30:17.890
That was how I tested that
a few moments ago, and

602
00:30:17.890 --> 00:30:20.130
just kinda checked it on the SMB side.

603
00:30:20.130 --> 00:30:26.790
If I want to check on the NMB side,
I could, get back to my user account.

604
00:30:26.790 --> 00:30:29.897
I'll do an nmb lookup, and

605
00:30:29.897 --> 00:30:34.502
I can do a name lookup against my server.

606
00:30:34.502 --> 00:30:38.378
Now when I do a name lookup, I can say -u
localhost, so I'm just gonna do a lookup

607
00:30:38.378 --> 00:30:41.638
right here against the local host,
and then I could provide a name.

608
00:30:41.638 --> 00:30:44.637
I'm gonna have a little problem here,
my lm host file is empty, so

609
00:30:44.637 --> 00:30:46.043
I haven't defined any names.

610
00:30:46.043 --> 00:30:47.857
And it hasn't learned any
names from the network,

611
00:30:47.857 --> 00:30:49.300
cuz I don't have any Windows machines.

612
00:30:49.300 --> 00:30:51.130
But if there was a Windows
machine on the network,

613
00:30:51.130 --> 00:30:52.670
I could type something like labserver02.

614
00:30:52.670 --> 00:30:55.370
And it would test that lookup and

615
00:30:55.370 --> 00:30:59.360
respond back if it could find some
kind of answer for what that was.

616
00:30:59.360 --> 00:31:02.400
So that's a way that we could
test that other side, but

617
00:31:02.400 --> 00:31:05.010
at this point,
we've got the server up and running.

618
00:31:05.010 --> 00:31:09.860
We've cleared it through security,
SE Linux is happy, the firewall is happy.

619
00:31:09.860 --> 00:31:10.700
We're up and running,

620
00:31:10.700 --> 00:31:15.000
but we haven't actually created
a shared file, a shared folder.

621
00:31:15.000 --> 00:31:17.500
We got the default stuff,
which most of it, we're not using.

622
00:31:17.500 --> 00:31:21.245
I don't have any printers,
I'm not sharing my home directory, so

00:31:28.570 --> 00:31:29.329

00:31:29.329 --> 00:31:32.030

00:31:32.030 --> 00:31:34.850

00:31:34.850 --> 00:31:38.160
We go through and we do this stuff one

00:31:52.630 --> 00:31:57.034
So I would do it now, but we've run

00:31:57.034 --> 00:31:57.717
part two.

>> Not the dance, but the protocol.

16

Yep, so in this episode we are picking
back up where we left off in part one,

17
00:00:40.587 --> 00:00:42.574
which is,
in part one we stood up a Samba server.

18
00:00:42.574 --> 00:00:43.141
>> Yes.
>> But

it wasn't terribly exciting because we

20

So that the server is up and

21
00:00:49.475 --> 00:00:53.391
[LAUGH] So in this episode we're gonna

00:00:53.391 --> 00:00:57.694

23
00:00:57.694 --> 00:00:59.890
So that's what we've got coming

24
00:00:59.890 --> 00:01:02.230
>> That's right.
So we got all the assembly out of the way.

25
00:01:02.230 --> 00:01:04.690
We're all set to go to actually use Samba.

26
00:01:04.690 --> 00:01:06.410
So how do we get started?

27
00:01:06.410 --> 00:01:08.543
>> All right, so
I wanna run through a scenario here.

28
00:01:08.543 --> 00:01:11.692
And the scenario is I wanna
create a shared folder that my

29
00:01:11.692 --> 00:01:13.460
employees can get to.

30
00:01:13.460 --> 00:01:16.908
So this folder will be available for
them to get to and store all their data,

31
00:01:16.908 --> 00:01:18.902
cuz I don't wanna back up 100 laptops.

32
00:01:18.902 --> 00:01:20.936
I want them all store the data
on the central share so

33
00:01:20.936 --> 00:01:22.507
I could just back up the central share.

34
00:01:22.507 --> 00:01:24.028
So that's what I want to create.

35
00:01:24.028 --> 00:01:27.964
So step one,
we need to create that folder.

36
00:01:27.964 --> 00:01:30.123
Now where we create
the folder is important.

37
00:01:30.123 --> 00:01:32.561
Samba by default,
if you have SE Linux in place,

38
00:01:32.561 --> 00:01:35.300
Samba does not have access
to your file system.

39
00:01:35.300 --> 00:01:38.480
It only has access to a couple of folders,
the folder where its configuration is

40
00:01:38.480 --> 00:01:41.760
stored and the folder where
the printers are stored, that's it.

41
00:01:41.760 --> 00:01:43.899
So if I wanna share a file or
share a folder,

42
00:01:43.899 --> 00:01:47.475
I've got to mess around with SE Linux
a little bit and get that cleared.

43
00:01:47.475 --> 00:01:48.960
So that's where I'm gonna start.

44
00:01:48.960 --> 00:01:52.820
Now the most common place, and I'm on
my server, same server from part one.

45
00:01:52.820 --> 00:01:56.970
I'm gonna bump up to a elevated
privilege shell here with sudo-s.

46
00:01:56.970 --> 00:02:00.816
The most common place to put
the shared folders is in /var, right?

47
00:02:00.816 --> 00:02:03.290
/var might be a separate partition for
you.

48
00:02:03.290 --> 00:02:05.380
It might be on the same
partition as your root.

49
00:02:05.380 --> 00:02:06.971
It just depends on how you set things up.

50
00:02:06.971 --> 00:02:09.267
But /var is where various data goes,

51
00:02:09.267 --> 00:02:12.147
and this is certainly
going to be various data.

52
00:02:12.147 --> 00:02:16.570
[LAUGH] So I'm gonna go into /var and I'm
just gonna make a folder which I'll call,

53
00:02:16.570 --> 00:02:17.910
we'll do corp, right?

54
00:02:17.910 --> 00:02:19.545
So this is gonna be my corporate data.

55
00:02:19.545 --> 00:02:24.850
And i'm not creative with names so
I'll just call it corp So /var/corp.

56
00:02:24.850 --> 00:02:28.990
Now if I do a ls -l with a capital Z,

57
00:02:30.000 --> 00:02:34.760
I can see the SE Linux context
of that file, or folder.

58
00:02:34.760 --> 00:02:38.084
And in this case, I can see that
it's currently unconfined, right?

59
00:02:38.084 --> 00:02:40.180
So it's just a standard object.

60
00:02:40.180 --> 00:02:43.541
And that means that Samba
will not have access to it.

61
00:02:43.541 --> 00:02:48.302
So in order for Samba to get to that, I'm
gonna have to adjust those permissions and

62
00:02:48.302 --> 00:02:52.871
make sure that it's set so that it will
have that access and be able to get there.

63
00:02:52.871 --> 00:02:57.400
So we can fix that pretty easy with
a chcon, which is change context.

64
00:02:57.400 --> 00:03:01.160
And I will just punch that in with a,
I'm gonna do a -r,

65
00:03:01.160 --> 00:03:04.160
cuz I'm in the habit of doing it,
which is make it recursive.

66
00:03:04.160 --> 00:03:06.540
If there were subfolders I'd
wanna change their context, too.

67
00:03:06.540 --> 00:03:10.080
I just made this, so I don't need the -r,
but I'll do it anyway.

68
00:03:10.080 --> 00:03:11.740
And then a v for verbose.

69
00:03:11.740 --> 00:03:15.090
If there's any errors I wanna
see the errors in detail.

70
00:03:15.090 --> 00:03:16.624
And the context type is,

71
00:03:16.624 --> 00:03:20.726
this is really the tricky part
is remembering the context_type.

72
00:03:20.726 --> 00:03:25.924
The context_type here is samba_share_t,
right?

73
00:03:25.924 --> 00:03:31.280
That's the context_type that
I wanna assign to /var/corp.

74
00:03:31.280 --> 00:03:34.111
So that's what's gonna clear
it to be able to get in there.

75
00:03:34.111 --> 00:03:37.943
And then I can verify that took
effect by looking back in here.

76
00:03:37.943 --> 00:03:40.542
And sure enough,
I can see that samba share is defined.

77
00:03:40.542 --> 00:03:43.240
It's got the right context on that folder.

78
00:03:43.240 --> 00:03:46.870
So now we're clear there to be able to use
this folder in the way that we attended.

79
00:03:46.870 --> 00:03:48.970
Now I might need to change
the permissions on the folder.

80
00:03:48.970 --> 00:03:53.220
Remember that Samba does obey
the Unix ACLs, the Access Control Lists.

81
00:03:53.220 --> 00:03:55.550
